I was looking for wireless headphones for my work and seriously considered Sony 1000X vs. Bose QC 35. While I was watching so many reviews, I found Sony just updated the 1000X, so I jumped into WH 1000XM2! I tried on both 1000XM2 and Bose QC 35 and honestly think that both are great headphones. Sony 1000XM2 has more features and longer battery life so I am very content with my purchase.

#Features
The touchpad is not a new feature but it is worth mentioning since Bose does not have this feature. Swipe up or down to control the volume. Swipe right or left to change the music. It is very intuitive and easy. You can even press long to activate Siri. Double tap to stop music or take a phone call.
Also, you can cup the right ear and disable the noise canceling and listen to others.

You can check the battery level by the home screen of a smartphone. I have only seen even numbers such as 100%, 70%, and 50% (then I would charge so I have not seen low numbers because of the reason). Maybe the headphone cannot tell the battery level precisely.

#Bluetooth connection
Bluetooth connection is great. I can leave my phone and go to next room without breaking the connection. Switching the devices is not easy though. With Bose, you can connect two devices at the same time. However, with 1000XM2, you need to disconnect one device to use other device.

To switch the device (updated)
1. Go to setting. Bluetooth, then disconnect WH-1000XM2.
2. Go to the other device, hit setting, Bluetooth, then click to connect.

If you don't want to touch the device connected currently but wans to switch the device (for example, 1000XM2 is connected to iPad that is in your bag and you don't want to pull it out), you can
1. Turn off the 1000XM2
2. Turn on and keep pressing power button to activate bluetooth pairing.
3. Go to your device you want to connect. Hit setting, bluetooth, then connect to 1000XM2.

Honestly, I don't mind doing this but I wish we could connect two iOS devices at the same time.

#Noise canceling
Sony and Bose are both excellent noise cancelling (NC) headphones. While QC35 cannot turn off the NC, 1000XM2 can turn of NC. Previous 1000X had a problem with phone call where you cannot hear yourself (so you end up shouting). Sony has fixed this problem and now 1000XM2 let you hear your voice easily with voice focus mode. Making phone call is much easier now.

#Sony headphone connect app
This app allows you to change the setting of NC based on your activity. You can pre-set the level of NC + voice focus according to your activity (rest, walking, running, and transportation). For frequent fliers, it can adjust the pressure too. You can also change where the sound comes from. For example, you can set as if the sound comes from your back.

When I was using 1000XM2 in the office, I used voice focus mode. It was very interesting experience because I did not hear any noise from construction etc but I heard my coworkers voice. Voice is picked up from the mic so it is an interesting experience.

#Gorgeous look
It honestly looks fantastic. I usually pick the black color but I tried gold at this time. The case of headphone had two-tone color (gold in the middle). It looks great. Please look at attached pictures as it tells you more how nice it looks. The headphone has hinges so you can actually make it very small and put it into the case.

#Sound
I cannot speak too much about the sound because I am not a professional musician. However, in my opinion, it sounds absolutely nice. It sounds even better than Bose QC35 but it is just my opinion. With the connect app, you can also change the sound effect such as Arena, Club, Outdoor Stage, and Concert Hall. It is subjective so you might want to try it before you buy, but I am very much satisfied.

#Comfort
This is where BOSE QC35 (quiet comfort) comes into play. WH 1000XM2 is comfortable but I feel my ears are hot after using this for 1 hour. The pad is touching my ears with 1000XM2 whereas QC35 has deeper ear pad. QC35 is much more comfortable for me.

#Sturdy design
I know cracking was the problem with 1000X. So far, it has been OK but I will definitely give updates after using several months (hope nothing will happen). It looks very sturdy and does not make the clicking sound when I open the headphone.

So which one you should buy? I am very happy with 1000XM2 because it has many features and long battery life (30 hours!). However, you may want to try it on before you buy because BOSE is more comfortable.

You have to have them adjusted just right to be comfortable for long periods but once you find that sweet spot can wear for hours and hours and the sound is awesome out of the headphones. Hard to find replacement pads though.

These headphones are one of my favourite things. They are so well built and are fully sound cancelling. I had the MDR1000x before this and decided to upgrade for the better battery life and app support. I’m going to list the pros and cons I’ve encountered so far and give some recommendations. FYI, I’ve never owned (but have tested) the QC35, beats solo and studio, and own the Senhiessers 550HD.

-Pros-
1) These are top notch in terms of noise cancelation and isolation. The mdr1000x were great and these are the same if not a step up. I could be mowing or trimming the lawn and if I close my eyes I’m in a totally different world. Can’t tell a machine is functioning in front of me.
2) Touchpad: this is such a cool feature. I’m an adoptee of new tech and have been loving it. Sometimes it doesn’t register my hand gestures but I mean it’s not the end of the world. Always registers the second time. The palm over to bring outside noise is super cool, but no one on the other end knows what’s going on. I’d be on a bus and talk to the driver and he’d think I’m on the phone and ignore me. But super cool nonetheless!
3) Battery life, 30-40 hours is Sony’s estimate I believe I’ve been getting very close to that as I go on walks and listen to music while studying overall super happy about it!
4) App is easy to use to pick between different general modes. Kinda cool. One con about this is I use tidal and the music centre only functions with Apple Music (I just use iOS and tidal. Dunno about Spotify or other platforms.
5) These headphones work great wirelessly and last long. But a great pro to them is when you connect the wires you get even better quality! Who knew that could be possible. Another pro is you could use the headphones when dead (without any of the extra bells and whistles) so having the wire on you is the equivalent to carrying another pair of headphones ;)

-Cons-
1) Potential chance of crack? I had the MDR 1000x for months and did not face the crack issues other have. But in my opinion, I totally agree with the video listed where the guy says the cracks are an easy con for the many pros and it’s something you should consider for yourself whether you care enough about that. Are there better speakers out there for the same price range? Yes. Do they have the same functions the Sony has? Not likely (touchpad particularly) is it worth its money? Yes!
2) The bag is the exact same and not very well made in my opinion. Nice that Sony puts it I but I mean you’ll likely want to get one yourself.
3) Connectivity not as (I’ve heard) easy as QC35 or others. Honestly, this isn’t a huge con but I listed it so you can have it in perspective. Do you want to connect to another device? Disconnect from the Bluetooth settings and connect to them on the other device. If the device is in your bag hold the power button to turn off, then continue to hold it after it turns on until it says pairing. I use 5 devices and this hasn’t been an issue for me.

This pair of headphones is well packaged and, in my humble opinion, well priced. You risk it having a small crack, I’ve never had, but for all the extras you get, it’s well worth it. Another thing is Sony did price it lower than the older model so it’s not like they’re charging extra for more functions. The pad sometimes doesn’t register stuff, but I think that’s more me getting used to it than it getting used to me. It's a give and take situation it does stuff for you but you have to learn to function with it and around its flaws.

A few things to improve on would be to have the headphones announce what they’re connected to rather than just staying connected. I believe this won’t be hard for Sony to add through the app, could be wrong, and then again it might not be something they want to do, to begin with. Would’ve loved to see USB type-C on this model. USB-C is the future would be great when small gadgets like this embrace that.

I’d recommend these to anyone who is looking to get a good quality headphone that is versatile with great sound cancelling and new technology. This is and will be for some time my daily driver for headphones.

Hope this helps some of you decide whether it’s a good fit for you — I’ll update this as time goes in regards to my experience with battery life, the infamous cracks and such.

I'll keep it short. I read the reviews of the Sony WH1000XM2 and the Bose QuietComfort 35 II and could not decide which to choose, so I bought both. I will return the Sony and keep the Bose. Here are the pros and cons:

Sony:
+ Crisper highs and deeper bass (I can't see how anyone says the Bose model sounds better)
+ Better song navigation with the figure gestures on side of right headpiece
- When making phone calls, those on the other end hear more of your background noise than on the Bose (I tested by calling from a land line to a family member who used my Sonys)
- Heavy on the head and hurts to wear for long periods (this was a deal breaker for me)
- Finger navigation feature is too sensitive sometimes - easy to skip/rewind songs by accident.

Bose
+ Great noise cancellation, especially with no music (better than Sony's)
+ Light weight and definitely more comfortable for long periods
+ Best for phone calls (those on other end don't hear much background noise)
- Sound is missing crispness at high and low ends; overall sounds are a bit muffled (it would be great to get Sony's sound on these speakers). If music quality is your deal breaker, buy the Sonys for sure.

In the end, I couldn't get over the uncomfortable aspect of the Sonys. I really preferred the Sony sound, but didn't see myself wearing the Sonys for long periods of time. My primary reason for buying these was muffling office and plane engine noise for long periods of time, therefore comfort was a deal breaker. It also helps that I can take conference calls on these.

I bought these headphones to replace my top-of-the-line Sony MDR-1RNC headphones, which have unbelievably great sound quality but they have been acting up lately (very frustrating). Let me first say that out of the box, the new 1000XM2 headphones had a little better noise cancelling than the MDR-1RNCs but the sound quality was not even close to what I was hoping for. The sound of these new headphones was really muddy with way to much mid-bass frequencies. But then I discovered the iPhone/iPad App for the WH1000XM2s which allows you to customize equalization settings (among other things). After reducing the level at 400 Hz (the muddy frequency range), increasing the levels for 1K, 2.5K, 6.3K, and 16K, and then increasing the level for clear bass (the lowest bass setting), I was able to get the nice V-shaped frequency response that make these headphones sound fantastic. No more mud, everything is crystal clear but not harsh, and the bass is really punchy without drowning out the mids and highs. It sounds great for all genres that I’ve tested (jazz, orchestral, pop, soundtrack, etc). I’ve attached an image of my equalization settings for anybody who wants to give what I did a try. Also, the Bluetooth connection works/sounds great with my iPad and iPhone and the battery seems to last a long time before needing to be recharged. So, these are now my go-to headphones for fun listening with unrivaled noise cancelling.

I've been using these daily for a couple of months now so I could really provide a great review. I use these to block noise in loud data centers while on the phone and for listening to music. These replaced a set of Bose headphones that my wife claimed as her own. Overall I like these more than the Bose set and here's why.
Noise Cancelling - my Bose headset is an older set (it's 7 years old now) but the noise cancelling on these is every bit as good as these are for the noise in a data center. If you've never been in a data center, it's a constant cacophony of high speed fans with more 'background' noise than found in normal commercial aircraft. It's the ultimate test for noise cancelling. I put these on and the noise level was decreased dramatically just from the well padded ear cups. Then I turn it on. Blissful near silence. Sure, I can hear some of the ancillary noises, but for the first time I can hear the subtle beeping of computers doing their thing. Way cool.
Next, I fire up my music app of choice - Pandora. I have an eclectic taste in music - U2 to Beethoven, Collective Soul to Moby, and just about everything in between. Unlike the Bose, the overall sound response is crisp, clear, and balanced. The Bose kit seemed a little bass heavy to me. Music is reproduced without hiss, buzz, or other artifacts.
Excited by this, I head home and fire up my lossless music subscription and bring up a collection of Jazz greats. I can hear it all. Wood creaking as the artist shifts their seat. The soft 'clump' of valves. No hiss. And this is through the bluetooth connection, NOT through the included cable. Amazing.
Now, I'm not a crazy audiophile. I've been plagued with tinnitus since birth so much of the subtle points is lost on me simply because of the ringing BUT I've been able to hear things using this set of headphones from music that I've never heard before WHILE in a loud data center.
I've worn these constantly for 10+ hours and aside from a little warmth, they were extremely comfortable. Battery life is every bit of 20 hours with no need to recharge after two days of heavy use.
The app that you can use with these is pretty easy to use and has some unique features. It is able to detect your actions and adjust noise cancellations accordingly. If you are on the street perhaps you want to me more aware of your surroundings. If you are sitting in a chair perhaps you want to block out more noise. This system will detect and adapt automatically. It's pretty effective and actually detects things pretty well. Going for a walk reduced the cancellation levels while sitting in my office increased it. Using the other tools is likely more of a gimmick - different sound stages (arena, outdoors, etc) Meh - not much difference really. Being able to change the directionality of the sound is also fun to play with and is very effective, but I fail to see the real point of this. Other neat features are the ability to control the headset using 'gestures' - tap to pause, swipe to change volume or advance tracks, and cup to enhance conversation. These are all extremely effective and useful. The 'cupping' motion continues to block lower mhz sound (jet engines, etc) while enhancing the sound range of normal human voices. Short conversations are easy even without taking these off. Swiping quickly becomes second nature and is extremely effective.
Bottom line is this - after owning several of the Bose offerings and really linking them, this set does a better job of faithfully recreating the original intent of sound to your ears than the Bose set does. Bose headsets are WONDERFUL and some of the music I listen to does sound better coming from them (I'm looking at you, dubstep), much of the other music is cleaner coming from these. Noise cancelling is jaw droppingly effective. Battery life is phenomenal. Overall the sound quality and technical features built in to this edge out the Bose in an unofficial head to head comparison.

Just a great pair of headphones with a superb sound quality. Well done Sony.

Update: well yes great sound quality, but after 5 months, same problem as previous model, mine got broken as usual at the headband.According to Sony, this is "physical damage".. Now I took good care of them and put them always in the original case... Omg Sony... What a disaster. Exactly today I was considering to pre-order the new camera Sony A73.... Well I might think twice after this treatment.

After hours of research on product reviews, I bought this pair of cans. When it arrived, I loved how it looked, felt and sounded. Then I noticed the ONLY ONE yet CRITICAL problem shortly. Whenever I move my head and there is little pressure on my left side of head, there is a squeaky sound and it is annoying. Especially, since you are isolated from noise from surrounding environment thanks to superb noise cancelling function, this squeaky noise from right inside your left cup sounds emphasized. I love the first impression of this product so I am returning back to get a replacement hoping that I have received a defective one.

I will definitely update this review after I receive the replacement product.

UPDATE 1 : I am still waiting for the replacement product to arrive. However, I found another issue meanwhile. When it is connected via its supplied audio cable, I only hear music via left cup only. It leads me to the conclusion that I have received a defective one. I just hope that next one will not have these issues.

UPDATE 2 : Thanks to the greatest Amazon return policy, I received the replacement within one day after filing a claim.

Firstly, this annoying squeaky sound inside the cup still exists. This replacement pair squeaks less than the first one to be honest, however, the problem still remains. If SONY reads this, I have a theory why this happens. I think the speaker cone works like a suction cup or plunger creating the crumbling sound from this flimsy speaker cone material whenever the cup is being pushed toward. Perhaps, few invisible tiny bits of vent holes can prevent this issue. I don't know how it will affect the noise isolation. Please, look into it.

Secondly, when it is connected via its audio cable, it works as advertised. Problem solved. Hooray~.

Lastly, I think this may be a mere software or phone specific (Samsung Galaxy S5) issue. Whenever I change the sound priority option, the headphone turns off and has to be reconnected. I hope this can be fixed by any future update.

I think this is a good pair of cans with great sound, superb noise cancelling and lots of useful functions. Yet, I think its craftsmanship falls a bit short as a premium headphone. Thus my initial 2 star rating remains the same. I am still thinking whether I should keep this or try something else such as Bose QC35. I guess I will find out within Amazon's return grace period.

Great great quality of sound! This unit comes with diverse product features that can be interpreted as good value from a consumer's perspective.
HOWEVER, no way to listen to music more than an hour because TOO heavy and the ear cups were somewhat smaller than mine (Don't think that my ears are far beyond average; mines are smaller than average). Too heavy, too tight mean very uncomfortable, although sound was the best one I've tried so far. It ended with returning it, thereby.

Easily the best sounding bluetooth wireless in the price range. However, they just aren't as comfortable as Bose QuietComfort which is a huge bummer. My ears fatigue from the pressure and if headphones aren't comfortable, you don't wear them. It won't matter if they sound better than other headphones. I can wear my Bose all day. I can wear my Sony's for about two to three hours before my ears tire from the pressure and uncomfortable ear pads. You will have to decide what's more important to you: comfort or best sound.

OK, my personal comparison of the Sony WH-1000Xm2 and the Bose Quietcomfort 35 II is complete. After reading all the reviews, the Sony seemed to win out, but with Amazon's generous return policy, I purchased both and did a several hour comparison yesterday. Both are great, but here's what pushed me over the edge for Bose.

1. Sound. I am not an audiophile so the terms I use in this section to describe what I experienced may be technically incorrect terms, so bear with me. The Bose sound is amazing. It is crisp and clean and full. I can hear so much more in the same music I have been listening to for years. It's hard to explain but the Sony seemed compressed while the Bose feels full. The highs are better on the Bose and the there is separation in the music. The bass on the Sony seems louder, but not crisp and clean like it does on the Bose. The Sony sound is very good but compressed and almost muddy compared to the Bose. I know reviews say the Sony sounds better, but I just don't hear it that way. I found myself cutting my Sony tests short so I could go back to the Bose.

2. Comfort. The Bose is lighter and more comfortable for me. The Sony felt heavy in comparison.

Every other feature became unimportant to me after hearing the sound and feeling the comfort. Both eliminated noise and did everything else fine.

Nothing against the Sony WH-1000Xm2 - it is a great product, but for me I'm keeping the Bose and sending back the Sony's.

After spending a week with these headphones all i can is wow. There very comfortable with plus like leather. And the Noise cancelation with the Sony app is spot on either when I start walking out my apt or sitting on the bus the headphones with the app adjust noise canceling levels accordingly. Not sure about the headband cracking since I haven't had them that long but they seem fine. I'm very happy with my purchase

These have great sound, but the build quality is very bad, and Sony's customer support is truly horrible. Don't buy these.
To preface this review, I purchased these for work, and they never left my office. When not on my head, they were on a headphone rack.
The first big bummer is that, unlike my Bose QC35's, the Sony cannot connect to multiple devices. So no listening to music through the computer but still being able to take calls. That's a huge downside.
Next, the power button "sank" into it's slot. Originally, there was a little feedback when you pressed the power button - a "click" so to speak. Then the button was really deep with no feedback. I have to jam my finer in and the only way I know I'm doing it right it to wait for the lights to blink.
I called Sony a few months after buying to see about getting the faulty button fixed. After over an hour on the phone they told me it was my fault and that I had abused them. As noted above, these never left my desk, and were either on my head or on a headphone rack. Sony was absolutely horrible.
A few weeks later, the "ambient noise" button above the power button did the same thing. It still works, but it's just annoying that something as common as a button doesn't work.
I've gone back to my almost three year old Bose QC35's for the office, and these are my "iPad shows in bed" headphones. That brings up the last annoying bit - there's a flashing blue light that you can't turn off, so when wearing these in the dark there's a constant distracting flash that's really bright, both peripherally and on the screen of the iPad.
Overall I'm really bummed, and am stuck with these mediocre defective cans that Sony won't fix. Buy the Bose - they're better.

First and foremost I hope this review those who have been thinking about these headphones to make a good decision whether these headphones are really for you and not compulsively buy the Sony WH1000XM2. So this review will be pretty detailed concerning these headphones. To get it out of the way, yes, these are the best sounding headphones with the most potential on the average consumer flagship market right now. After reading many reviews, I find that not everyone is a tech enthusiast or know holistically about these. So I will address the problems then get into what I like.

Do these suffer from the same cracking issue as the mdr?: From my experience, they have not. The hinges are mostly a plastic finish with some metallic bands encircling the arch of the headphone and no these are not water resistant. This makes the headphones sturdy, however, with a sufficient enough stress, you can crack the hinges on the headphones. You can also hurt the overall durability but stretching the headphone to far constantly. Jimmy reviews did a stress test but that was mainly the outside arch and not the inside hinges, which are durable so far.

Why do these sound different across phones?: Sony really pushes advertising for LDAC, if you do not own a Sony phone or own an android phone with android oreo (any phone that came out before 2017 barring the google pixel). Do not worry, most 2016 flagships will be getting android oreo later this year which will come LDAC. If you do not own an LDAC compatible device then you will notice a DRASTIC change in sound quality. Not to say that phones without LDAC will not sound good but the older your phone, the less bit rates it can transfer to the headphones which affects the quality. Those who own android 8 (or those that are sony fans in general) are the ones touting how amazing these headphones are. I noticed that those with older phones were the ones complaining how they were not up to par, typically, there are some who talked about how they were great but not on Bose level with android oreo 8 phones and sony phones but it was very few.

Are these bass heavy?: These are bass heavy depending on your sound stage and your EQ settings. The Sony's have Arena, Club, Concert, Outside stage or off (neutral sound). Also depends on whether you have DSEE HX active on auto or not (mainly CD quality or not). By the way, in order to customize the sound you need to have an emphasis on stable connection. An emphasis on sound quality will mean that your headphones will optimize the song for you. You will need to use the Sony app (this is not compatible with the MDR as it is a software limnitation). There are two more aps such as the sony music app that you really do not need and another app called smart connect. Essentially controlling what your headphones do at a certain time. Such as noting that at 4:00 you can call a friend that time. Or playing a certain song at a time (which I assumed is where the music center comes into play)

Club: The most bass heavy soundstage of the four. It sounds as if you are right in front of the stereo that is playing. In short, this works with bass dominant EQ settings with high volumes. It can work with mellow songs but it is more geared towards bass.

Arena: Ever been at a music festival or hardstyle's Qlimax? It sounds like you are in the middle. So the music is farther away and this sound stage places an emphasis on vocals and bass (with a far away reverb effect) so you there are 3 drivers that work to create this. This is primarily good for mid bass emphasis and treble heavy songs. Vocals also go well with this but can go with another sound stage.

Concert: As the name implies, as if you at a music concert. Vocal heavy sounds are recommended moreso than bass heavy songs. There is a lot of reverb with this sound stage so prepare to hear a lot of echo which actually sounds wonderful. Bass heavy songs are hit or miss. Beethoven, thomas bergusen, mark petrie, other choir songs work. Treble is nice here too.

Outside stage. Combine club and arena. Good amount of bass and vocals, This can essentially work with any song, it is kind of like off but the best for average optimization as the music feels more "alive" so to speak. if you have a balance enough amount of bass and treble with a bit more emphasis on vocals in your EQ, then you will get the most out of this sound stage. The song still sounds less in your face as the club sound stage but still great nonetheless.

Off: How you would listen to any headphone really without any additives and just your EQ.

Are these better than the beats studio 3, Bose QC II, Senheiser px550: IT really depends on your taste.each produce their own sound, some people like the bose for the comfort, if you are comfortable while listing to music, your music naturally sounds better. They are definitely better than beats though, but between senheiser, bose, and these pair, you will not really be disappointed. The willikans are also amazing but their comfortably is abysmal in my opinion.

I mainly chose the Sony because it is not a one trick pony and actually offers a variety of options and features that makes these headphones great. What blows you away is really up to how you customize your headphones, how loud the volume is, your EQ, your sound stage. It never distorts which is nice.

You can control the direction of where the sound comes from as well. This is useful if you are in an area where you need to talk to someone but change the a hip-hop song to feel like it is coming from behind you so you can still hear the person talking. On that note, it is important to mention that using this option, automatically shuts off any sound stage you are using and reverts it back to off. Your EQ will be fine though and DSSE HX will be fine.

The best feature is probably how you can change your noise cancellation in 20 levels and whether you want a focus on voice, not only that, you can have it automatically adjust depending on what you are doing. These are not the first to do this, the nuhera earbuds did this but the technology was early and thus it was not really all that good. Dare I say that Sony has perfected it. At 0 you cannot hear anything while music is playing and you only really hear someone if they are shouting at the top of their lungs or if you get hit by a cup by one of your coworkers to get your attention. At 20, you can hear all your surrounding or you can place your hand over the right earcup to block out sound and lowers the volume (if the volume was high, you still hear the song but it is still faint). Best in ANC right now

You can also activate the assistent by long pressing the right earcup then just speak. It is a bit better than cheaper earphones as you need to wait for awhile. Not as good as bose though as that is near instant but nice enough.

The main bad thing is the comfortability, while these are decent to wear, not as comfortable as Bose but after awhile, your ears can feel pressured by the earcup. You have to adjust the earcup to your ears manually (It is kind of odd to explain) but it fits that way. Even then, you can feel uncomfortable after about an 1 or 3 hours if you're used to them.

Overall, these are wonderful headphones for the money right now. If you do not have a phone that has LDAC then these will still sound great but you may feel as if "maybe these can do a bit more". You will not be dsappointed, any additional feature is already in description and features. The atomospheric pressure just makes your song slow down as the altitude gets higher, it solves a problem nobody had but is nice none the less. You will not be disappointed by this pair but still surf around. If you okay with headphones with moderate comfortably but with amazing sound and a variety of features then these will do the job.

TLDR: Expensive but very high quality construction and sound, a must buy.

Pros:

- Sound is incredible. All highs, mids, and lows are clear and crisp.
- Feel and weight is on point. This headset feels good. I can wear it all day without discomfort.
- Battery length is what is being advertised. I could easily run the headset all day without issue.
- People complain about the touch controls but I personally love them once I understood how they worked. The Sony competitor doesn't have the ability to skip tracks and that is an important feature for me. The touch controls are well done and I haven't had a single problem with them.
- Noise cancelling is very good. The headset keeps out all of the ambient sound in my office, which is an incredible feat of engineering IMO.

Cons:

- Even after EQ adjustment, the bass isn't as deep as I'd like. I'd like a little more bass out of these headphones.
- The mic for calling isn't noise cancelling, which I thought that it was.
- Expensive! This headset is very pricey.
- Minor gripe but this thing should be USB C. I don't understand why Micro is still being used.
- The advertised ability to "quickly disable noise cancelling" to hear people talking around you is buggy and inconsistent. It is a good idea but poorly executed. Most of the time, I will tap and nothing will happen.

I got these babies for the gym because I can’t stand earbuds. These Sony Headphones look freaking slick. The touch controls are a brilliant addition, sure my shoulder will rub against it and pause it once in a while but switching volume/songs/pausing without needing your phone is a huge plus. The build has been grea so far, I put them in my gym bag without the case a lot. I obviously don’t trash them because they’re $350 headphones but they have stood up through a lot of use. The battery is outstanding, and awesome having a battery indicator on your phone. The noise cancelling is so well done. These are better than Boss, plus the sound quality is pretty damn good. Bass is nice, clear crisp sound. I honestly am happy I spent the extra to get these headphones. Way better than Beats too. The ear cups are very comfortable, and Are not too hot for extended use.

These are amazing. Buy the if they are in your budget.

Pros
They sound and noise canceling are great.
They can change NC mode when you walk around allowing you to hear ambient sound if you chose to.
Sound controls on the ear piece work very well. The app is very easy to use.
Covering the right ear piece with your hand you can hear ambient great for planes and coworkers. (Stretching your arms up can also trigger this if you touch them.rare scenario.)

Cons
Cost is high
They do feel hot to wear after a while. Not comfortable on hot days. Bose may be a better fit there.
Can become uncomfortable on long flights. After about 4-6 hours. Bose seem to have all day comfort.

Comfort is high on my list and I still chose these.

I love the color, sound, noise-cancellation (on par with Bose) and tech features. I think the fit is slightly tight, but I could have lived with it.

I am returning the product, however, because it does not support true bluetooth multi-point connectivity. It does support connecting one device in "headphone" mode (no mic) and another device simultaneously in "headset" mode... however I need to connect to both a laptop and my phone and have the mic activated for both. It's too bad, I liked the product otherwise.

I was really confused with bose quite comfort and Sony 1000x. I ended up buying both :)

Now that I have used both of them, Sony outranks Bose in every department. If you are a techie, Sony is what you want. The ambient sound enhancer is a feature to die for. Just place your hand on your right ear cuff and boom suddenly you can hear everything. The noise cancelling is simply Amazing, I tested both these headphones next to a vacuum cleaner, Sony has far outperformed Bose. You can hear absolutely nothing on Sony. Bose too does a good job but, Sony is far better.
Sound quality is comparable on both.

People say Sony is a bit heavier, I couldn’t find any notable difference.

These headphones sound great. I was between these and Bose but I felt the bose sounded too artificial. The Sony’s have a nice soundstage with accurate mids and highs, and a nice punchy bass. Comfort is top notch, with little fatigue after long listening sessions. Noise canceling is amazing, the world becomes silent and I think it’s better than bose. Well worth the money.

I lov'em, plain and simple, they are comfortable (I have small ears tho), stylish and the active noise cancelling is top notch. Price is high, but imho is well deserved. The tactile interface on the right earpad works really well: it's not a gimmick (that was my initial fear), but a useful feature that wont make you miss the presence of physical buttons.
If you are really into customizations, the app can give you a good range of freedom about EQ, sound positioning and the threshold of the noise cancelling feats, however you can easily live with the out of the box defaults.

My only complaint is the quality of conversation when used to answer a phonecall: mics are distant and you may sound very distant to the other sid, most of the time you will find yourself screaming in the crowd (since sound proofing is so good you can't hear your own voice, but of course other people can)

Fantastic headphones. Was going to wait for Sony’s Bluetooth 5.0 headphones next year but couldn’t resist buying these. I’m glad I did though. They sound clean, crisp and precise. Very spacious sound. They look and feel great as well. They do get hot though after a while. More so than most headphones so I would like to see that improved in the next model. Lots of features and settings as well which is nice. Give em a try, I think you’ll enjoy them.

In my opinion, these are the best headphones ever. I love the feature to turn noise cancelling feature off and ambient sound on. This helps me enjoy my music or a movie and still listen to my family around the house. Battery life is great. Noise cancelling feature is also great. I can barely hear the person standing next to me.
I found only two downsides to these which I can live with and I believe could be found in any over the ear head phones.
1) I can't not lay sideways which these on. It is very uncomfortable.
2) When I am not using these headphones, I usually wrap them around my neck. With my usual setting, these are bit tight. So I always end up stretching the straps all the way.

Very comfortable. I wear them on 15-20 hour overseas flights for listening (music/movies) and noise cancellation (sleeping). Excellent sound quality. Good battery life (25-30 hrs). Easy to use (right ear cup has a variety of touch controls). Be sure and download the app if you like to fine tune your listening experience and 'manage' your headphones.

I am not an audiophile but I own several closed headphones including a Master and Dynamics wireless headphones and a Bose with ambient Noise reduction. These are my preferred headphones. The sound is very clear, with great bass.
The noise canceling system works even too well ( sometimes I am afraid that somebody will take away the house around me and I will not be able to hear a thing). Anyway, overall I think these are the best sounding headphones I have.

Absolutely my favorite purchase of the past several months. Quality product, excellent sound reproduction & comfortable to wear. And, most importantly, the noise cancelling is exceptional. These are a tad large for workout headphones but I like to listen to audio books when I exercise. And trying to hear a recitation when it's competing with a gaggle of treadmill walkers more focused on chatting than sweating was problematic at best. Turn on the NC feature and they disappear - perfect.

These are the best NC Wireless Headphones I have ever owned, even better than the Bose and Beats I used to own. Amazing sound, noise cancelling and battery life. The iPhone App is ok, and has room for improvement, but that has nothing to do with the quality and sound of the headphones. They are amazing!

I have owned these for a few months now. I like them a lot. Noise cancelling is excellent. Very comfortable for extended listening. The battery life is amazing. The sound quality is not quite as great as some other cans I have owned over the years but all of the other features and the price make these a great buy.

So after some research, this was the product I chose to spend my money on. I have had it for about a week and must say that I am impressed with both sound quality and noise canceling. The touch tech on the right earcup has been very reactive and have had zero issues with it. My hesitance was with the cracking issue reported by other users. I have yet to experience the cracking issue but did get the 4 year protection plan just in case. Note that you must buy it new for them to accept the insurance. I will update if I notice any defects but so far so good.

Sound quality and noise cancelling is very good. Battery time is amazing. The only thing I do not like is that compared to my Bose QC15, the handsfree function is not very good. Particularly in noisy areas the sounds cuts in short intervals. The reason might be that the microphone is not on the cable. For listening to music these are great, but do not buy them as a handsfree set if you are going to talk a lot in noisy areas.

very comfortable and easy to use. The noise cancelling function is very useful. In my opinion, if you want to buy a noise cancelling earphone, you should consider these aspects :
1. noise cancelling effect
2. comfortable or not for using long time
3. battery
4. appearace
Therefore, I choose to buy this one not Bose QC35.

By far, the best headphones I have ever owned. The abundance of features combined with the clearest sound and pulsing bass, makes this a sound purchase ( no pun intended). I bought refurbished from Amazon and I can't tell it from new. Saved a bunch of money as well. The noise cancelling is phenomenal.
These headphones are nice except for there is a crackle in the right ear cup when I am listening. I am not sure if that is a problem that other people have had.

I freaking LOVE this headset!! It was a bit more pricey than most headphones I've purchased in the past but I am so happy that I did. The highs and lows are pleasant, the cup fits nicely over my ears, albeit it can get a bit warm after awhile. But they're still so comfortable that I fell asleep with them on. I have not yet flown with them but based on how light and comfortable they are, I imagine that I'll enjoy them more than my Klipsch headphone.

I've used both the Bose QC35I and these, and decided to go with the 1000XM2s. Overall, the package of the Sonys feels more premium than the Bose, as far as finish and the technology. I can't speak on detailed comparison of the ANC, but Sony's definitely sounds at least as good as Bose's, and I think it's really cool how it has adaptive sensing as well as calibration for hairstyle/glasses and air pressure. I have no idea how much of a difference it makes compared to Bose, but just the fact that it's there gives it extra value for me. Additionally, the Sony app includes different sound stage adjustments to make it sound as if you're listening in a concert hall, outdoor stadium, etc, and has automatic and manual EQ adjustments. Bose has none of these features.

The Sony also has distinctly better sound quality than the Bose does. It's cleaner and richer, whereas the Bose has somewhat muddied mid-tones and highs. The touch controls on the Sony took a little bit to get used to, but in the end I think they give you much more control than the Bose, and the ability to place your palm against the control panel to allow ambient sound in through the microphones is a cool touch.

Comfort is where the Sony falls short, but just slightly. The ear muffs on the Sony get warm and a bit clammy after extended use and can cause some uncomfortable pressure on the earlobes, whereas I found the Bose stayed away from my ears due to the angled design of the inside mesh. Still, you can expect to wear the Sony's for hours and be comfortable.

Update: I had my first chance to use these on a 13 hour flight to Asia. I have to say that the noise canceling on these is far more comfortable than on the Bose QCs, which on a train ride created that odd, pressurized feeling in my ears. I'm not sure if my ears had just grown used to the noise canceling inverse waveform, but on my flight I felt no discomfort. It's amazing how more comfortable a long flight can be when you cut out that constant drone of engine noise, listen to music, and get slightly more restful sleep.

Well I liked many features of these headphones
Pros:
1.The sound quality is really good considering its bluetooth.
2.It looks really good and is very comfortable.
3.Long battery life of about 28 hours.
4.The noise cancellation is on par with bose qc 35.

Cons:
1.The earpads presses the ear a bit so it gets kinda fatigued after wearing a long time.
2.The sound quality and volume is bit lacking.

Overall it's a really nice pair of headphonesand I loved it.The problem of volume and quality can be easily solved using an amplifier(I used my FiiO A5 & it sounded really nice with the amp). I would recommend it to everyone who wishes to get a pair of good noise cancelling headphones.

I travel a lot and have owned several pairs of Bose noise cancelling headphones over the years but have also been a big Sony fan so decided to try these headphones. Compared to my old Bose Quiet Comfort 15s, the Sony has better sound and better cancellation. Bluetooth isn't so important to me but it works well and I like the touch-control features where you can adjust volume or turn off cancellation with the swipe or tap of a finger. My one star deduction is for the weight of the unit - seems much more than Bose - and as some others have mentioned, my ears eventually get hot under the Sony's whereas they never seemed to under the Bose. Overall, this is a quality product that does what it's supposed to and I plan on enjoying them over many flights.

These headphones are great. I'm really impressed by the sound and noise-cancelling feature. It's a godsend at work—in an open office where people can't keep their voices down and distracting noise just carries everywhere. These headphones have made a huge difference in my mental health and wellbeing. My only criticism is that the they can sometimes be a bit heavy, and probably are not the best fit for my head shape. Otherwise, they're great.

Uhhh! Marvelous, wonderful, that's what this headset is for me! I am so happy! It's perfect in all aspects. Friendly use without any disgusting unconfortable search for buttons to press. Oh what a great and soft and powerful sound, no distortions and hummmms; and the noise cancelling functions are a great engineering breakthrough. And ... NO WIRES! WoW! I hope this headphone endures and keeps working for many years.

The noise cancelling is so good. I like that some things are intuitive without fiddling with the settings like: Plugging in the audio cable automatically turns off bluetooth. Holding your hand over the right earpiece automatically pauses noise cancelling if it is on and turns the volume down so you can hear someone speaking to you.

These headphones are fantastic. They're comfortable even after a couple of hours. The sound is excellent. I've been wearing them while mowing the lawn. Can barely hear the mower. They're crazy expensive. Personally, they're well over priced at $300+ but I knew that when I tried them on in the store. Fell in love with how they blocked out most of the sound in a very noisy store. Saw Amazon had them for a bit under $300 on Black Friday so I spoiled myself.

They work perfectly. Great noise cancelling. You hear your music or your book and nothing else. The pause function by placing your hand on the right headphone was the reason I purchased these and its awesome. The sound is great too. Download the app and it has an equalizer which is great for getting that right sound.
Whoa. Highly effective. As advertised. Great on airplane. Seem more effective than the Bose QC I lost. Sort of glad I did now...

Very good noise cancelling abilities. There is a noise cancelling optimizer feature which is pretty useful since the noise cancelling can adjust to different environments.
The sound is very smooth and there's an equalizer in the app so you can set it as you want.
I find the touch features very convenient and use them often.
The headphones fit the head quite good and are pretty much comfortable.
I recommend these headphones.

These are great headphones, the active sound canceling I can't hear anything other than what is playing through the headphones, can't even hear myself talk. These are perfect for Fortnite, you can pin point where the enemy is in a building or where they are shooting from. Sound quality is great for BT 4.0 headphones. Would have given them 5 stars but if you do not seat them on your ears to where they slide in, the pressure they have on the ear after long periods of time will be uncomfortable.

I bought these to replace my old wired Bose QC25 headphones. I love them. Some of the highlights for me:
- Long battery life and battery indicator when connected to my iPhone 8 so I know when to charge them
- Controls on right ear are fantastic. Ability to instantly stop/start/vol up & down/next song is incredibly convenient
- Range is awesome, on par with my Apple Airpods. Just now I left my phone in my seat (8C on a 737) and used the restroom at the rear of the plane. No disconnect or degradation whatsoever.
- Sound isolation as good or better than the QC25.

Very highly recommended.

They honestly are better than the Bose and the Beats studio 3 in terms of noise cancelling. They don't fit very well however. I'm a pretty average guy and they were constantly slipping forward and backward with any motion be it ever so slight. If you recline with them on they will slowly slip off your head onto the chair/couch/bed.

I had these on my wish list for about six months, but had been hesitant to purchase them because of the price. I impulsively bought them one night, and it was an excellent decision. I'm a writer working in a busy office, and it is so easy to get distracted by the chatter. The noise-canceling function on these is AMAZING. I can zone out and listen to my music in peace. The audio quality is also stellar. It was simple to pair with my iPhone, and the controls are easy to use. I especially like the feature in which you can touch the right earphone and hear ambient noise for a few moments. It's great for those occasional interruptions. This is an amazing piece of tech and well worth purchasing.

They are good but a little on the small side for a 6’ male with probably larger than normal ears. The Bose 35s are more comfortable to wear for hours. I have taken these on (2) 30 hour overseas trips and the battery lasted the entire trip which is no small feet. I picked these vs the Bose because I like the integrated controls better. Once you get the hang of the touch controls it is nice....not perfect but nice.

These headphones are excellent in every way. They sound fantastic. The noise cancelling is outstanding. They have futuristic control and features (Cover right ear to hear the outside world? Too cool!). They look great (people always ask me what kind they are). The battery life is incredible. I think I charge it once every two weeks or so. Wired option is also great.

I'm a big advocate of spending big money on headphones that will give you the best experience and last you a long time over repeatedly buying cheaper headphones more frequently.

These are my favorite way to experience music to date. Worth every penny.

Very comfortable with excellent noise cancelling properties. Using the outer shell as a touchpad to control the volume is a bit annoying but not a deal-breaker.Sound quality is similar to the Bose NC headphones. Comfort and sound quality way better than Beats, Skull Candy, or practically any other popular brands. Cost is pretty steep but well worth it
Never been a fan of Bose telling you what things should sound like. These sonys are solid, they shut off the outside world and the bluetooth works perfectly with my Android, IOS, and PC devices.

It's all about sound and these headphones provide the best sound I've heard in any headphones. It also has so many features, but it's not the features that make these headphones the best. Whether they all hold up over time is another story and the only thing I don't like is the internal battery can't be replaced. Still the sound is amazing.

These cans put out the kind of enveloping sound that transports even an audiophile into a new realm. I hear brand new sounds even in old favorite tunes. There are more controls than you ever thought you needed in a pair of headphones. Controls are easy to master AND they make meaningful differences to your music. I compared them directly with the Bose 35. The Sonys matched or exceeded them in every category except comfort. (The Bose go around the ear while the Sonys are on-the-ear.) Still, I listen without a problem for hours at a time. One of the best audio purchases I've ever made.

These are fantastic for listening to music, making calls, and travelling. I'm slightly disappointed with the software though, I tried to use with my computer via bluetooth and there are two audio options, one for stereo sound and one for headset sound. In my experience I could only use one of these at a time, so you can't play games in stereo sound for hearing footsteps and also be on Skype or Discord at the same time. Tried some troubleshooting and tinkering but haven't yet been able to get around it. Other than that - these headphones are absolutely fantastic! Incredibly comfortable (more so than any other headset I've tried on), music quality is perfect, noise cancelling is great, and the ambient sound feature works great (albeit maybe more of a gimmick than something I'll use, but who cares!).

I'm so glad I chose this over the Bose. This has good bass, great sound (more balanced than Bose, which seems to be treble-heavy). Like the phone app which gives you plenty of control. The finger and hand controls are easy to get used to. Battery life is spectacular! The only reason I give it 4 stars instead of 5 is it is a little heavy, so your head and neck need to adapt to the weight. You will feel some fatigue the first few days.
This has been one of the best head phone with noise cancelling I have ever owned.

These headphones sound very good. The noise canceling is very effective, capable of turning construction sounds (in the next room) into background noise. They are very comfortable. The gesture controls are easy to use and the listening feature is extremely convenient. I have had a pair for several months now and I only have positive comments. Great for music, videos, or gaming.

I have to agree with the other reviews here that these are the best noise canceling headphones of 2017. Heck I'd say they are the best I've ever used!.
The quality is really high and the case it comes in is very good as well.
The sound is next level. You hear things in your music you just couldn't hear before.
I bought an extended warranty on these since there were alot of reviews saying the plastic is a bit fragile.
But all in all 5 stars.

The only two downsides to these are that you can't disable the beeps that play when you use the touch controls and you can't use the touch controls while wired. Takes a bit to get used to the location of play/pause buy once you do the headphones are great. Great sound, great noise isolation, great comfort for long term wear, great all around.
Loving it. I came from a dead Bose Quiet Comfort 3 and the noise canceling is much better. And it has bluetooth, works when off as long as it is plugged and feels awesome and comfort.

Extremely expensive, but they are the best, and better than the Bose I tried of the same type. Very comfortable and easy to use, and the noise cancelling doesn't pressurize ears much at all, far better than others. the sound quality is the best also, pretty transparent sound, no problems, but its still really expensive for wireless headphones, I hope the market drops it down to around 150 soon, 350 is ridiculous.

Bought those 6 months ago in gold, a few weeks later they showed black discoloration on the outside of the Headphone and on the cable. I called Amazon suppprt who forwarded me to Sony Customer Service. Sony does not view the product design or accessories like the case (which most likely caused the discoloration) as part of the product to acknowledge it as a defect and refuses to replace them. Good job Sony, I'm going back to buying Bose and only Bose!

Stylish design and sound so good. Has a gooud noise cancenling that I can't even here airplane passing by to where I am staying. And best of all, one of the top bluetooth noise canceling headphones on battery. You can even use it in off mode with the aux cable

I read the reviews on Amazon, and I also researched this product on Youtube reviews. I was surprised to read and hear that the Sony WH1000XM2s are supposed to be better than the Bose 35 II. I just received my order and have been using them to my satisfaction. They block out ambient noise far better than I expected. The SENSE engine makes a huge difference over its competitors. The optimizer adds another layer of quality to the noise cancellation feature. I highly recommend these.

Performed unbelievably in the noise cancelation department. I had previously owed a Bose QC20 and the Sony is at least equal or better than the Bose. Plus, it has a much longer battery life. Given that it's at least $50 cheaper than the Bose, it's a no-brainer purchase.

Great product. Was in between the Bose quiet comfort 35 and this one. My main concern was if it was as comfortable since I couldn’t get to try it on. On the reviews the quality of sound and the newer technology it offers was clearly much more superior to Bose in my opinion. Since I started using it in terms of comfort I am very happy. It is quiet light and can be used for very long hours. So in my opinion this is the best wireless noise canceling headphone you can get.

I purchased both this and the Bose QuietComfort 35 Series II to compare the two. I liked that the Sony has an interactive app that shows me how it's calculating the noise cancelling (and it is noticeably improved after the calculation). The app also lets you choose different equalizer settings, including custom settings, which I like because I have hearing loss and I could customize it to my exact hearing needs. The controls are pretty slick, just swiping on the side of the earcup instead of hunting for a button. The sound quality of the music is excellent.

However, here is why I ultimately chose the Bose, and it comes down to two things. Noise cancelling, and advanced sound processing. Re Noise cancellation, I recorded myself in the voice memo app on my phone using the both sets of headphones as the recording device. This simulates what someone would hear when I called them on the phone using the headphones. The noise cancelling in the Bose was excellent, and I only heard my voice. With the Sony, I could hear background noise. The Bose playback sounded like I was talking using a handset, and the Sony sounded like I was on speaker phone.

The Bose iPhone app does not let you calculate anything, and it does not have an equalizer. At first this annoyed me, and then I realized that the Bose was calculating the levels for each song to produce the best sound, so I didn't have to use an equalizer.

Also, when you're wearing the Sony, they are bulky and look geeky on. The Bose is more streamlined to the head. I personally find the Bose more comfortable on over glasses. The Sony seems to have some clamping to shut out the sound, and this is not comfortable over glasses. The Bose has very soft earcups and relies on the noise cancellation instead of physically clamping down on your ears.
The headphone is great, noise canceling works very well. The sound quality is perfect!

This is my first time for using noise cancelling headphones, no more comparison ,as every function includes the quality of music, ease of operation, interface looking,time of battery and so on, is amazing for me. If you want it just to focus on working at any noisy places, like me, it will definitely be the priority tool for you after you play music on it. It provides you a new world.
However, my mac cannot be connected with it, which actually is not easy to us since I need to handle the wire. Maybe there is something wrong with my setting.
Since I live in Australia, no more judgement about the shipping. I just get a perfect product as the first time I use amazon. What a great experience!

To begin with, this review is for the XM2 model. You may see two of these Sony Premium Noise Cancelling Headphones listed on Amazon and wonder what the difference is. The XM2 is the newest model for this year and is built with newer materials. Sony may have addressed the headband cracking issue of the previous model in this release. That is not certain, but complaint(s) seem to be very limited on that issue.

I have been wearing noise cancelling headphones for a very long time. Have tried many other brands including Bose and Audio-Technica. The Audio-Technica noise-cancelling headphones are quite good, but outdated technology wise. As for Bose -- some of you may know this already -- but they are generally not a good brand. Most of their innovation costs go into advertising how great their speakers and headphones are rather than into the product itself. The current QC35 headphones are pretty darn good, but I ended up returning them once I heard these Sony headphones.

By far, these are the most advanced and best sounding noise cancelling headphones for the price.

Setup is extremely easy. For my iPhone and iPad, I simply downloaded Sony's companion app which walked me through the setup process. To fully explain how painless it is to start using these headphones out of the box, let me say that I didn't even bother to open the instruction book and instead relied on the app. Even if I didn't use the app, you can pair these headphones with mostly any device by long-pressing the power button.

What I found rather neat is that the headphones have voice prompts which tell you when they are powered on or off, or when connected or disconnected.

The noise-cancelling is as good or better than the Bose or Audio-Technica where it eliminates approximately 95% of ambient noise. You will never obtain complete silence while just wearing the headphones, but once you start playing music, the ambient noise is completely eliminated, thus immersing you completely into the listening experience.

Two terrific features as far as gestures are concerned....

While using the headphones, you can temporarily turn off the noise canceling while cupping your hand over one of the headphones. This allows you to carry on a conversation with someone. Remove your hand and the noise-canceling resumes.

For iOS users, take your finger and press it against one of the headphone cups and Siri automatically activates so you can issue a command.

By the way, the Sony headphones easily paired with my Macbook Pro and iMac.

Music sounds spectacular. The highs are present without being overblown. The bass is present while not being too exaggerated. You don't get that "muddy" sound that cheaper headphones provide.

The headphones arrive in a nice oval case along with a USB charging and separate headphone connecting cord.

I realize that some may be concerned about the reports of headphone band cracking that was reported on the previous model. This was a concern of mine as well. Looking at this new model, the complaints of cracking seem to be very rare and if you look further into them via an Internet search, perhaps limited to a specific individual who is repeating the complaints on many sites. I don't want to fully make that accusation as I am not completely certain, but I was just not able to get a substantial amount of evidence to back up the claims of this model having headband issues. Sony has stated that this new model is made of newer materials and I am assuming it was done to address the problems of the prior model.

Let's just say that I have seen no cracking issues with my headphones.

THESE are the ultimate noise-cancelling headphones. Do not hesitate to pick these over other brands. You will be amazed by their performance.

Noise cancellation is great, they are comfy and sound quality is good when connected via cable.
There is a strange issue with volume being a bit too low when connected to bluetooth.
Noise cancellation - which is the reason i bought these- turns itself off every 15 min. Allegedly, a ‘feature’ by design. Returning them - and buying Bose.

To start with, I am not fans of this type of headphones, because most of them are big and not so handy, plus my ears would hurt after wearing for more than 15 minutes. However, when I saw this product in a store, and tried it on, I knew that this is the headphone I am looking for. The headband is not as tight I think, and super comfortable to wear. The noise cancellation functions well and on-point. The only thing I will complain is the pairing problem with my Macbook pro, though it works perfectly well with my Iphone. My laptop can't recognize the bluebooth of the headphone. Does anybody have a similar problem?

Headphones had a constant static sound when the noise cancelling was turned on. The static could be heard over the music. Very annoying when no music was playing. Called Sony customer support and they had me do some trouble shooting and resetting the headphones. Nothing helped Sony advised returning for an exchange or refund.

These pairs completely met my expectations, they are just amazing!
I'm Using them more than a month and no issues with them, yet. The only thing that is missing here is connecting to more than one device at a time, in order I do not have to connect every time when I switch from my laptop to phone. But the pros are so much that I can close my eyes on that. Worth the many. Definitely 5 stars.

The noise concealing works very good, and is better, in my opinion, than Bose QC35 that my friend has. The sound quality is not as good as the wired Hi-res headphones made by sony at the same price, but it's the best you can expect for a wireless headphones, especially with ldac turned on (which is now supported by all the phones with Android 8). And there's no cracking issues that the old version used to have any more. And the app is also pretty good.

These were so close to being great, but... First, although advertised as multipoint (able to maintain 2 Bluetooth connections simultaneously), they don't. They can make an audio connection with one device and simultaneously a phone connection with another, but they cannot make two audio connections at the same time. If, like me, you want to connect with a tablet (for, say, YouTube videos) and a phone (for, say, music and phone calls), you're out of luck. For a device at this price point, that's just too big a flub to tolerate. Second, the Android headphones app seems to choke on these (at least when connecting to a Sony smartphone). Products from the same company that don't play well together? Really? Anyway, the audio quality is very good (though not stellar) and the controls on the ear are nifty. But, in my book, that's not nearly enough to make up for the botched multipoint functionality.

I had two choices, the WH1000XM2 and the Bose QC35II. I chose Sony because of the suite of features that it had over Bose. Additionally, other reviewers said the bass was strong (they were right), which became the main selling point for me.

Having listened to these headphones for myself, I can say with full confidence that I made the correct decision.

This is my first review I've ever left and listen..to say these headphones changed my life is an understatement..Years later I will look to this moment as the defining breaking point in my life and I will say to myself "I would have paid any amount of money for those dang things"

I'm an old time audiophile, with over 20k lossless tracks — but I also travel a lot, so I need NC (noise canceling).
Using a carefully selected range of FLAC tracks, through a decent DAC, I tried all the top-ranked over-ear and in-year NC systems, of every brand I could get my hands on — but below $400, that's just my psychological limit for headphones.
My head and ears are normal size.

Pros:
These cans had the best balance between noise canceling and audio quality, hands down. There's just no comparison. Especially the active calibration is very useful in planes with "particular" engine sounds. I fly overseas (long flights) and use them for 7-8 hours without problems. I much prefer these to the Boses available in Executive/First class.

Cons:
The over-ear Boses (only comparable NC) feel smaller and lighter, and somewhat more comfortable. And of course, there are a bunch of great, more neutral, more audiophile cans out there.

Overall, strongly recommended.

This is a very expensive headphone but the noise cancellation works perfectly, We compare the headphone with Bose QuiteComfort 35, which is in the same price range, Sony works much better. If you are in a noisy environment, this is the headphone for you.
A bit pricey, but worth every penny. Beautiful sound, great construction, flexible controls, great battery life...very satisfied!!

Great sounding headphones with excellent noise cancelling. Like them better than the Boses. But the experience of making and answering phone calls is not great, with the person on the other side often reporting poor sound quality.
Amazing headphones. I tried the Bose QC35 initially, and they were good...but I just love the sound quality on these much more.

So far so good. I'm still trying to get it to work seamlessly with phone calls (operator error, no doubt.) Noise cancellation seems pretty good. I was torn between this unit and the comparable Bose. I have no complaints at this juncture.

After all the Utube and amazon reviews I decided to buy these instead of the Bose CQ35II. I liked the features of the headphones over the other brand. I've use the older version of the bose and loved them so much I wanted some bluetooth ones. I did a lot of research and read/watched reviews. Now only a few days later and I need to return them.

Pros-
1) Very good noise cancelling when listening to music or watching videos.
2) Great features like mute, ANC sensitivity, app, and gesture controls.
3) Battery life.

Cons-
1) White noise. I got white noise when not listening to anything. I got even more white noise when not listening to anything and plugged in with the cable.
2) Ears got warm. Couldn't keep these on longer then a couple of hours before becoming uncomfortable. I've used bose for 15-18 hours without problems.
3) Besides my ears getting warm, the headphones are a little tight on my head. Could tell if that's why I got headaches or the white noise.
4) My ears also touched the inside of the cups. There isn't a lot of room inside the cups for your ears.

Conclusion-
I want $350 headphones to be comfortable and not get hot. The features are great but I want comfort too. I guess bose had the correct name for their product . . . it's in the name.

Hope this helps someone and thank you for reading.

Excellent sound and noise cancelling capabilities. Right side earphone functionality on these headphones is great!! Swipe your finger in different directions to achieve different results. My coworker has Bose and I think these are better.

I had been eyeing the 1000x for a while now, having only ever used (on a daily basis) IEMs due to having thick hair and glasses. I finally decided to try it out, even though the in-store units I tried on were quite frankly terrible. I was very surprised, pleasantly so. The adaptive sound or sense engine works extremely well, exceeding my experience with the Bose QC35 and Bose QC20. For the QC35, I primarily could just not get a good seal and had sound leaking in as a result. I am very pleased with the sound quality, comfort, and noise cancellation ability of the WH-1000XM2. It doesn't blow anything out of the water if you have previously owned any Bose ANC unit, but it is an improvement in every way but one (including the touch-interface, which far outstrips the Bose units in ease of use).

The microphone quality is absolutely horrendous. The moment I attempted to
call someone, they muted me and told me I sounded like an incarnation of death and white noise. I thought it might just be an exaggeration, but after recording myself using the unit and the phone microphone, I can safely say that the WH-1000XM2's outbound voice quality is on par with an extremely cheap knockoff one could find at a dollar store. I am not sure if it is a defect or what, but I was definitely disappointed that one of the marketable features was not remotely serviceable in a completely silent room. Still, I didn't buy it for the microphone, and the rest of the features that this headphone comes with is well worth the price.

They’re alright. Not worth 300 or 350. Uncomfortable and not that loud. Noise cancelling is good. I believe Bose is better like everyone is sayin. I wanted to go against whatever was saying and purchase these because I don’t like Bose as a company. Let down. Oh well.

Best headphones I've ever owned. Noise canceling is great and has lots of different features. The Bluetooth functionality is equally impressive. Finally, the 30-hour battery life is ridiculous. 10/10 would go deaf again.
Fabulous! I tried both and I'm glad I got Sony. You decide for yourself

Everything I expected from wireless headphones and more. To be fair, I've never had any before now, but it's a really good quality of life addition. I use them every day at my open office job and I can't recommend them enough

Had the Sennheiser and they served me well for years - started flying more and began to notice the need for better noise cancelling - the isolation and clarity are excellent - just hope I don't break them trying to fold them up!

Great noice cancelling headphones. Changed my flights completely - now I get way less tired during the flights. The internal microphone has some quirks when using the headphones in a loud place (cafe, airport). Also the headphones keep switching to ambient sound after some time from noice cancelling mode (maybe it's a feature, which I don't know how to turn off).

Changed my life! with noise cancelling on, I can barely hear the keyboard sound as I'm typing now. Not mentioning that I can't head the sound of the loud fan on my server. Very high quality product and top notch technology as you'll expect from Sony!
Sound and comfort are next level... spend the money and you won't regret it. I am a die hard JBL sound guy and it pains me to say that Sony has everyone far far far behind

I have purchased many head phones over the years. These have to be one of my favorite pairs. The sound quality is great both with Bluetooth or with the cable. I travel a lot so my favorite feature is defiantly the optimizer function. This makes a major deference when flying and it seems to help with change in pressure. Also having the gesture sensor on the ear makes turning up the music or changing the song very convenient.

Excellent noise cancelling. Cancels the humming noise in Airplane and makes life a bit easy on long duration flights. Cancels background noise while on phone call. Bose won't do that. Comfortable on my ears even for 9+ hours.

I would have given these headphones 4 stars (since the quality is pretty decent), except the customer service is absolutely horrendous! We have had a problem with the audio cord right out of the gate. It looks perfect, but whatever we plug it into the sounds was very muffled and crackly. Very annoying. We were just looking for a simple replacement of the defective cord from Sony since they are still under warranty, but have been trying to no avail for months! They will put you on hold for more than an hour, and when/if they answer, they pretend they can't help. It is obvious Sony has outsourced their support overseas., and these people haven't a clue or a care to help customers. This will be my last Sony product.
Cant get over how much i love these headphones. So comfortable and stylish. Great for working in a noisy office, especially with the feature that allows you to listen to your surroundings

I was skeptical about buying this headphone because of the reviews I've read that' it's uncomfortable and hot compared to Bose QC 35. But I needed a new headphone that I could take on my two 14 hrs flight and two 8 hrs flight this December. According to reviews, Bose's noise cancelling is not that good and can give you headache. I have Bose soundlink on ear wireless headphone but I don't want it anymore because that one really makes my ears hot. I received this headphone yesterday and I wore it straight 5 hrs. I was blown away! So comfortable, it did not make my ears hot, the sound is crisp and the built-in touch control is so convenient. And I like it that I can control the equalizer and surround sound on my iPhone. I still have to try the other features. But for now I'm very happy with my purchase. Highly recommended.

The headphones work very well (hence, the 4 stars), but the "gold" is in no way gold. The cups are dark beige (matte, not even metallic) and the band is more of a metallic copper. I am extremely disappointed with the color of the "gold" headphones. Stick to black.

The photo shows the gold-tipped cord next to the headphones. They're clearly not gold.

I was able to compare the noise cancelling directly to the Bose QC35 ii because my office has a noisy lab and bought one of the Bose headsets for every workstation basically. The noise cancelling itself, at least after adaptation, is as good as the Bose. It's probably not better, but it still has a leg-up on the Bose due to the better passive noise cancelling. Just wearing these block out more of the high frequencies (passed the ANC range), so these end up being noticeably better.

They're very comfortable, priced $50 less than the Bose, stylish, lightweight, lots of features. I would definitely recommend these over the Bose assuming it doesn't have the headband cracking issue that the MDR-1000x had. So far I haven't seen nearly as many reports of headband cracking on these.

One thing I wish they'd done something about was the ability to avoid pressing the touch controls when moving the headset on and off your head. That can get annoying if you're not careful. Now that I'm aware of the flaw it's pretty easy to avoid though.

Be aware that these headphones don't support simultaneous bluetooth devices. You'll have to manually disconnect from one before connecting with the other. That's not a big deal for me since I'll only want to use these with my phone, and god forbid I'd have to hold the bluetooth icon in the notification shade to bring up the bluetooth settings (NFC is overrated for the same reason).

The last thing to mention is the difference in Bluetooth codec between the Bose and Sony. Bose supports only AAC as a high-def codec, whereas Sony supports LDAC (of course) and AptX (thank god). Check the hi-def codecs your device supports before choosing a headset.
Some of the best headphones on the market. Great sound,and amazing when playing on suround sound mode.
