Wow, they are better than advertised, easy to setup and use the hand jesters are awesome! They connect up to my iPhone 8+ and iPad with out any issues and they work perfectly. Highly recommend these the NC is amazing and sound quality is work every penny.

Tested these and the Bose QC35 2 in store and there is a sound difference. Sony has definitely dethroned Bose. Base is sharp and and vivid with no distortion. The neat little touch sensitive controls are awesome and super intuitive, especially the cupping to hear exterior noise. Definitely glad I got these over the Bose. Also Google assistant works beautifully on it, so not losing out anything by not getting the QCs

Advantages:
- Great sound Quality
- awesome noise cancellation (Better than BOSE)
- Comfort
- casing
- no cabin pressure feeling "after 2 days".

Disadvantages:
- Can't connect to more than 1 device at the same time.
- BOSE QC35 II is more comfortable while wearing it.

These. Are. Awesome.

Amazing sound, amazing battery life, great noise canceling. Some of the features are a bit questionable, and I don't like the lag/pause when they switch modes ... plus the app eats too much battery life on my phone. So ... I just don't use it much and I'm back to what's great about these. Also, quite comfortable, if a bit bulky.

HIGHLY recommended.

At least once an hour, my heart swells with joy when a really great song hits a particular high point and these puppies just absolutely NAIL delivering it to me. At least once a day, I fight the urge to burst into song and/or dance in the middle of a grocery store or other public place. I am now immersed in music 10 hours a day, and the battery life means I never run out of juice so long as I throw them on the charger before bed every couple of days. Also the noise cancelling is unreal, and the touch controls are awesome, but the real "we live in future times" moment comes when you flip to ambient mode and have a conversation with them on while it kills every sound in the room EXCEPT for the person's voice who you're talking to. Jeezy Petes! What wizardry is that!?

Buy these headphones. They're future wizards you wear on your ears basically.

Everything everyone says about them are true.

They're amazing.

I got them for $300 (when they're usually $350) so I'm ecstatic.

Best headphones money can buy! NC is our of this world.. The customization app is really cool.

Only downside is the High Res Audio is currently only supported on iOS and Oreo devices...
Love this headphone..much better in noise reduction than their previous headset. It’s so good that when I’m wearing it in the train..I keep missing my stop..haha.
Well, they are amazing. The controls are incredible. If you can afford it, get them.

I purchased these because I have a small yappy dog, a preschooler, a snoring spouse and a long day of work that involves people talking to me. So, the thought of coming home and putting these bad boys on was like a dream. They arrived and I was so excited. While at first aprehensive of the color (Gold), I totally fell in love with them. I immediately took them out of the package and noticed they had some charge. Awesome! Put them on and all I could hear was the equivalent of the winds of a mountain top, the gentle breeze of being on a beach, or the tranquil silence of camping under the desert stars. Then it happend, I started getting nauseated. The feeling of dizziness and sickness came over me. That's right folks, I'm one of those people who apparently can't handle the loss of external neural input when wearing these. I basically felt "sea sick" each time I put them on. Over and over, I tried them on and off because my denial was fierce. Eventually, I had to give in and choose to accept my defeat. I cannot own a pair of noise cancelling earphones. Instead, I'm doing well with the Skull Candy noise isolating (not cancelling) headphones. Not as awesome, but a good runner up to getting some peace and quiet.

Noise cancelling is superb with minimal effect on the awesome sound quality. The clarity & soundstage is excellent. Long time comfort wonderful also. Battery life v good. Buttons take a little time to master but nothing major. Sony has really got it right with these gems. Recommend 100%!
Excellent headphones. Easy to use, pair, and connect to Samsung TV. (Bose would not connect consistently) Noice-cancelling works well. Appreciable stereo sound

I'm starting to hear the cracking sounds from the left side of the head band (from the point where the previous models have been cracking). Also, sometimes, the headphones start producing ticking sounds in the audio. It then needs to be turned off and restarted to get this fixed for a while.
Excellent Sound and Options. It Keeps me Dancing :D

Switched from the Bose QC35 II to these. These are hands down the better headphones.

I will say that the Bose QC35 is more comfortable. The ear cups are softer and seem to provide a little more space. That being said, these are by no means uncomfortable and I wear them 6+ hours per day.

The touch controls are great, the battery life is awesome, the bluetooth range is at LEAST 3X that of the Bose. They support higher quality protocols, the noise cancelling is better in my opinion. All good stuff. Definitely worth the few extra dollars.

To Sony: I really wish the LEDs could be optionally disabled via the app.

These headphones are amazing—and expensive. After much research and debate, I decided, if I were going to get a pair of noise cancelling, I would get a pair that was the best at it. My choice came down to the WH1000, MDR1000 or QC35. Through my research, most reviews seem to favor both Sonys over the QC35 for noise cancelling. And, noise cancelling is most important to me. Again, through my research online, not hands-on, the Sony’s and QC35 are fairly comparable with only a slight edge to Sony. With my choice narrowed to either the WH1000 or the MDR1000, I ultimately chose the WH1000 because of what I read about potential creaking with the MDR1000. I could not get a sense of how wide spread the issue was so I decided to just go with the newer version and hope for the best.

The noise-cancelling is outstanding. I initially put them on in my office with no audio and someone taking a call just outside my office. I put them on my ears, turned on the NC feature, and all outside noise ceased. Im fortunate enough to have an office directly by a door that frequently opens and closes, people walk by quite often, the office AC is fairly loud and drones, and people often take calls at their desk. With no audio and NC active, I hear almost nothing. By “almost” I mean, I hear only voices occasionally but they sound like a barely audible mumble. With audio playing at roughly 40% to 50%, I hear absolutely nothing. I had someone talk normally just beside me—I couldn’t hear them. I snapped my fingers directly beside my ear—I couldn’t hear it at all.

I wear these off and on throughout my work day for a total of about 6 hours in the office. With my attention on work and listening to audio, I forgot all about them being on. They are comfortable and I had no problem wearing them for long periods of time. The ear pads are soft and my ears didn’t get hot.

I will end by saying, if noise cancelling is what you are looking for, these are excellent. I'm not a big audiophile. To me, the audio either sounds good enough or bad. These sound just fine to me.

These headphones sound amazing, and the noise cancelling is top notch. However, the tops of my ears start hurting after only 30 minutes to 1 hour of use. It's because the cups are shallow enough that my ears touch the foam protecting the driver. It gets bad enough that I have to take them off for a while. Re-adjusting them doesn't help. I really wanted to like these headphones, but I want something that I can wear for many hours without having discomfort.

This headphones are the most expensive I have bought but still I think it was a good purchase, the Sound is great (Even better when you use the Bluetooth and the Sony App) and are confortable. The noise cancelling is great I haven't compared to other headphones like Bose but I have read a lot of reviews were they say the noise cancelling technology is better.

The apps let's you customize your headphones, disable, enable and optimize the noise cancelling, change the equalizer and change the sound quality.

The touch control on the right side of the headphones are quite confusing at first, but they work great once you get use to them. The battery life is great and you can use the headphones with the jack and you don't need to turn them on in order to hear music(unless you want to use the noise cancelling).

The only CONS I found for this product was the price.

I guess I'd give these 4.5 stars if I could, because there are a couple of annoying issues with them. But having played them a lot over the last few days since receiving them, here are my thoughts in the hope that this may be helpful for someone like me, who is not an expert in anything. But I do enjoy music quite a lot.

Sound - 5 stars. This is what matters most, and this is what is the most subjective. That being said, I've owned quite a few headphones and earbuds over the years, and I am really enjoying these. To me, Bose products are somewhat overrated, and these sound better than the QuietComforts to my ears anyway. Of course the sound can't match high-end wired headphones connected to expensive output equipment, but considering that these are going without the wires, it's very hard for me to find fault with them. Warm overall sound, very good clarity, nice even bass without distortion. Excellent.

Build quality - 5 stars. They look and feel very solid. I got the gold ones, which are really more of a tan color, but really nice. Kept in the hard case that comes with them, I believe they will last a long time.

Comfort - 3 stars. After about an hour, they start to hurt my ears somewhat. That's been my experience to some extent with every pair I've owned, but hopefully I will get used to them over time. I find myself adjusting them quite a bit to get more comfortable. The ear cups are pretty tight, which obviously helps with:

Sound Isolation - 5 stars. My gym has a lot of noise, but these block out about 90% of it. I haven't been on a plane with them yet, but I think they will be just fine.

Features - 4.5 stars. I like being able to control everything by touching the sides of the headphones. But the right side volume, pausing, and skip ahead functions are very sensitive and take some getting used to. The two buttons on the left ear cup are small and hard to find by touching them, frequently causing me to hit the wrong one. The app (at least for the iPhone) has a lot of functionality, and I really like the customizable equalizer. That really makes a big difference for me. There are lots of other things (everything pretty much) that you can do from the app. Pretty cool. Other reviewers have mentioned problems with the app, but not me. There are lots of other features that are of questionable value to me personally (sound position, atmospheric pressure, virtual sound, etc.), but may be useful to others. As far as technology goes, these seem to be way up there.

Bluetooth/Pairing 4.5 stars. It pairs very easily to up to eight devices. The range is very good also. I live in a pretty decent size single level house, and I can go anywhere with no signal degradation. Even outside, I can wander pretty far, no problem on the porch or outside deck for example. However, switching from one device to another is an unnecessary pain. You should be able to connect to two devices at a time. Minus a half star for that.

Battery - 5 stars. So far, so good. After 10 to 15 hours, battery level is still "medium".

For a long time I put off getting wireless headphones, fearing that I would have to sacrifice sound quality for convenience. Now you can have the best of both worlds.

If you are researching which noise cancelling headphones, let me save you the time because I've already done it for you. I was first sold on the Bose Quiet Comfort QC35 II's. In fact, I wasn't really aware there was a solid competitor, nevertheless a superior product. But like any of my other tech/gadget purchases I spend hours reading reviews, watching YouTube reviews, etc. It wasn't until I started my research that I even knew Sony had a direct competitor for the Bose QC's. In fact about 9 out of every 10 reviews rated the Sony's either just a step above if not dead even with the Bose. Most all of the reviews stated that the only area they found the Bose to be superior was in comfort (they are a bit lighter and the design of the ear cups don't tend to make your ears as warm,) FULL DISCLOSURE: I have tried the Bose on in the store but not side by side with the Sony. So while I may not be qualified to do a true head to head comparison in my personal opinion (I have used both, just not at the same time), the research I have done all points to the Sony.

Now, on to what I can tell you about them after using them. #1 - the touch function on the ear cup is pretty cool. I plan to primarily use these in the yard while mowing/edging/etc and being able to reach up quickly and up the volume or change to the next track with a quick swipe is pretty nice. The fewer times I have to reach in my pocket to find my phone and change things the better. Yes... Bose has buttons that do this... but having the touchpad to me is a bit easier without having to learn/know where the specific buttons are at all times. #2 - the "pause and listen" function is outstanding. When using them, if you cup your hand over the right ear cup, the noise cancelling ends and the mic turns on to allow you to hear outside noise. This is great if I'm working in the yard and stop to talk to a neighbor or the wife for something brief. Obviously for an entire conversation I'd just pause them and take them off, but just being able to hear something quickly and let go and go back to action to me is an awesome feature. #3 - the ambient noise settings/adjustments are great. The headphones can sense your activity (idle, walking, running, etc) and will adjust for ambient noise accordingly. You can also have the headphones focus on speech and drown out other ambient noise. I tested this feature out while the wife was watching TV. Its strange to not hear the sounds of cars and other usual noises but hear them talking well. I found that I could no longer hear the dishwasher running or background noise on the TV, but as soon as my wife said something or a character on TV spoke, I could hear it perfectly. I don't wear headphones at work, but I imagine in an office setting this would be really nice.

I'm really looking forward to a day in the yard with mowers running and edgers and trimmers and just being able to listen to my favorite music instead. I'm used to having in earbuds that pull out of my ears if I turn my head too quickly. I'm excited to use these moving forward!

I was looking for noise cancelling for 2 main reasons(among other reasons) 1. Travel to my work deployment assignments, 2. Use them as a work tool/protection for my ears.
I do contracting work for the military so wherever they go i have to go. Having said this... Military planes are not built for comfort(or quietness)and if you've been inside of a C17 or C5 aircraft then you know that cabin noise is huge (they're not quiet at all), you literally have to yell to the person next to you if you want to converse. Also working in aviation field with jets coming in and out every couple of hours will hurt your ears. Add to this that you're trying to relax or sleep in your tent and now you have noisy neighbors..etc..
I also have an above normal loud car (custom exhaust) so this is where I tested my Sony WH1000XM2.
While driving my car to work (loud exhaust,floor sound deadening removed, no a/c so widows slightly down and air noise also coming in) I decided to test these headphones with the Noise Cancelling on and OH MY!! What a sweet difference! I could comfortably drive and listen to music and it felt like I was in a quiet room. I could only feel the vibration of the car and the road feedback as I drove but absolutely no noise. Even with the loud exhaust I could even use Google assist thru the headphones to activate apps such as IHeart radio or even just say an address to navigate and it did it with no problem and without me having to take my hands off the steering wheel. I have also made phone calls thru the headphones while driving and also while just walking around and the quality, detail of voice in the calls is impressive.
I used the Sony phone app to adjust the ambient sound levels I want to let in just so that I can listen to music but still want to be able to hear outside voices. Just as I am typing this review I am sitting at the car dealer(with my headphone on and listening to music) servicing my wife's car and the service advisor has come twice to speak to me and I have been able to hear him with no problem and with the headphones on. It's truly amazing! I really love these headphones!

In terms of comfort I honestly don't have any complaints. I guess I must have smaller ears because they absolutely feel very comfortable even after an hour of use I don't feel any discomfort to where I feel like taking a break from them. My ears dont feel weird because of the NC. I've heard mixed reviews about this and how people change the ear pads to make them better but in my case I feel they're excellent.
The headband part is also cushioned and does not brothers me at all even after an hour or two of wearing them.

Sound quality. I think these headphones are very well balanced. Voices and guitars sound so clean, crisp and defined(I listen to all types of music). Bass levels and drum punch is just right from factory settings. I did play with the different EQ adjustments (Arena, Club, Concert Hall.. etc) on the Sony app and I think factory settings are on point. I think i just added 1 or 2 notches on the Bass and thats it. I have been able to really hear/distinguish more detail in my everyday music (same songs) that i didnt know it was there. It's like ...where did those Instruments or where did those riffs came on? I had never heard that in that song.. it's really satisfying.

So far I've used these headphones for about 7 days and I am still on my initial charge. Use has been aprox 2 hrs each day and when i press on the battery level check it still says battery level high. I haven't used them 100% on noise cancelling though, maybe that has to do with how long the battery lasts.

I bought these headphones partly because I wanted a new pair of nice headphones, and partly because I had a 17 hour international flight coming up. They do not disappoint on either front.

The sound quality is wonderful. I would encourage you to go to a physical store to compare these to the competition. Compared to the Bose Quiet Comfort 35 and Bowers and Wilkins PX, this was the pair that I fell in love with.

They are also remarkably comfortable. I don't think I have ever had a pair of headphones fit so well. Even after wearing them almost non-stop for the entire flight, I felt virtually no strain on my head.

Speaking of that flight? I had a small child sitting behind me, which is usually a recipe for disaster. I didn't hear him once, and it wasn't because he was well behaved (I knew when he was throwing tantrums because I would feel him kicking my seat, not because I could hear him.) So on top of the excellent audio quality, the noise cancelling is also top notch.

I am stopping short of 5 stars because of the weird Bluetooth pairing. You can only pair with one device at a time, which means if you want to switch between devices you have to go into your Bluetooth settings and manually disconnect, or shut the headphones off and restart them in pairing mode. Compared to every other pair of Bluetooth headphones I have owned, this is draconian. In addition, if you plug the headphones in to charge, they shut off and you cannot pair them with anything until you stop charging them. I don't know if the analog cable still works while charging, but it's kind of an annoying drawback.

However, once you are connected there are 0 issues. The connection is very strong; I can comfortably walk into another room 40 or 50 feet away from my iPhone and not have any drops. The battery is excellent, even with wireless and noise cancelling on. They lasted the entire flight + layovers without any problem, with some breaks in between (probably at least 20 hours of use.) They seem to charge quickly as well.

The carrying case is a nice touch, it's very sturdy and I never worried about the safety of the headphones while they were getting backpacked around Thailand. All in all I'd say do your homework, but if you buy these headphones you won't be disappointed.

I spend a lot of time traveling and wanted a good pair of ANC headphones. I’ve used the Bose QC 35’s in the past, and although those were quite good, positive reviews from friends led me to want to try the 1000XM2s.

For long-haul flights, these are a godsend. As I write this, I just out of a 23 hour travel experience, and I wore these headphones for the majority of my 3 flights. The battery lasted the entire time (and ANC was on), and I still show 20% battery (though, I imagine it’s a bit closer to 10%), and I was playing music or video for the vast majority of the trip.

At first I thought the “cup the right ear to pause/turn off ANC” would be a gimmick, but when trying to listen for announcements on the plane or in the airport, it was really useful.

I’m also a big fan of the control gestures on the right side. I have AirPods that I use for my general wireless usage (walking around/commuting to work), and the double-tap to pause/play action is identical. I also appreciate there being an easy way to skip/reverse tracks and to raise and lower volumes.

I typically don’t bother with third-party apps for EQ stuff, but out of boredom I was messing with it this trip and found that tuning the settings can give off great results. That said, I was very satisfied with the audio quality as-is.

The feature that allows the ANC to balance based on air pressure/altitude seemed to be really good, but that could just be placebo.

Speaking of ANC, it’s jusf fantastic. I know there are some complaints about it turning off when not in use (you have to plug something into the line-out to keep it active), but since I prefer my own traveling playlist over white noise, this hasn’t been an issue for me. Needless to say, the crying baby sitting two rows behind me in my 10-hour return flight from São Paulo to the United States didn’t bother me, which was nothing shirt of a miracle.

The included carrying case is great. Just don’t do what I did and leave it someplace in an airport in Brazil. Song does sell replacement parts, but they are expensive, relatively speaking ($60 for a case, $35 for a color-marched headphone cable). That’s my fault for leaving them, not Sony’s, but I thought I’d mention it.

Connectivity with my iPhone X and iPad Pro was great. It also works perfectly with my Apple Watch (if you want to use that to control playback). Pairing isn’t as instaneous as using W1-chip headphones (AirPods, Beats Solo 3 Wireless and the new Beats Studio 3), but it’s fast nonetheless. You do have to disconnect from one device before pairing to another (simply pairing won’t work, you need to disconnect the other device first), which is a mild annoyance. I would love more flawless device switching or support for multiple BT connections.

I’ve also used them with a mid-2017 MacBook Pro, a mid-2017 iMac 5K, and a late-2016 Surface Book with great success. I usually don’t use noise canceling headphones at work because too many people yell at me (wired Song MDR-7506s have been my default pick for years now), but these are excellent and especially convenient when trying to do work or even a quiet conference call from the airport lounge or the speaking room at a conference.

I can’t speak to long term durability yet, but so far these have more than met my expectations.

As far as comfort, I haven’t done a direct comparison with the Bose (the last time I used the Bose was close to a year ago), but these didn’t bother me, even after 10+ hours of continuous use.

From a pure sound quality point of of view, there are probably equally good or better options for less money on the market, but the battery life and excellent ANC makes these ideal for travel.

I purchased these headphones mostly because my new phone doesn't have a headphone jack. I commute via the subway every day, and it's nice to be able to listen to music on occasion without having to worry about wires. These headphones have been great so far and I can't really think of any substantial downsides. Others have done the in-depth sound and NC comparisons against Bose and Sennheiser, so I won't do that here.

For commuting on trains and buses, these are fantastic. The noise cancelling is excellent, to the point where I've almost missed my stop because I couldn't hear the announcement. I've had a couple times where I've been in a cramped compartment with people talking and it becomes instant silence when I turn these on. The sound quality is also great. The low notes are very full without overwhelming everything else. I'm also hearing subtleties in my music that I haven't noticed before. I listen to a lot of rock, some electronic, and some lo-fi stuff, and these have been great with everything. Build quality is solid; I haven't once been concerned about cracking in the headband, but I treat these very well. I've had these for a couple months and I've only had to charge them twice.

The only annoying thing I can think of with these is the earcup controls. It usually works well for volume, pausing, and switching tracks, but not 100%. There are times I'll swipe to turn up the volume, but it pauses instead. Or I try to forward a track and it pauses. Very minor thing that's not a dealbreaker by any means, but still annoying.

Overall, these are solid headphones that I would recommend.
It really cuts out a LOT of the outside noise. also like the covering of the right ear piece to hear any conversation also the ability to control the sound .

Pros:
By far the best active noise cancelling headphones. Comfortable to wear for long duration like commute or at work. Build quality is superior. Decent battery life (last a whole week with average use 5-6 hrs daily). Good case for storage and comes with good quality accessories.

Cons:
Not much except price is a bit high and ear cup pads could have been a bit more soft (qc35 I think has the best ear cup pads).

This headphones really surprised me.
I bought them for both office use & public transportation.
I ended up using them all day long, the sound just made the outside world without the headphones seem really, really loud.
battery always seems to have a charge, can be used around the two days straight.
In terms of sound quality - I can't compline - did not found any issue with them.
They are addictive, probably my best purchase so far.

great noise canceling! feels like you're alone in the world.
I am so very happy with them and although they are expensive I feel they worth the money
but do take those downsides under consideration:
- there's no warning before charging is needed, headphones just die. (really annoying, this should be fixed!)
- poor phone call quality, I switch to my cheap HP for that :)
- this color is many things, but it's not GOLD :)))
These are the best headphones I've used. They are a real treat and the noise canceling is high end, probably the best ever.

They are very comfortable and have awesome sound quality. Also battery life is absolutely great.
I haven't tried other noise cancelling headphones but I can say that they do not completely block all sounds.
For example, with noise cancelling on, you can still hear people talking around you. Sure, you would hear them less but you still hear the voice well enough to understand words.

My daughter said that they aren't as loud as beats and don't sound much better.
For the price, I would not buy them again.
Bought them for Christmas 2017 so, hopefully they will last. It is March 2018 as of this writing.

Best pair of headphones I've ever owned. I've come a long way from the rattling Skullcandy Skullcrushers of middle school, or the weird ass Sony behind the ear looping ones with the orange ear foam. These are so comfortable I wear them to sleep, so sweet in their sound that I find my body gyrating and head bopping in places where it is surely seen as inappropriate but I just can't help it - the sound is too good. I love the controls and sometimes just flick to skip or cup it to hear around me and giggle with how intuitive it is, although yes the responsiveness of tapping to play and pause can be fickle at times.

Battery is incredible, and I haven't had anyone say that they couldn't hear me when I take a call on them. The days of me crooking my neck in order to mush the phone to my shoulder are over. I can't tell if the app truly works that takes into account atmospheric pressure or personalization of sound to you, but the placebo effect of the slick presentation does put a bougie ass smile on my face.

Build quality is cool, though I do wish they felt a little tougher.

I've never paid such a grand amount for a piece of audio tech, but this feels well worth it. Like two little pudgy cherub hands caressing my ears and projecting heavenly sounds straight to my auditory cortices.

Sleep in 'em, block out your roomates with 'em, or let in the world as the music moves with you.
Sound and noise cancellation are great, lots of options but they put pressure on your head and get uncomfortable

These headphones are awesome! They are my first pair of over the ear bluetooth headphones as I have just switched to a Google Pixel 2. I was worried about the hassle of bluetooth but it is not a big deal at all. The only real drawback I have to offer is that the full palm cupping to lower the level of music can be a touch sensitive at time even when I am just trying to adjust the fit.

Great sound, even better noise cancelling. I love some of the touch sensitivity features, particularly being able to put my hand on the right cup to let outside sound into the headphones. Battery life lasts 16+ hours, so they're great for long trips.
THE best noise cancelling headphone in 2017! Not even one of!
What I expwcted but it is very hard to pause music or audio using you headphones only.
I can’t speak highly enough about these headphones. Amazing sound and cancels all outside noise, even kiddos haha
So far so good. Amazing battery life, I have been using it for a week at work(4-5 hours a day) without charing.
Nice noise cancellation for user on an aircraft. The case allows them to be packed up in a very small space.

Best Value and far exceeds Bose 20 and 35 series noise canceling...Bose does not stand by their product. Argumentative and not staffed with appropriate customer service mindset..... Sony is top rate!! A+++

Excellent product and the latest version. Some of the previous versions of this product had a material flaw which caused the headband to break. Sony will replace those if they fall into the serial number range (which is quite large). I use these every night and they are great for flying. Noise suppression is very good. Waiting is very good and the phones will let you know how the charge is doing (recorded female voice) when you press the power on button while in use. Comfortable and they come with a cable and adaptor for use on a plane. Lasted 16 hours of flying time easily.

I am a fairly serious music listener. I have had many different kinds of Bluetooth, Noise Cancelling, Sports, over ear, in ear -- way too many to count.
Buy these.
It took me a couple of days to get used to all of the various options and features, but these are hands-down the best on the market today. Virtually every feature is customizable from the NC feature to equalization of music. The app also is great so that one does not have to remove the headphones to manually use the features located on the left and right earphones. My only problem was with the initial pairing. I simply went to my Amazon order and followed the "need help" instructions and within 4 or 5 minutes the Amazon rep told me how to factory reset. Immediately it paired to my iPhone. Finally, although the instructions do not mention compatibility with iPhone X, they are... Both products are simply so new that the manual was not quite up to date with the latest iPhone.
An amazing pair of headphones, just they start to feel tight around your ears after a while.

Amazing! I use them at the office and if it can block my coworkers out then it can block out your problem at work too! Finally I can concentrate but still hear with a quick hand gesture that enhances the ambient sounds.
I bought these for my wife and she loves them, great at reducing noise and listening to favorite music.

only problem i have is that tiny sound delay from the souce like 0.2s sound delay from the play souce
it wont hurt u if u just listen to mp3
but it will hurt u a bit when u watch moive
and alot on play games
was hoping sony fix that problem in mark-2
but sony didnt

I wanted to wait till enough time have passed, and after almost 8 months with these headphones I can honestly say they deserve all the hype surrounding them.
They are amazing, innovative, and really cancel surrounding noise!!
Hadn't experienced any fracture that I've heard about from the mdr-1000x users.

Cheers :)
The best headphone I ever had 😊 the king of noise cancelation

Pros:
1) Supports a wide variety of wireless audio codecs making it a versatile device compared to others in the same range (Bose QC35 ii wink wink)
2) The sound quality is amazing and to an untrained ear, it is indistinguishable when compared to most dedicated headphones in the same price range.
3) Comes with a supporting Application, which lets it control the atmospheric pressure inside the cans.
4) On a full charge lasts about 20 to 25 hours depending on the usage.
5) Noise cancellation is indistinguishable when compared to the market leader Bose QC35 ii.

Cons:
1) App needs an update. It is glitchy and more often than not unresponsive.
2) The build quality could be better.
3) Bluetooth pairing experience and switching between paired devices needs work.

Like many of you, I was torn between the Sony WH 1000XM2 and Bose QC35 II. The decision is going to come down to your priorities. Sony's headphones overall sound better, especially with dance or bass-heavy music. If you have FLAC or ALAC tracks, you'll notice the Sony sounding better since they support the LDAC Bluetooth codec, which is more advanced and uses higher bandwidth than Bose,

However, if you're heavily invested in the Android ecosystem and need the headphones to travel, the Bose are more comfortable and have better controls as the touch controls on the Sony are hit and miss. The built-in Google Assistant on the Bose is actually very helpful once you learn it's capabilities.

So overall I give 4/5 stars since they are less comfortable than the Bose (hot on ears), have finicky touch controls, have no Google Assistant integration, but sound better than the Bose. Returned these and kept the Bose.

My goal in buying over the ear headphones was mainly to control the noise level at work.

I work in a small office with several other folks, one of which in particular has a tendency to talk at length about random stuff at times when I really need to concentrate on work.

Loud sighs, sliding down in my chair behind my monitors, mumbled oaths and other unsubtle hints fell on deaf ears, and so to maintain an otherwise good relationship with this valued colleague I started looking for a solution, which lead me to a comparison of noise cancelling headphones.

As others have noted, these are fantastic at making the outside world go away.

On testing with my wife, I at first suspected she was having fun with me and just moving her lips - hand over the right headphone suspends the noise cancellation and I could hear her deliberately loud and goofy shrilling. Visualize Xena Warrior Princess battle cry.

At work, with or without low level music, my problem is solved and I can cheerfully donate a couple of minutes being a good listener here and there, knowing I can raise my shields at will.

Others more qualified to speak on sound quality may find fault with these, but to me they sound fine, particularly after adjusting various settings in the Sony Connect app for my phone.

At home, I've enjoyed using these with my Roku - I use the "private listening" feature on the Roku phone app to accomplish that.

I've worn them for hours at a time with no discomfort, and find the ear and headband padding adequate.

I like the gesture control and find it easy to remember and use. The "grab the right headphone to listen" thing is especially useful, and I make use of it frequently.

I work in a very noisy environment - over 200 computers pushing 70 dB of white fan noise. It becomes intolerable over time, and after trying several cheap noise cancelling headphones, I took a chance and coined up these Sony's. I'm quite pleased. These are comfy enough to wear for several hours of the day, even when wearing reading glasses. They offer some modicum of a physical barrier to noise, so they help quite a bit even when Off. This is important for any noise cancelling headphone, and these Sony's have a reasonably good shell structure for blocking some sound passively. When the Noise Cancellation is On, I get to enjoy near total quiet where I normally sit, and I get plenty of protection when I go in and among the computers to do work up close to the whirring and buzzing cooling fans, which can be quite loud - up to 90 dB up close. I also used then while being driven around they do a great job at reducing regular car / freeway noise. They are robust but a tad fragile. I treat them like the sensitive electronic instruments that they are, and so should you. Protect them and they will serve you well. Sound quality is quite adequate for my needs - but this is not the true strength of this device. It is of course waaayyy better than any of the cheaper ones I have tried.

I have been using the Bose QC35 headphones for about a year and really like them. However, I've seen such generally very positive reviews for the Sony MDR-1000X phones that, when this new model came out, I had to give them a shot. Since I was already very satisfied with the Bose, I knew that the Sonys had to be something special for me to keep both headphones.
When I received the Sonys and unpacked them, I was really excited to try them. The first thing I noticed was that the comfort level was several steps below the Bose. They felt heavier (which they are), tighter on my head, did not completely envelop my ears, and immediately felt too warm on my ears. Comfort is a very important factor to me, so I knew that the Sonys would have to be outstanding compared to the Bose on other factors.
So, let's go down the checklist:
1. Build Quality - As anyone who reads Amazon customer reviews of the MDR-1000X will see, cracking of the headband was a substantial issue, with associated poor customer service responses from Sony. I can find no mention that the issue was resolved on the new phones, although time will tell.
2. Noise Cancelling - Bose has been at the forefront of this for many years, but Sony has clearly caught up. However, for me, I needed the noise cancelling to be substantially better on the Sonys for me to keep them over the Bose. Although the Sonys have more noise cancelling options, I could not detect a marked improvement over the Bose.
3. Sound Quality - This is probably the most subjective factor under consideration. After a few hours of A/B comparison of the two headphones, it turned out that I prefer the Bose. To me, they have a cleaner sound with better instrument separation.
4. Features - Sony clearly outperforms Bose on this factor. From the many options on the Sony app, to the touch controls, to the Quick Attention Mode feature, it is obvious that Bose has a lot of catching up to do.

So, for me, the Sony advanced features are just not enough for me to use them over the Bose. Many thanks to Amazon for making the return process so easy.

Sony vs Bose:
I had a long battle on which to choose and for my uses, I think the Bose suit me better.
The Bose are more comfortable to me, I like physical buttons and dont need gimmicky features that the Sonys have. I can pair the Bose more easily and can pair up to 2 Bluetooth devices (not just 1) to the headphones.
The Sonys would be a better choice if I wanted slightly more bass/punch as I listen to a lot of Hip-Hop/Electronic music but even then the difference to my ears wasnt light years ahead of the Bose.
It comes to personal taste on the look, comfort and sound really. The Sonys do have better battery life from what Ive heard (20v30 hours) so that is definitley a plus. All in all, If I had only 1 pair of headphones to use, I might like these better...but If I want bluetooth and great noise cancelling that is easy to use and straightforward, Ill take the Bose . I also own Audio Technica ATH50s and Sony MDR-1s that are amazing for listening through media with Aux jacks which is still the way to go if you want the best quality sound.
The best headphone i ever had

Our upstairs neighbors are heavy steppers/walkers to the point it was really stressing me out. To drown out the stomper-clompers I tried turning up the stereo or TV, but that’s stressful too if you’re looking for peace and quiet instead, or maybe some low key classical music. Enter my recent purchase of the Sony WH1000XM2 headphones which I can’t emphasize enough have been life changing. Slip these babies on and I can have near total quiet with the NC selected, or total immersive music bliss. If you’re looking for an escape from a noisy situation I can’t recommend these enough! Love the easy to use controls and the cupping feature so you can carry on a conversation without taking them off.

I purchased the Sony headphones and the Bose QuietComfort 35 (Series II) set because the reviews were so close and I wasn't sure which ones I would like better. While the Bose were definitely more comfortable and the case was large enough to fit the charging cord and headphone jack, the sound did not quite measure up. I did like the on/off switch of the Bose headphones better and the Bose app, but I love the Sony headphones for the following reasons. The sound is phenomenal...it's transforming. I took them on a recent flight and it was like being in another world...no noisy discussions or engine noise, just a beautiful series of sounds that volleyed from one ear to the next. It's easy to change tracks, adjust volume, or stop play by simply swiping or tapping the outside of the right earpiece. The Sony app is fairly easy to use, too, including a way to adjust if your connection cuts in and out. I didn't experience that with the Sony, but did with the Bose. If I could have chosen the comfort of the Bose with the sound of the Sony (and the convenient swipe feature) I would never take them off!

So far, so good. I tend to have a slightly low expectation for headphones since I'm not a fan of the band playing in the center of my head effect. I was surprised that these headphones actually have a great spatial sound. The noise canceling is on point. I had a chance to use them twice on flights over the weekend and they performed as marketed.

It has an adaptive noise canceling feature that's good, but it audibly alerts you when it changes. Not a big fan that, so I might turn it off. I have to admire the app and the headphones for actually guessing what I'm doing and where I am. It's a bit spooky, to be honest. Haha

I have a fairly large head, so I was a bit worried that they might cause a squeezed feeling, but they didn't. I've been able to wear them for several hours at a time without strain.

I care about my music quality and silence while working. These are awesome, high-end headphones for daily use to keep your in a cocoon of sound. They've helped ease air travel and train rides. Though because they're over-ear (which is my preference) they don't play well with neck pillows.

The tap to play/pause/next/back feature is amazing, but only works in bluetooth mode (not auxiliary plug in). The volume swipe uses rather small increments so you might have to swipe up quite a few times to increase by 50% or more.

The noise cancelling calibration does really work. I can hear the difference after it runs in a new environment. This is the product main differentiator from other similar models. I never use the app, but you can press to calibrate which I do all the time.

Fantastic headphones. The sound is clear and balanced. Using the app allows you to tweak the sound profile to your precise preference. Sony delivers awesome active noise cancelling as well. These are perfect for when I want to tune out everything else around me. The gesture based controls are very intuitive and I really like being able to allow ambient sound in by simply cupping the right side. I was torn between these and the Bose QC35s. Bose's offering are more comfortable, but these Sonys just offer more features as well as a much more fleshed out app. I've worn them for 4 hours without feeling discomofort on the crown of my head or around my ears. Battery life is great. I usually only have to charge them once a week. I have no regrets with my purchase and would recommend these to anyone.

Wow. Just...wow. My company moved to open plan recently. The noise cancelling feature has literally saved lives (of my coworkers).

Phones fit great (I'm a big dude) are light and comfortable and come with an awesome carrying case and adapters for airplane seats. Amazing design and function. The atmospheric pressure adjustment is a huge plus for air travel, as is the ability to change the level of noise cancelling.

PROS
- I didn't realize just how noisy my office was until I wore these for 8 hours, looked over, saw a couple gaggles of people behind me, took the headphones off, and then got blown away by how loud my coworkers are... I mean damn, it's like a music concert filled with chickens.
- There is background noise from environmental sounds (e.g. talking), but 2 people talking versus 10 people talking will barely change that background noise level. Even a slight background style music going will drown out those environmental sounds.
- Battery life

CONS
Ear cushions are rather narrow. If you're of the northeast European variety, then your ears will touch the inside of the cushion. For me that happens but it isn't uncomfortable, and my ears are on the large side.

I actually returned this product. The fit was uncomfortable (flight was about 3 hrs.) and the Noise cancelling feature would shut itself off automatically when I wore them to cancel the noise only. When listening to music or watching a movie there was no issue. Sound quality was pretty good but you have no control if you want to listen at a louder level.

As a longtime, satisfied Bose headphones user (QC15's), I anxiously awaited Black Friday to see if they were going to discount the QC35 II's for the holidays. When they did not budge from their std. list rate, coupled with high reviews both online and from a co-worker on the Sony's, I opted to purchase the latest model Sony WH1000XM2's.

I recently traveled internationally and had an opportunity to use the Sony's during multiple flights and am grateful to no longer have to be concerned about the QC15 cord and am very satisfied with the audio quality and noise cancellation. I like the ability to adjust volume and change songs by swiping on the right earpiece and the ability to briefly suppress noise cancellation by placing your right hand over the right ear cup.

Bose's unwillingness to reduce their std. list rate cost them a sale and potentially a longtime customer.

Love these headphones. Comfortable, don't hurt my head while wearing for any length of time. Great sound quality and noise cancellation. Also, the touch pad, compactness, and battery life make this a worthwhile purchase. Worth every penny. Would buy again.

Another serious contender. These headphones provide serious noise cancellation and wonderful music reproduction. Nonetheless the app that's free and included with the Headphones is very cleverly done and provides a significant amount of user input. Can't believe how good the noise cancelling is and how many features these headphones have. At first u will find the sound flat and a bid "muddy" but you just simply need to adjust the equalizer to your personal preferences and enjoy them👌👌

Product fits well, connects well, sounds great, and effectively blocks ambient noise. Audiophiles will prefer the sound of these over the Bose Q35's, and if you're a fan of deep bass (like me), again, you'll prefer these. The downloadable app for the headphones includes a customizable equalizer (not just a list of available presets like in Apple's music settings), and includes the option to increase bass specifically. This is important to me because by increasing the bass through the headphones themselves, rather than through the equalizer in my spotify app, I get the increased bass while bypassing the degradation in audio that characterizes bluetooth streaming. The LDAC system/High-Res Audio is great. The sound is noticeably better than the Q35's. If you purchase the Q35's you might notice that they sound great (bass included, it's very impressive) over a WIRED connection. But when transitioning to a bluetooth connection (e.g. from my Mac to my iPhone) the bass completely falls apart. It actually sounds like they're broken. This won't be an issue if you don't artificially increase the bass like I do (with the EQ in the spotify app), but if you like bass you will be disappointed. Not with the Sony pair though. The bass is great, the streaming quality is certainly superior, and the battery is phenomenal. Though for $350 I recommend getting the warranty. I've not experienced any "cracking" referenced in some other reviews (I've also had them for less than a month), but it was enough to scare me into getting the warranty. Which, considering the price of the investment, is really not a bad idea anyways.

Overall, highly recommend.

It's probably too early to write a review, after all I've only had this headphone set for less than 24 hours as I write this. But so far this Sony WH-1000XM2--an impersonal, heartless name if there ever was one--has been an impressive kit, at least after I actually figured out how the controls worked on this unit. So far I like the sonic qualities well enough for a closed design. I also like the comfort as I spent time with these on my day off, listening to a multitude of streamed music off of Amazon's Unlimited service, as well as my own digital files stored on my tablet and my phone.

It's lightweight enough to be comfortable throughout longer listening sessions. Even with my large ears the earpads envelope them and confirm that the design is truly an over-ear headphone set. The battery life is as promised and is still going strong well into its first charge. Its noise cancellation skill seems to be credible enough; though I'll need a noisier environment than my washing machine and vacuum cleaner to be certain (it may be my day off but chores are chores). The swipe controls (on the right earpiece housing) aren't the most intuitive to me at first and do seem quite sensitive, but I'm getting used to how it works. Fit and finish, as well as the build quality and materials are still too soon to judge, but so far they seem decent enough for something that costs $300 less tax(bought on sale here on Amazon). Comparing them to the QuietComfort 35 that I also was considering, this one hasn't left me wanting...so far.

This 'review' is for now more of a placeholder than a comprehensive go-over of the Sony, but at least for a day this Bluetooth headphone set has my attention. 4+ stars, for now.

Day 2: I've discovered that the XM2's noise cancelling ability is truly impressive. I've also discovered that wearing this headset to bed has its downfalls; rolling over onto my right side (a natural tendency I have), the right earcup ended up putting a fair amount of pressure on my head just above my ear. About four hours in I awoke with the headset still in place (something of a surprise since with other headphones I have a habit of losing or removing them off of my head during sleep), I had a pronounced sore spot at that area above my right ear, no doubt caused by the XM2 pressing against my skull for a good amount of that time. Hours later I still feel the irritation from wearing the Sony set during that sleep period. Disappointing but truthfully not totally unexpected.

I also have begun to garner a growing dislike for the touch controls on this headphone set. It's awfully easy for me to unintentionally or inadvertently sweep across that touch control surface and "do something" that didn't need to be done with the settings. That's an annoyance that I'll need to adjust myself to. Frankly having dedicated hardware controls would've mitigated this, but probably in Sony's design staff's view would've compromised the unit's exterior aesthetics, which I must admit is nicely clean and without clutter. But sometimes sacrifices need to be made and in this case of overly sensitive touch controls, this is one of those instances that clean, sparse aesthetics should have taken a back seat to functional parameters.

Battery life is indeed tremendous, but it's a downer that the headset can't be used wirelessly when the battery is charging. In fact when the unit is charging it's not particularly usable even when the included mini patch chord is used. There's a lot of electrical noise leakage when the XM2 is being charged, and it's enough to my ears to quell any desire to use the headset when the micro USB power chord is plugged in. I've also discovered some irritating sonic qualities to the Sony's sound signature and imaging soundstage. Some music really comes off as being rather murky sounding, muddled in the lack of detail and presence, while other types or specific songs are considerably less noticeable as such. It doesn't have me tossing aside the XM2 and reaching for one of my open-back headphones just yet, but it's still disappointing nonetheless.

Still calling it 4+ stars, but inching slowly downward.

Day 14: Yeah, I do LIKE this set of headphones. The noise cancelling is still excellent and better than I imagined it would ever be. The sound quality is very good given its closed dynamics. The SQ will never approach my preferred preference for open-back headphones and (to me) their superior, more 'natural' spatial qualities, but for what it is this XM2's sound continues to please me. I've figured out where to adjust the headband to in able to relieve most of the pressure this design places on the top of my ear, so even from a comfort standpoint it's becoming a non-event. The touch controls remain the only annoyance, but I AM adapting. I just think that it shouldn't have to be such a pain, especially since fingering and swiping the side of one's head is not exactly a natural thing for humans (well, most of us anyway).

Definitely 4+ stars.

Goosebumps continues...;) Throw some 24bits FLAC. Oh my.... The base. Middle. Highs. Fellas, mp3s won't do any justice to these cans. It all depends on your music. 24 bits have so much details. The base is another level. I've S8 with Exynos. So no aptX HD. But just put the Sony app and change mode to connection priority. Then fiddle with the EQ and see the difference. But put mode to quality priority if you want the best details. Unless you've latest snapdragon devices which natively support aptX HD, it doesn't matter. So I'd take the customization instead of aptX ( not 'aptx HD'). But if you've aptx HD capable device go ahead by all means. Again only for HQ audio. If your library is mp3 put it on connection priority and get the EQ adjustments. Enjoy fellas. Mind blowing. But for the ULTIMATE QUALITY you've to plug in the cable. Even LDAC can't equal wired quality. These cans + cable + S8 + 24bits FLAC = musical paradise. But who cares, we buy Bluetooth headphones for wireless freedom.

Amazing noise cancelling. I could enjoy using these, but I prefer the Bose QC35. With these Sony’s, my ears get hot and there is too much clamping pressure. Plus I don’t like the white noise at low volume. That being said - the noise cancelling at anything above low volume blows Bose out of the water. Coming from my favorite Sony MDR-7506, needed noise-cancelling for travel. Rich balanced sound - not bass-heavy like some other sets I've tried, much more balanced and comfortable sound levels. Very little difference overall from the MDR-7506 using mobile phone as source. Noise cancelling is superb. The NC Optimizer can be triggered with a press of a button and adjusts noise cancelling to your environment. Touch sensor on the right side is brilliant - easy control of music and phone calls. Love the Quick Attention feature, placing your hand over the touch panel quiets the music and pipes in ambient sound so you can quickly hear what's going on around you. Much more comfortable than my MDR-7506 - I can wear these for hours with no issues - very soft pads. Impressive build quality. Great that they can be used sans-power when connecting the cable. No complaints whatsoever.

I used Bose noise canceling for at least 10 years and I am very glad Sony came out with these headphones. The noise canceling might be slightly less efficient but the overall experience is much, much better. The app allows to equalize the sound to your taste, which is great; you can tap on the side of the set to pause, skip songs, hear the flight attendant without taking off the set. The battery charge is enough to fly to far, very far destinations and the construction feels robust. Comfort is good too. I am looking forward to see how long the foam pads will last. All my Bose sets started to fall apart in a very annoying way after a few years and I can’t believe they never fixed the problem choosing better materials.

The headphones are just amazing. The sound quality is definetly worth the price, and the ANC functuality definetly lives up to its name. These headphones are nothing short of incredible.

They block out all types of noises while also providing rich sounding audio. I've used these on the train and the amount of sound the noise canceling reduces is remarkable. One time on the train there was a woman playing the guitar literally across from me and I could just very faintly hear her with the noise canceling on and no music playing. Even my bus rides have been made so much more enjoyable just by wearing these headphones and being able to tune out the traffic just beyond my window.

In addition to the noise canceling, I like the fact that it can be turned off so you can let ambient sound in. Why you may ask? So when you're walking on a busy street or an intersection, you can still hear oncoming cars for safety purposes.

The fit is comfy and I like the foldable flat design. The touch controls are effective and I like being able to cup my hand over the right earcup if I need to speak to someone and don't want to take off my headphones. The battery life is excellent and they do well with all types of music from Jazz, to hip-hop, blues, vocals, you name it.

My only con is they can make my ears sweat after a prolonged period of time, so unfortunately I won't be wearing these during the summer. But I have earbuds for that, so I'm good. These ain't cheap but they're well worth the money.

OMG These headphones are spectacular. For a while now I've been a "no wire, no fun" headphone kind of guy, but I decided to try these. I've heard great things about Sony so I figured why not. And I'm never going back. The sound quality is excellent, I'd say better than alot of "premium" wired headphones and they are definitely leading the wireless headphones scene. Not only do they sound amazing, but they manage to retain this quality with VERY powerful noise cancelling AND Bluetooth. Also it comes with some very cool features like a touch sensitive ear cup. Just cool.

So what separates these from other headphones? Well in my experience they sound better, have insane noise cancelling magic, and are actually really comfy to wear. I recently went on about a 6 hour car ride and they were super comfy throughout the trip. Also, this battery lasts forever. I've never got the headphones to "battery level: medium" let alone the headphones dying.

Now of course nothing is perfect. The bass could be the tiniest bit punchier, but some eq settings fixed that quickly. More importantly though, the case is just silly. There is no room inside for anything than the headphones. The wires you might want to bring have a pocket on the outside of the case. Cmooonnnn. It's funny really that the worst part of the headphones are the cases. But again I won't detract from the headphones, they are spectacular, and if you need a different case, you can choose from a variety of third party options.

Overall: buy these things. I almost never give reviews on Amazon stuff, but these deserve one.

Great noise cancelling headphones with a few wrinkles. Consider saving yourself $100+ and buy the refurbished MDR-1000X/B which are last year's version and almost identical. I've taken both the 1000XM2 and the 1000X/B on a flight and compared the them by swapping back and forth repeatedly; both using only noice cancellation, and while listening to music and movies while also using noise cancellation. The noise cancelling between them is almost identical, but not quite. XM2 seem to have the slightest edge over the old X/B, but I suspect it is because of the earpieces, not the technology. If you look at the photo I've included with this review, you'll see the XM2 headphones have smaller openings for your ears. If you have a large head or ears, this is definitely noticeable when you're wearing them. I suspect this smaller opening contributes to the ever so slightly better noise cancellation on the XM2. And it is really slight. However, because of this tighter opening for the ears, the XM2 will make your ears hotter than the X/B if you're wearing them for hours at a time (e.g. on long flights).

As for the sound quality, both the XM2 and the X/B sound good, not great. If sound quality is top priority over noise cancelling, then go with the B&W PX or any number of other wired passive headphones. Here again, the XM2's tighter earpieces were a downside for me. They cause the soundstage move further toward the back of head, instead of out front where you really want it to be. The X/B put the soundstage right in between my ears, which still isn't awesome, but it's SLIGHTLY better than the XM2. Neither model can compete with a pair of good open cup headphones like the Sennheiser HD650. But then you get absolutely no noise isolation, so pick your priority.

Other oddities...the XM2 has textured faux leather on the ear cups, the X/B has smooth. I prefer the smooth. The touch controls on the XM2 seem more prone to error (skipping tracks when you just meant to change the volume) than the X/B.

TL;DR Apparently I'm turning in a grumpy old man who doesn't like change. The MDR1000X/B were great--why, Sony, did you change them for this? And get off my lawn!

EDIT: The above review was written before I tired the companion app. The app has a soundstage control ("Sound Position Control") that appears to be a crossfeed function. It fixes the "back of your head" soundstage problem I mentioned above. If you're reading this, Sony, please ditch the graphic EQ and adopt a parametric version where the user can just adjust the frequency response curve to their desired target. So much more useful than a graphic EQ.

Some other reviews mentioned the cracking issues on the MDR-1000X/B that I professed a fondness for. I haven't had any issues with mine, but others certainly have. Definitely take that into consideration. I also haven't had any issues with either headphones responding to pillows, seat cushions, hoods, or stocking caps. Capacitive controls shouldn't respond to pressure from everyday objects. That sounds like a defective headphone.

Just hands down the best set of headphones I've owned, admittedly, I don't own very many. Others have written more thorough and thoughtful reviews and I agree with nearly all aspects. They looks great and sound even better, even with ANC turned on. I commute by subway through NYC and with these cans on nearly all background noises dissolve away, quite amazing. They are on the pricier side for me, but it's an audio investment for years to come. Get the warranty, you can't beat a $17, 4 year warranty through square trade.

For anyone doing comparison shopping between these and the Bose QC35 II. You can't go wrong with either, however, i'm very happy with my decision to go with Sony. Just don't buy beats studio 3, they're garbage for the price range.
