Up until a couple days ago, these headphones were absolutely wonderful for me. Great sound, comfortable, and the noise cancelling was almost too good. However, unfolding them one day, they snapped on me. The plastic screw housing that holds the back of the connectors to the cups (L and R shown in pics) cracked, and are now being held together with tape. Be careful, they're more delicate than they look.

The touch feature is good but can be annoying as it can stop the sounds if it inadvertently touch anything. I think it is better if Sony will put a off/on switch to activate the touch feature. I have the comparable Bose and the sounds are comparable but I, personally, prefer the Bose sounds. I really do not know as maybe I am just used to Bose headphones. They are the same price if I can only buy one, I would prefer the Bose. As far as noise cancelling in airplanes, I have not tested them yet.

I purchased these headphones to replace a pair of Sennheiser RS160 for the ANR feature as I use them for watching TV simultaneously with my wife who listens through my surround sound system. I have hearing loss such that we can't find a volume that doesn't blast her out in order for me to hear. Even then, I struggle with speech clarity. I have then connected to two unused channels from my Denon 3300 AVR through an Avantree Priva III bluetooth adapter with APTX LL. I was concerned that the Sony WH1000 that although they have APTX they don't support low latency, but when I tried this combination dialog matching between picture and sound is very close and not a hindrance at all.

When I tested these haedphones at Best Buy I was standing next to a young mother with two toddlers that were anything but quiet at the time. Shut them out completely. At home, exterior noises are just about non-existant so this ANR is fantastic. The controls are easy and the headphones paired with the adapter right away on first try. They reconnect easily when I turn them on.

I have experienced a desire for a little more volume as many others reviews have pointed out but not enough to lower my rating. I am also concerned with the reports of cracking and so I am extra careful when handling the headphones The carrying case is not built very strong but I don't use them in that way.

For ANR, these headphones even the playing field with Bose if not exceeds the pricier headphones.

Works as advertised. Very comfortable. The app that you can sync it to is a little gimmicky though. Only two or three of the presets sound decent but if you really mess around with a custom option you can improve the listening experience a little bit.

The bluetooth range is fantastic. I went down three flights of stairs, through three doors, out of my garage and still picked up clear signal. Bluetooth range should never be a worry.

The noise cancelling is really good but after owning it for a few months it seems to be working with a little less quality. It may be because I mostly sync it to my laptop now instead of my phone. The app makes everything sound better and that is perhaps the reason why.

Far better build than the MDR 1000x. Only issue I have with it is that it still cannot pair via bluetooth to a Windows 10 Pro or other Windows OS laptop/desktop. It states it is connected but the device shows up and wrong driver, non-functioning driver or just doesn't pair/work. I use the supplied audio cable for laptop purposes.

These headphones are great. The price is a little steap but the quality you are getting is well worth it. Better than any Apple product I’ve used as well. The only reason I’m giving it 4 stars is because I do not like the touch feature to adjust the volume or to skip. It’s just a preference but I find it really annoying because you have to continuously swipe to get to the volume level you desire. I prefer how you can just choose the level once. These are very comfortable and the option to cover your ear to mut the music is very useful.

Oversea user. Cheaper than in China, I researched months, comparing each models of different brands, primarily between BOSE QC35 and this baby. Finally choosed Sony. Over 3 months using it, so far so good, It won’t cancel all the noise, but it will reduce enought amount of them to help me concentrate, only major one downside is switching paired bluetoothdevices is not so easy. And it’s expensive you decide

The Good:
noise cancelling is great, adaptive settings seem to really help different environments
comfortable ear cups, easily fit over ear, I can wear for hours. Easy to put on without missing ear lobes or hair.
touch controls are great after a bit of getting used to. Pass through audio is super effective.

The Ok:
GSM interference whilst connected via bluetooth is a bit "retro" If phone is near face, it's quiet loud
Microphone seems to pick up a lot of ambient noise when making calls. Other end can hear me, but also traffic noises.

The Bad:
Case, albeit tidy, cannot store USB or 3.5mm jack cable, but does have storage for flight adapter?!?! which is, of course, useless without jack cable.

Really like these headphones, though! I'd recommend them, but the GSM noise just knocks some of the shine away.
(I don't know if this is a common problem on BT/NC headphones, but its the first time I've heard on a bluetooth set, last time I heard/suffered was with cabled Bose QC2 about 10 years ago before I moved to bluetooth headphones)

Wow, excellent audio quality! My music that I stream through Google Play Music sounds amazing!

Has a feature where if I place my palm on the right headphone it will mute the music so I can hear what my wife is saying. Otherwise I can't hear her. I made my wife try these on and talked to her, and she said the only thing she could hear from me was when I made a "sssss" sound.

I just love these headphones. The noise cancellation is insane, and they sound amazing. You can tell each sound appart and they all sound in great harmony.

Best case scenario, my wife is having a "not-so-great" time with our kids, 2 and 4 years old, and I just fire them up listening to spotify, or even a movie on Netflix, and my peace and calm are back in an instant.

After thorough research, I have concluded these are the best headphones for my personal preferences in the $350 price point. These will give you the best combination of sound quality, battery life, and noise cancellation. The main qualities that helped me choose these over the bose 35 series were the follow:

Sound Quality: Based on reviews these were shown to have slightly better sound quality than the bose 35. Also, when the sony headphones are completely out of battery you can still use them as headphones without a distortion of sound quality while the bose 35 headphone sound deteriorates.

Battery Life: Sony's headphones have ~30 hours of battery life per charge while the bose 35 only last for 20 hours.

Features: The Sony headphones have more features. I particularly like the Sony headphones ability to pause sound in the headphones by cupping the right ear so you can speak to someone normally without needing to take off the headphones.

Hope my review was helpful! Please like my review if it assisted you.

excellent product !!!, I love listening to music, while I go or leave my work, I love not listening to anyone while I'm with my favorite music.I bought bc qc35, compared to sony and both are excellent! Noise reduction in both, the sound a little better in the Sony. only criticism, is the touch panel of the Sony, which is sometimes confused when you turn down the volume or change the song, there strange manual control of the bose. excellent product if you like to listen to music with your cell phone and use headphones that accompany, recommended!

The sound quality is great and I love the touch panel that can turn up/down the volume and change sounds. However, I wore this for 2 hours and my neck began to sour because how heavy it is. Have to return it because it is not a headphone I can wear all day.
Overall it is a nice headphone if you don't mind the weight of it.

I have the Bose QC15s and other headphones. These sound *amazing*. The noise cancelling is better than the Bose and the sound richer. As a long-time Bose user, I almost hate to say it but get these over the Bose QC15s. The Bose are a tiny bit more comfortable to me, but these are great.

Really excellent product. Could have a higher maximum volume. Not that I use it that high but it’s a nice feeling knowing that I’m not more than half way to the limit. I know Sony just wants to save want heating.

These are great as long as you're listening to an audio source. But if you'd like to use them simply to block ambient noise, don't buy these as they automatically shut off after five minutes without a wired input or Bluetooth pairing.

Do a very good job cutting noise in workplace or on bus.
Sound quality is decent, not amazing. Fit is a bit loose and the adjustment in the band a bit too light so it needs to be reset every time I put them on. Provided case is nice and battery life quite good.

These headphones sound great, however in Bluetooth mode you can still tell sometimes that you are listening to Bluetooth headphones. There is still the typical Bluetooth sound signature. Don't get me wrong though, they sound excellent for Bluetooth headphones. Vocal bass is a bit weak, but instrumental bass is great. Mid-tones are good and have enough detail. Treble frequencies are very good. I find that to get the best sound, I have to put my iPhone equalizer on the treble boost setting, and as well, I have to put the Sony Connect app on it's treble boost setting also. Otherwise without these settings, the headphones sound muffled.

I find that I can have long listening sessions with these headphones without any temporary hearing loss or ear fatigue. I can not say this for all headphone I have used, so this is a positive.

The Sony mobile app has several features including a manual equalizer that works pretty well. The app has a surround feature to change the position of vocals. I don't know why anyone would want to use this feature, since it distorts already good sounding audio. The ambient sound auto-adjust feature can be turned on and off in the app. It is disabled by default.

The product is nicely manufactured and the headband does have enough pleather coated padding. I have not felt any discomfort wearing the headphones. I did not find the touchpad difficult to use; it works great. Noise cancelation is unusually good and I think this is the headphones strength. I feel that I made a good purchase. These do not sound as good as the Bowers and Wilkins P7wireless, but the ability to have very good active noise cancelation makes them a good buy. My only complaint about the headphones is that there is audible hissing during noise cancelation mode. Hopefully this will be corrected in the next model.

Noise canceling works good but fit very loosely on head, you cannot move abruptly when wearing or they fall off, wish they fit tighter,also sound quality is not so great for a large headset like these, wish they were louder,don’t recommend.

Awesome headphones.....so far none of this cracking business that I keep hearing about.
Battery life really is long lasting and the NC is perfect for flights and noisy offices. It does not block out sound 100% but it is definitely good enough and if you play music then you will not hear anything else guaranteed. I have had this now for a few months and I do not regret buying it at all.

The headphones are amazing. ANC is the best when compared to other headphones in the range and they look extremely stylish. I used them regularly on commutes and I was pretty satisfied with them.

The mic in the headphones are so terrible that I thought I got a defective piece and exchanged it for another one and found out that the new product also had the same problem. The person on the other end of the call cant even hear my voice over the noise in a bus/train. The same problem persisted on a not so noisy office environment. Sony should seriously consider working on fixing this issue.
Worked fine but the touch controls were very sensitive. Had to return.

Stopped working after just a single day! The headphones would no longer turn on, and it turns out that this is an incredibly common problem that Sony doesn't like to admit to or properly deal with. In addition, I also came across countless reviews that mentioned that the old problem of the hinges and band breaking after just a few months of normal use has not been fixed. Sony has never been very good about dealing with defective products. They are very difficult to get ahold of to begin with, and they try to deny your warranty claim any chance they get. If you do manage to get the claim approved, then it takes months and months to do so.

Beyond the many problems with the headphones, the sound leaves a lot to be desired. They have good highs and half decent lows, but the mids are absolutely non-existent. My cheap $15 headphones sound better even with their tin-like highs. I will say that on the plus side they are very comfortable, and even without the noise cancellation they do a great job of blocking out outside sounds. I would much rather either go a slight step up with something like the Sennheiser HD-1 or something cheaper like the under $100 Plantronics or some other brand.
These are the best headphones I've ever owned. They sound fantastic, they feel premium, they ARE premium. It's a lot of money to drop on headphones, but if you want the best, here it is.

With 30+ hrs battery on bluetooth and 40+ hrs on wire, these super comfy headphones deliver the best sound quality, with market leading noise cancellation technology by Sony. I used them in the streets of Cairo (one of the loudest cities on the globe), and it just kept all the noise out! It was magical to me as I've never experienced such thing as long with that much of comfort these headphones deliver.
I strongly recommend these headphones; They might be a bit expensive, but they are totally worth the money.

Okay, I've only had these for a few days so these are my initial impressions. (I keep updating this review as I continue to use the headphones)

I've also bought the Sennheiser PXC 550 Wireless. The Sony ANC is *much* better than the PXC.

I found the PXC earmuffs got my ears very hot even in a room less than 70º F. I can't possibly imagine using them in the summer. The room I'm is 69º F. The headphones, and my ears, are 90º F. My ears are red.

ANC: I turned on a battery driven vacuum cleaner which is *extremely* loud. I normally wear commercial grade hearing protection when working with loud equipment. I tried on the Sony ANC and the noise dropped massively. The commercial grade hearing protection let in a lot more noise. But make no mistake, no ANC is going to magically remove all noise.

Switching between the Mac and iPhone is a massive pain. I don't think Sony could have made switching more difficult. Probably easier to have two sets of headphones because if you're using the headphones on the Mac and the iPhone rings, you will never, ever be able to switch before the calling party hangs up.

I find the Sony headset controls to be confusing. The PXC were easier to use.

Connecting to Siri on my iPhone X is completely hit-or-miss. The directions are all over the place. Double tap for 0.4 seconds (seriously?) and other directions state to press and hold. I would like to make a phone call from the Sony without having to get the iPhone out but I haven't found the magical press or tap or double tap to invoke Siri and say "Hey Siri, call Pizza". Update: Reading a different portion of the manual, I found that tapping the headphone will activate Siri.

I found this portion of the manual confusing:

"Make a request to Siri through the headset’s microphone.
When the iPhone is in standby or playing music, hold your finger to the touch sensor control panel to activate Siri.
Siri is activated and you will hear the start-up sound."

....then several lines down....

"Siri cannot be activated when you say “Hey Siri” through the headset’s microphone even when the iPhone’s [Allow “Hey Siri”] setting is on."

Can someone explain the apparent contradiction in instructions above or am I really dense?

Contrary to what the negative comments regarding the microphone, I found the Sony microphone to be clear (at least according to the person I was speaking to).

I'm not an audiophile but I found the sound quality to be very, very good in Bluetooth mode.

The Sony app annoys me. Why does Sony need to know my exact location at all times (even when running in the background) to work properly. How does it matter if I'm 5th or 6th avenue? The 'Privacy' EULA is over the top.

I have had the headphones on for about 30 minutes and my ears are very, very warm. There's not a chance I could use the Sony over the ears headphones in a warm (let alone hot) environment. These would be great for keeping your ears warm in the winter.

While I'm not thrilled with Bose, I'm going to a store to compare the Sony against the QC35 II for ANC and far more importantly, ear comfort.
If the headphones are very uncomfortable (hot and sweaty), I'm not going to use the headphone regardless of how great they sound.

Ugghh. My ears are burning up in the time I've written this review -- I've got to take them off.

If you're the type of person who tends to have cold ears, then these may be perfect you (if you can figure out the controls).

I'm probably going to keep these for a niche use: I spend a lot of time in waiting rooms where the TV is blaring putting a hole through my head. Yes, I could use high-quality noise ear plugs to virtually eliminate the noise but I want to listen to something. So for the 30-90 minutes I have to wait, I can tune out the mindless screeching from the TV and calmly listen to music from my phone.

Great features
Supports multiple modes including ambient noise enablement when required
Excellent sound quality

Cons
LDAC only supported in Android Oreo so most Android phones will have to wait
Does not pair with TaoTronics BT transmitter so I'm unable to connect to my TV.
I really like the comfort of these headphones, but if you use them to talk on the phone, the noise can be very loud for the person you’re talking to.

Liking the sound.

Update : Sound is awesome but had to return them because they were loose from side. Disappointed because I actually loved the headphones

Upgraded from a Bohm 66 to this headset. No regrets here. The sound quality build and noise cancellation are vastly superior to the Bohm 66, but its not a fair comparison is it?

Found this to be as good if not better than the QC35. At less than 300 USD on black Friday, these just beat the QC 35 hands down as my choice of a premium noise cancelling wireless headset for long trans pacific flights.
Great sound and functionality, but they don’t like to always connect which is a pain to deal with.

The noise-canceling is amazing. It can shut his voice off without me telling him to shut up. Or if u want to use the headphone just for noise canceling, it’s still good. Just mute the music and enjoy the world of silence.
By the way, just to not mislead anyone, it doesn’t completely silence the voice, if you hear some noise leaking in, it’s normal. Nothing is wrong with that.
Defective and unreliable. Even the audio jack does not work properly!

The confort and weight they offer is amazing. The sound is very good, but, coming from the MDR 950BT, the volume and bass didn't feel as loud as I'd like to. That could've been a deal breaker for some people.

I own a pair of bose QC35's and got these for my wife. As they are at the same price point, I expected this to be the same or better. It's not:
1) They are not nearly as comfortable. They fit quite tightly whereas the bose fits like a pillow. My wife has to take her earrings off every time she uses these, while she can keep them on with the Bose QC35. I can wear the Bose for 4-5 hours straight - have to take the sony's off after a while.
2) Pairing multiple devices is a breeze with the bose, it's a pain in the rear with the Sony.
3) Sound quality is not on par. Sound is flatter than the Bose. Yes there is an app and an EQ for your phone, but see #4.
4) For $50 I'd like to toy with headphones. At almost $400, I want the damn things to be studio quality. I don't want an app with 5 different customisation settings. It's almost as if all the "features" are there to make up for lack of sound fullness.

Yes there are more features than the Bose, but this headset fails as premium headphones and that's its primary purpose.
The good:
1) Noise Cancellation is great.
2) Gesture control is nice.
3) They can play significantly louder than the Bose.
hard to get the headphones to work. much more difficult to use than the bose models

Extremely Comfortable, after upgrading from a pair of High-end SkullCandy Headphones, I am blown away.
If you are looking for the best features and amazing Noise Cancelling, the Sony 1000xm2's are the way to go!

Hi,
I am founder indexoid.com. The headphones are all right for me, I would recommend making a case made of carbon fiber, it would be better.

Absolutely love these !!!! They sound amazing! They Shipped very fast they smell very fresh when I opened them. Had a tiny bit of charge to test the sounds. Downloaded the Sony connect app. Extremely satisfied with this purchase. I upgraded to these from the bose QC 25. Not as comfortable as the QC25 or 35 but has more features. They came with everything that they should come with. Looks very nice wearing them. Over all love them.

Well the item itself is good. Noise-canceling tech is really something amazing.Once connected to my walkmanA35,the LDAC is awesome ,making the quality of the music fantastic.And its comfortable to wear on my head. However, the touch control is not so sensitive. Anyway,it's okay for me to enjoy listening to music with this product.
Love them. Noice cancellation is amazing without that weird pressure feeling from Bose. Sound is great even though I still like my old Harman/Kardon BT more :)

Great noise cancelling. I wore them at the Vikings game and was able to listen to the radio broadcast. They probably saved my hearing as the crowd noise at the stadium was really loud. I've also worn them on airplanes and they work VERY well.
It's good
Best noise cancelling cans today. Unboxing experience was great. Can't ask for more accessories. Delivers great sound and noise cancellation as promised.

So this was my third attempt at finding a pair of wireless over-ear headphones. My previous two were a cheaper set of Sonys and the Bowers & Wilkins PX. For various reasons, those did not work out, which led me to these. This will be the quickest I've ever returned a set of headphones. I had 4 main issues with these:

1. They did not fit on my head. Even on the tightest setting, they were too loose on my head. If I look up, they'd slide off backwards. If I look down, they'd slide off forwards. If I look left and right they slowly slide down my ears. Funny enough, I always thought I had a slightly larger than average head size, but apparently my head is not big enough to keep these headphones on them, even on the snuggest setting. This was massively disappointing as I did not see any other reviewers mention this.

2. The ear cup size is actually too small for my ears. These headphones are making me paranoid: am I a small headed, big eared freak? Seriously, the opening in each ear cup is too small to fit my ears, regardless of how much I shift them around. This made them ultimately feel like they're somewhere between on ear headphones and over ear headphones. Maybe they should brand them as Mostly Over Ear? It's uncomfortable not having your ears fit inside the cups.

3. Sound leakage. Good god these are awful in this category. It's embarrassing trying to ride the train and knowing that everyone around you can hear exactly what you're listening to. If you like to listen to music loudly, you may as well carry a boom box around because your neighbors within about 12 feet will hear everything you're listening to.

4. Swipe controls. This is the smallest complaint, and the only one that wouldn't be a deal breaker for me if it were the only issue I had with these. They're way too sensitive and I couldn't find a way to turn them off. The slightest adjustment I was trying to make to the ear cups, which happened often since they wouldn't stay on my head, would accidentally trigger the volume lowering or the song skipping or something. I'm sure with enough time I would perfect the art of tip-toe-ing around accidentally triggering the controls when adjusting the fit, but I will not own them long enough for that to happen.

So I guess I'll mention what these headphones do good: sound quality and noise cancellation. They are great at both of these things. So I guess if you're a big headed, small eared person who doesn't care that your neighbors can hear everything you're listening to, or maybe you just listen at home when no one else is around, or maybe you're just inconsiderate and don't care that everyone can hear your music, then feel free to buy these headphones. As for me, the quest to find a solid pair of wireless headphones continues.
Really helps me commuting to work. They truly are noise cancelling. My only grievance is the sound - wish it was better.
Sound quality is good, but it's not comfortable to wear long period of time at least for me.

This is the best noise cancelling wireless head set available right now !! My thoughts after using it for a month.
Pros:
- It really has close to 30 hours battery life
- Very good noise isolation and cancellation. Even better than Bose QC35 II.
- Customization's for ambient noise
- Touch screen controls will need some getting to know, but when you do you will love it
- Useful companion app on Mobile device
- Wired sounds even better. Comes with a very nice and sturdy 3.5 mm to 3.5 mm aux
- Two tone color
Cons:
- These cans do tend to get hot and are not quite as comfortable as Bose for longer duration's
- MDR 1000X (it's predecessor) headbands used to crack a lot
- The case could be made better to stow the aux and usb cables

Got it during the sale for $50 off !!

Will update this review when I receive the replacement. I have had this product in my wish list for weeks, and have been visiting Target to try them on and test them - just to make sure I was making the right buying decision. You know, $299+ is a lot of money! So anyway, I bit the bullet yesterday and purchased them with same-day shipping. After I charged them up, I turned them on...paired my bluetooth...put them on...and what do you know, the left ear doesn't work at all. :(
Thankfully Amazon is sending a replacement today, so fingers crossed the new set works as expected.

Since other people write pro audio tech reviews, let me write something else.

the gold color is not like shining color so its easy to match any of your clothing, and its not too casual, giving even formal feeling from the smooth surface. Also its imortant to note that Im male who doesn’t look girly at all by wearing this.

In addition, its 12 degree here today, definitely good investment to walk in the NYC safely by enabling ambient mode on. I enabled voice focus mode on, and I was able to chat with my partner without taking out this headset under this cold weather.

Perfect modern urban gear.

As an audio engineer of many decades who has mixed music and film, I am absolutely bowled over by these headphones. They absolutely destroy my old SONY Bt-60's for audio quality. And the noise cancellation function is astonishing. Now, I will confess I have never owned a set of noise-cancelling headphones before, but as I work in a wood shop for hours each day, these things are a godsend and well worth the top dollar to me personally. The noise of my table saw which I have suffered with for years is radically diminished. And low level ambient sounds such as fans, traffic, driving in your automobile, even your shopping cart, completely disappear!

The touch-sensitive controls -- no more buttons or dials -- to adjust the phones appear very functional and superb. Now, as yet this review is not very long because I have just tested this set, but I will add to this review later as I can elaborate with more detail and experience. For the moment, it must be obvious I am in a state of euphoria.

I was like most people, struggling to decide to pick this or the qc35 ii. I tried both at Bestbuy and decided to go with this. The sound is much better. The media playback functions are much easier to use. Just swipe or tap on the right earcup. Mich more natural than the multi function button in Bose. This is also very comfortable enough for my 2 hour gym session. Not to mention I bought this when it was on sale. So $50 cheaper than Bose.

Upgraded to noise cancelling from a pair of AKG Y50BT which came with my Samsung S8+.

Extremely impressive cans. The app is also very well done. I often work from a well known coffee chain for a few hours at a time, and it's amazing how much of the ambient noise these reduce. I really like the color, although it's not gold but more of a light bronze. Unlike some reviewers, I have no discomfort wearing for 8 hours a day, they fit nicely over my ears -- I have no hair, and don't extend the band, so maybe that's why they fit well.

One tip is that unless you use the app, you may be disappointed by the default EQ settings. I listen to mostly chillout, minimal, progressive, and other electronic instrumental music, and out of the box the bass was weaker than expected. BUT the app lets you create custom EQ settings, which allowed me to perfectly EQ for what I prefer. I'm really picky and the app satisfied my needs.

If you have the cash, I strongly recommend these!

In all honesty, this review may not give justice to how good these headphones sound. The ANC on these is so good that I can't even hear my friend talking next to me in the car while I write this review. The sounds from cars are almost completely diminished, and classroom chatter is significantly reduced. When you start playing music, you can hear only louder noises, like car horns, generators, and PA announcements. Even these sounds are dull and reduced a lot.The sound quality in these is stellar. There is no focus on either bass or treble; they are generally more balanced. You can control this in the app that you should definitely download and then get tinkering with the equalizer. The headphones are great for the flier since they can help reduce or increase the pressure, controlled through the app. The battery life is so good. I haven't even used the entire thing in an entire week, but I guess that depends on how much you use this. The only con with these is that they are pretty expensive and that if you lose them or get them stolen, that's a big loss of an investment.I could go on about the items great features, but the only way you can definitely know about it is if you buy it, which you should.

Wanted an upgrade from my previous ANC headphones, Beats Studio 2.0. Headphones considered: Bowers and Wilkins PX and Sennheiser PXC 550. No...I didn't even consider the Bose QC 35 2. Demoed it in the store and thought the bass was way too heavy and too similar sounding to the Beats Studio 2.0. I loved my Beats and they served their purpose well but technology changes rapidly and I wanted something with BT capabilities.

Sound is phenomenal! Crisp highs and mids without boomy, over exaggerated bass. I like my share of bass but not to a point where it takes over. I truly enjoy listening to my music in the 1000XM2! Sound is different when wireless, using a cable and with ANC on. Although different, the sound is still great in any mode. Personally, I prefer wireless with ANC on. I haven't found a need to mess with any of the setting in the app much but will explore those settings as well.

ANC is MUCH better than my previous travel and work headphones. Outside sound is muted and I feel like I'm in my own world. With my previous headphones I could still hear outside noises just not clearly. Music sounds great with ANC on or off but I do find it to be a bit different.

Comfort is EXCELLENT! Very lightweight, soft ear pads and not tight on my head/ears. I have not noticed any heat issues but have only worn them for 2 hours at a time so far. The absolute most comfortable of any of the headphones that I was able to try on or any that I currently own (V-Moda LP2 with XL ear pads, Beats Studio 2.0, JBL Synchros S700, and Logitech UE 6000)

Features are far beyond what I as using. Very easy to lear and use. The touch controls are a game changer in the headphone market! The form factor when folded and in the case is small and compact.

Overall, I'm very pleased with this purchase. I ordered and demoed the Bowers and Wilkins PX also but they are going back. GREAT sound but the Sony WH1000XM2 is far more comfortable and I prefer the touch controls.

Update 2/19:
I finally started messing around with the Sony Headphones Connect App. This puts this product even further ahead of all others that I tried and considered. The ability fine tune Ambient Sound and ANC truly is a game changer!!! The Equalizer is another option that is included and is very helpful. Adaptive Sound Control works well but I prefer to set my own ambient and ANC settings. YES...I LOVE these headphones!

The headphones are every bit as advertised. They sound great, the base noise cancellation is incredible, the bluetooth connectivity and sound processing work over a very long range, and they are exceptionally comfortable. The one drawback from these headphones is not the device itself but rather the optional software you can download for them to your mobile device. The base noise cancellation works incredibly well. When you get into the software fine tuning it lessens the noise cancellation effect to a noticeable degree. If I could change one thing about the software I would lessen the fine tuning of the noise cancellation and add other functionality such as a pedometer. Wait, I almost forgot to mention the touch controls on the unit. They all work exceptionally well axcept the pause/play function. If you don't hit the spot exactly you might end up skipping a song. Volume and next/previous song work fine since it is a swiping action.

Frequent Traveler who bought these primarily for flights.

Have Beats wired Studio noise canceling head phones, bought the Bose Q35 and compared to the Sony WH1000XM2. Also have Bose Wireless Sport headphones, Seinser wired ear buds, Bose wired sport buds, AKG buds I got with my S8 and I-Phone buds I got with my IPhone 6.

Sound Quality is subjective and very personal, my preference is the Sony's over all the headphones I currently have, non noise canceling and noise canceling.

Direct comparison to the Beats, Bose, the sound quality is preferred on the Sony as mentioned above, noise canceling very, very slight edge to the Sony, Bose and Sony are both well ahead of the Beats I own (4 year old model). Features, hands down the Sony absolutely blows away anything I've seen on the market. The App allows you to customize the noise canceling in useful, meaningful ways, has a customizable equalizer that allows you to personalize the sound in a meaningful way. The app also has surround sound settings that are gimmicky, didn't seem to do anything but take away from the sound quality. Being able to cup the right ear to turn off the head phones and hear someone is really great feature, being able to customize the noise canceling to filter out or allow voices and if you like automatically adjust based on your movement pretty cool.

On calls - I've read professional and personal reviews that all say phone calls are better on the Bose, I tested both, the Sony performed better for me, I was able to hear myself more clearly, others heard me more clearly on the Sony. The Sony's did pick up more ambient noise that was passed on to the caller on the other line.

Bluetooth connectivity is better than any Bluetooth headphones I have owned prior in regards to sound quality. Having no wires while traveling, getting on and off planes, wow, never realized what I was missing.

Comfort - Bose win out here - they are more comfortable, they cover the entire hear, create less heat around your ears and less pressure on your head, ears, face and jaw. Sony's aren't bad from a comfort standpoint but Bose is a level above any other over the ear headphones I've tried.

Overall I would say you have to try the various headphones on the market as so much of what you will or won't like about a particular pair is subjective. For me, the sound quality, the features and noise canceling won the day for me. Bose fell flat on a sound quality and feature standpoint, I actually preferred my Beats to the Bose on sound quality. The sacrifice is on the comfort front, no one beats Bose. If you are looking for noise canceling and that's a key feature, as other reviews have said, Sony and Bose are the best. If overall sound quality trumps all else, there are a couple headphones on the market that perform better on sound quality but aren't in the same ballpark from a noise canceling standpoint. Generally wired and non noise canceling sound better. The Sony's seem to strike the best compromise for me on delivering everything I want in my noise canceling headphones that are primarily for travel.

I was upgrading my Bose QC15 and here are my thoughts after 5 weeks of nearly daily use (3-8 hours per day).

Noise cancellation: Sony WH1000XM2 wins. The difference is subtle at first, until you get to use Sony for at a few hours.

Comfort: QC15 wins hands down. I can tolerate Sony headset, but it is pretty uncomfortable (and hot). QC15 is pleasure to wear.

Sound quality: QC15 wins here. Sony has a bit better bass, but anything above else just sucks, plus that hiss... Which is very unfortunate.

(nitpick) Naming: I understand "QC15" "QC25"... etc, but wtf is "WH1000XM2", sony?

Summary: I am keeping my Sony for when I need the best noise cancellation. But will stick with QC15 for daily use.

I narrowed down my hunt to upgrade my exercise music experience to three higher end headphones and couldn't narrow it further so decided to get all three to find out in side by side comparisons which would be the best for me.

[1] Bose QuietComfort 35 (Series II) Wireless Headphones, Noise Cancelling ($349.00)

[2] Beats Studio3 Wireless Headphones ($298.99)

[3] Sony Noise Cancelling Headphones WH1000XM2: Over Ear Wireless Bluetooth ($348.00)

I put on the Beats and the heaviness and fit gave me the sense of an impending headache the instant I put them on. That, and the sound was empty and flat compared with either Sony or Bose. What was most surprising to me was they didn't have strong bass, which I had thought they were known for.

I put on the Sony and they were bigger but somewhat better fitting, not a lot lighter, but with more of a clear and full range from high to low.

I put on the Bose and it was surprisingly and significantly lighter and better fitting than either of the others and the sound was basically perfect. Good bass, full range of highs and lows. I have to admit that I had to switch back and forth between the Sony and the Bose about 10 times to determine if I *really* preferred the Bose to the Sony, and they were actually pretty darn close. The final point that won out for Bose was they were so much lighter and better fitting.

In addition to all of the above, as I've continued to use the Bose for 'everything' - I was most surprised when on a whim I decided to see if I could place a call with them; and my two initial callers both exlaimed that this was the BEST and clearest sound talking to me they had yet experienced (For years I've tried their patience through testing calls with 10-15 different best rated wired and wireless headpeices, ear buds et al). The rave reviews of the recipients of my calls carried from inside to outside walking the streets of NYC with all the usual sirens and traffic noise.

But most important of all, I can listen to my music in full head-filling gorgeous energizing glory when I'm exercising.

Sound Quality: Pretty good but not great. The WH1000XM2’s have quite a lot of coloration especially in the low to mid frequency range. At first it sounds punchy and full, but over time my ears became fatigued. The Bose QC35’s have a flatter frequency response that is very similar to my AKG K240’s. In fact the EQ settings I normally use for K240’s work with just some very slight tweeking for the QC35’s, but for the WH1000XM2’s I had to use completely different settings. But in the end the Sony’s just didn’t have good clarity and stereo seperation compared with the Bose.

Comfort: At first, the Sony’s seemed on par with the Bose, but after a while the headband started to hurt me on top of my head, and I found myself constantly adjusting them, and everytime I touched them I inadvertently caused the music to pause or rewind. I can wear the bose for hours on end and hardly feel them at all.

Battery Life: I haven’t had them long enough to comment on this, but others claim they can go days without being charged, and this is believable because the Bose can do that too.

Touch Controls: I hate it. Needs dedicated buttons so you don’t inadvertently pause or skip to the next song, but all you really wanted was to adjust them on your head.

Bluetooth (pairing): Out of four different devices, I only successfully paired them to one. They paired to my Galaxy S7 but would not pair to my ipad pro. I also failed to pair them with another galaxy phone and an Amazon Fire tablet. None of the devices could see the headphones on a normal bluetooth scan. The galaxy S7 was only able to pair when I switched on the near field (NFC) function. The Bose QC-35’s have a manual pairing function that makes pairing painless.

Bluetooth Range: Very good.

Noise Canceling: Very good. Just as good as the Bose as far as I can tell.

With a little work these phones could be as good (or better) than the Bose, but right now it’s just hype. I’m sending these back btw because of the pairing issue.

I like this headphone, however I returned it for two of the reasons below:
1. This device will shut down after 5 minutes of unused. Meaning that if you do not connect to any bluetooth device, this headphone will automatically shut down after 5 minutes. Why on earth would a Noise Canceling device have this feature without an option to turn it off? Who thinks it's a good idea to have this feature from the beginning? Even if you are connected to a device, it'll shut down if it's inactive for 5 minutes. So unless you are planning on listening to music 14 hours straight for your flight, then don't get this headphone. Why am I force to listen to music 14 hours straight just to use the ANC feature? Why can't I have quiet time? This is the reason why I bought this from the beginning.

2. The touch feature is nice on the right ear, however, anything can and will trigger this touch function. Let say you're laying down on the side, the pillow or chair will touch the right ear cup and will let ambient noises in. Seriously? we can unlock our phone using fingerprint and faces, yet Sony's Engineers can't create a touch function that will only register touch from fingers only?

Great sound, aesthetics, battery life, etc. but a couple issues in execution that prevent 4 or 5 stars.

USB Micro? Come on gang. Every time you release a product using legacy standards you have a chilling effect on adopting newer hotness. Used to not think the USB-C thing was a significant improvement, but its very nice not having to flip and fumble for that connection. Provide a cable for both USB-C to USB-C as well as a USB-A to USB-C; Since we're just using them for charging at standard USB rates, it doesn't have to be anything more than USB 2 or what-not. Literally no downside to USB-C for this kind of implementation. Or, better yet, QI maybe? Mmmmm... wireless charging... it's almost like someone willing to pay a couple hundred for premium wireless cans might be interested in wireless charging too... But for the love of all that is holy, don't use a proprietary connector (or inductive charging) like jaybird.

While we're talking about wireless and connectivity, what’s the deal with pushing the whole NFC connect? I love the forward-thinking interface, but the use-case is so small, and implementation so trouble ridden, it seems like it’s not adding any value. Yeah, conceptually it would be nice to use this instead of opening the Bluetooth connection options, but I'm usually switching between work-laptop, phone, and personal-laptop; while my phone has NFC, neither of the laptops have it, so that's kind of useless for 2/3s of my gear. Also, most people I know don't understand NFC, let alone bother enabling it on the devices that support it (my android stuff seems to default to NFC off; security risk maybe?). I suppose if they hardened the spec and everyone started using NFC for tap-to-pay then acceptance would pick up and more devices would have it, but considering Sony spun off their computers and their tablets don't even list NFC on their specs, it feels like a misguided feature that should have had the kids in marketing spend their UX thought elsewhere, like on the buttonless touch controls…

The capacitive stroking for volume and track changing is a neat trick and probably the right choice with regards to tech for physical control of the unit, but its unreliability and telegraphing make it a nuisance rather than an asset. Gotta reach up, place my hand around the can to reliably stroke the correct motion; it can take several strokes to get the motion right. Maybe put tactile guides for the finger to follow to increase reliability/consistency in motions, or, you know, maybe just a capacitive contact plate that I can feel and hold my finger on to send the same sort of signal. Less telegraphing of the finger and more consistency in sending the command (also looks less goofy than gently petting your headphones constantly).

Use similar contact plates for power-on and noise-cancel on/off settings. The current traditional buttons are too small to find easily and feel jankey when you push. Contact plates instead of a large stroke field seems like a win-win.

Finally! Connecting or powering-on the headphones causes the noise-cancelling (NC) to turn on. Considering that noise is usually not an issue and I value battery life over the NC, this is a genuine nuisance. I've already talked about the capacitive controls on the headphones increasing the complexity of interacting with the device, but continually reversing a setting I've enabled and turning on the NC every time I power-on or connect is NOT a value-add. I'm hoping there is a setting in the phone app that will allow me to disable NC on-at-connect or something (not going to hold my breath though).

Bottom line: My MDR-1RBTMK2's are more comfortable and have a more youthful aesthetic while these WH1000XM2's have a better sound stage, stay cooler on my head after hours of listening.

I think my MDR-1RBTMRK2's are still the cans to beat for wireless fidelity, battery-life and comfort but the WH1000XM2's are not bad by any means. Will keep one pair at home and one pair at work.

How they stack up against my other headphones:
- Grado 325 (best sound; literally painful to wear for long sessions; wired)
- Oppo PM3 (great++ sound that doesn't inflict 4d12 bludgeoning damage after 1d4 hours listening; wired)
- Sony MDR-1RBTMRK2 (great sound; great battery; comfort; wireless convenience is awesome)
- Sony WH1000XM2 (great+ sound; great battery; comfort+; wireless convenience is awesome; good noise cancelling; user interface struggles.)
- Audio-Technica ATH-A900X (great sound; heavy; poor aesthetics; wired)
- Jaybird x-3 (fair sound; good battery; super portable; fit can be tricky; proprietary charger is schwag)
- Jaybird x-2 (fair+ sound; fair battery; super portable; fit can be tricky; unreliable; break frequently; great while they last)
- Sony MDRV6 (good sound; sturdy; crazy-good value)
- Various other Jaybird products (freedom, bluebuds, JB-200) (passable sound, fragile, poor range, etc., use the x lineup)
- Sennheiser MM 400-X (passable sound, pathetic battery; worthless noise canceling; fragile; expensive; uncomfortable; The only headphones besides Apple's old ipod earbuds I've ever had an antagonistic relationship with; Only positive attribute is the built-in audio pass-through; I keep them just to remind me of why I love everything else)

one of my first reviews ever, so: Look it's a decent bit of kit but it does definitely have some drawbacks, i'll try and stick to pro's and cons. For reference I traded in my PXC 550's for this, I don't mind my PXC 550's but they where just a bit too quiet.

Pros:
- Noise cancelling and the hand over the headphone to hear others is great, I wish it would respond just a tiny bit faster, but otherwise good
- The sound signature/profile is pretty good, i have my doubts if they have any more clarity than say the PXC 550's, but the sound signature is way more my style (think more bass, flatter dynamics I would say but in this day and age of ultra compressed music it's not too noticeable, no high-pitched tinnyness)
- WAY more comfortable than the pxc 550's, especially for those of you like me with dumbo ears.
- excellent battery life, lasts forever, but...

Cons:
- The worst by far is this: Wifi is turned off when you plug it in for charging, COME ON SONY! How hard can it be to fix that? This is why i removed two stars, this is just unacceptable in this day and age, how bloody hard could it possibly be???
- When you turn up the volume or indeed do any sort of action, the noises to indicate for example you have reached max volume are way too long, there is no need for it to take up that much space to just tell me ive hit max volume, shorten this down.
- i occasionally get odd ear pains that I think have something to do with the noise cancellation, i didn't ever get this with the PXC 550's (to be fair, this may be due to the pxc 550's never forming a true seal around my ears since the pads on the pxc 550 where too small for my envy-of-elephants ears)

Shipping box and product box arrived unscathed and in great condition. Headphones themselves looked brand new, except for some potentially shoddy adhesive work near the joint where the headphones themselves can fold in on themselves (the glue work looked like something you'd expect from a child during arts and crafts). Despite the hefty price tag of these headphones, this aesthetic 'whoops' could have been overlooked if the product performed as expected. Unfortunately, the box did not include the airplane adapter and the audio input cord said to be included with the product. Most importantly, the item failed to pair with multiple Bluetooth devices. It is as if I was shipped a poorly refurbished and/or returned item cataloged as brand new. I was going back and forth on whether to purchases these versus the Bose equivalents, and I now am kicking myself for ever straying away from Bose to begin with. Luckily Amazon's and SquareTrade's customer support were both supportive in processing my full refund.

I really wanted to like these headphones.
I also own bose QC 25 and the 30
But considering that these the most expensive ANC BT option at the moment, they really aren’t worth the cost. Here is the problems:

- Touch control on the earcups are a gimmick and they are not practical. If you wear a hoodie or a coat with a hood you will have trouble using the earphones.

- most of the features of the app ar gimmicky - like the one that never works that should keep track of your position with the gps and change settings, it’s neevr accurate and just a mess. Or the altitude detection, what is that supposed to do? Or the silly haadx which is supposed to add frequencies to an mp3 to make it sound like a wave file... silly gimmicks.

- noise isolation is not as good as the bose QC. Part of the reason is that the earcups cannot seal at all if you have glasses

- when anc is on and you are not listening to anything, there is constant hiss. Bose don’t have this. It’s unacceptable!!

- there is a cracking noise coming randomly during playback, I had to make sure this was indeed from the headphones. I’m not sure if it’s because the headband is vibrating when the volume is high, as this headset is very prone to amplify physical vibrations and create artifact sounds out of it with the ANC chip

- sound is not very balanced, lack in the definition of bass and the bass is overall too present for acoustic music. I could live with that if the rest was on point, but those are not an audiophile earphones by any extent.

My bose broke twice in a row, their quality is not great either, so I wanted to find an alternative but Sony is not it. About to return them after 15 days of extended testing. Will get the bose again with a warranty since the QC35 break very easily but overall they have better reliability and sound.

I have sensitive hearing and the distortion makes it unenjoyable to use in instances in which I have to turn the volume up high like when I am mowing the lawn. Also, LDAC connectivity is also spotty at times. Overall they are great Headphones, with an awesome companion app but headphones at this price range should not distort at high volumes.
