I'm not an audiophile, and currently have one good headphones (AKG K701) that are not really portable and I use them mostly when working from home (sound leakage, open design). I am looking for polyvalent wireless headphones, mostly to listen while working 8h / day. Tried the Skullcandy Hesh 3 Wireless Headphone, Black (S6HTW-K033), the Sennheiser HD 4.40 Around Ear Bluetooth Wireless Headphones (HD 4.40 BT), the Sony Noise Cancelling Headphones WH1000XM2: Over Ear Wireless Bluetooth Headphones with Case - Gold and the Bose QC35II. Did compare them on various musics, rock, pop, classic, ... .

Bottom line: The only one I kept are the Hesh 3! Not for myself as I felt the comfort was not great (too tight / clamping pressure, burning ears after 1h listening), but for commute / smaller listening periods (i.e not full workday), they are great. Bluetooth is stable, sound quality is good. I'll keep looking for a comfy work-polyvalent headphones, probably give up the bluetooth criteria as I'm disappointed by the sound quality of the Sony & the Bose, and I'm not ready to put 350$ for 100$ audio quality level.

Sound quality:
Sony and the Bose are OK, but that's it, just OK, not great and not what I expect from 350$ headphones.
Hesh3 have well defined bass (not too boomy, just what's needed to make it a fun headphones to listen to). Very good spatialization. Grabbed them at 80$ on black friday, and for my uneducated ears, they compare more to the Sony & the Bose than with my AKG K701 (not in the same category :-)). TBH, the sony & bose are a bit more clear than the Hesh3, but ... I feel the Hesh3 are more "fun" and would be my choice here.
The clear looser here are the Sennheiser. They are disqualified from this review. Stay away from them, my 10y-old 15$ Koss are better. No spatialization, bad for rock, for pop, for classic... Might do for techno / podcasts.

Build / comfort:
Hesh 3 feels a bit plastic like at opening, but you quickly forget it. Comfort is so-so, you definitely feel them more than Sony & Bose. More clamping pressure, lower quality ear pads.
Sony feels good and are probably the winner, I'm just a bit worried about the touch control thingy, what happens after the warranty expires ? Do you pay 200$ for repair if this stop working or bug ?
Bose earpads feel less durable, BUT, they are the comfort winner. If you have money and want to buy a light, comfy headphones, go for it. Sony are the 2nd best in these models.

Bluetooth:
Hesh3: all good.
Sony: I sent them back because... they kept jumping on my macbook. If I looked left or right, the sound will jump. If I walk 2 meter away from the laptop, it will jump. Worked good with my iPhone, but ... it's the only BT headphones I tried that was disqualified because of this. Not acceptable for this price range.
Bose: did try them only 30min, but they seemed good.

Sound leakage / isolation:
Hesh3: no active noise cancellation, but cost 5 time less than the competition. I don't need that much noise cancellation and what they provide is enough to work in a open space, very little sound leakage.
Sony / Bose: amazing. You put them on, and feel isolated from a lot of background noise. If you're looking for peaceful commute, they are worth it. The mic from the Sony did seems to pick less background noise in the few calls I tried.

I have pained over the reviews to look for clues to see which unit I should purchase. I compared these to the Bose in a big box store with the same ambient noise and they were better than the Bose for noise cancellation. I use the headphones on airplanes for noise cancellation, with and --here is the key -- often without music playing. These phones turn off after five minutes if they are not connected to a device. That is a spectacular feature [I am trying to be positive this year]. The engineers at SONY need to take a course in reality. I also had trouble with one of the speakers on phone. I have returned the device. Back to the drawing board.

turns off after 5 min if there is no Bluetooth. according to sony it is for power saving, and that's it. can't use it just as noise canceling, unless you drain your phone power, or have a wire connected to it. Sony refuses to acknowledge or offer a solution.
the noise canceling and sound quality are very good,but since I bought it, I mainly use my old headphones because the foam is tight on my ears. If I had small ears and (I think they are average), and there was a way just to use the noise canceling, I would had given a better score. If I want to sleep in a noisy place, I have to stick in a headphone cord to prevent the automated shutdown. Pretty lame for a $350 set.

Quality Is not what they said at all.
Just so you can have an idea, AirPods sound better!
Only positive thing I can’t denie Is isolation.

These shut off automatically unless they are connected to a device by bluetooth or have a cord plugged in. This is the most idiotic design imaginable. Can't connect to your phone or computer during taxiing, takeoff, landing, etc.? Hahahaha, every five minutes it says "powering off" and shuts down. Then it's loud time for you until you turn them back on. THEY SHUT OFF EVERY FIVE MINUTES. Whose idea was that??? Flying and just want noise canceling and don't want bluetooth on or put a plug in? Too bad. THEY SHUT OFF EVERY FIVE MINUTES.

Apparently the work around is to stick a plug in the plug hole but I have a better idea -- Don't have idiots who never fly design your noise canceling headphones that are idealized for flying. Outrageous.

I'm not sure whether I'll return them or just get a little plug and resent the designers every time I fly. No bueno.

That said, the sound is good.

I changed the review from 1 to 4 stars
Despite the very annoying bug below, where headphones shut off every 5 minutes (unless you have an active connection)
the noise cancellation is amazing. Much better than Bose qc35. I tested both, and Sony has much better
You have to experience the noise cancellation on these to really understand how good it is. Go from a noisy background to tranquility when you put them on. The best on the market, but let down by the bug (see below), and poor quality app.

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Headphones automatically shut off every 5 minutes. So can’t easily be used just for noise cancelling

There are 2 work arounds for this
1) Have it connected via blue tooth to a cell. (not practical as you need to dedicate a cell phone , with a blue tooth connection to each head set)
2) Plug in a dummy wireless jack and have a dangling cord (this is not practical when you are using the headphones in bed, to help you sleep)

This is such a stupid feature, that could so easily have been fixed
It is a deal breaker, if you just want a pair of headphones for noise cancelling.

So, I am going to give it 1 out of 5 as a protest.
Sorry Sony, but these headphones are sold as "the best noise cancelling headphones on the market"
But turn themselves off every 5 minutes"
this is not sony WH1000XM2 headphone false advertisement please do something about it i got sony MDR1000x this is not good the box is wh1000xm2 but the item inside is MDR1000x this un acceptable
Too difficult and awkward to operate. Functions delay. Not comfortable. Material is made cheaply.

I ended up returning these immediately. They smell like formaldehyde and would need some serious time to offgas (gross), but worse, they just didn't sound good. Maybe I was naive in thinking that super pricey bluetooth headphones would sound as good as my corded Sennheiser noise cancelling ones, but they don't. The noise cancelling function makes the audio sound thin and weak, and the "ambient" function just adds some weird noise on top of that. Unimaginable for the cost.

Well good sound.
But it keeps adapting to my environment so often and cuts the music so many times I damn really HATE that feature.

mic its terrible, don't use it for calls.
after use it gets hot.
bluetooth connectivity lost after a while.
noise canceling not good as advice
poor and cheap material

Was Decent And 3 Stars Is Just Me Being Generous, They Don't Get That Loud And There Are A Lot Of Headphones That Have A Lot Of More Bass And/Or Clarity Even When You Play Around With The Features Even The Parrot Zik 2.0 Does A Lot Better With All The Features They Share In Common Like Noise Cancelling, Apps, Treble, Bass, highs miss and lows, and have better sound quality. I've Had These Since November And I Regret The Purchase Only Reason These Are The Go To Cause I'm Not Spending Anymore Money On Headphones There Durable And Expensive And Decent With Sound And With Ambient Sound 4year Warranty To Back Me Up With Anything. I Just Expected A Lot Better In The Main Departments Of Bluetooth Headphones With The Features That They Have.

This is one of the worst designed and most buggy products I've bought in a long time. The noise cancellation was great--for 2-3 minutes at a time. After that, it would cheefully inform me that "noise cancellation is off", and then act like a pair of regular, dumb headphones. I should say "exceptionally uncomfortable headphones". No matter how I adjusted the tensioning, the top of the band pressed paiinfully into my head. I had to put a folded washcloth between me and the headphones to make them (barely) comfortable. After an hour of repeated rebootings, I gave up and put the headphones back in their nice case, ready to return for a refund. The woman next to me on the plane had some Bose headphones, which she let me try. They were much more comfortable. My advice: skip the Sony, and go directly to Bose.
for the price very dissapointed

This is ridiculous this will not pair the software do you have to download from another site and I can’t even find it why do you have to make it so difficult iPad headphones or including Sony ones that hasn’t been this difficult
Don't work I'm very very mad
Bass lacks, headband cracks
too expensive

LITERALLY got here in less than 24 hours with free Prime shipping, though I have no idea how, as I live WAY out in the boondocks! Either way, I was stoked to see them arrive, as they have amazing noice-cancellation features! Not nearly as comfortable as my old Bose QuietComfort 15s, but the noice-canceling is way better and the sound is almost comparable. I think I need to deepen the bass a little on my app settings, but so far I love these headphones, and am looking forward to using them on some long distance flights coming up soon. Loving the touch pad controls as well!

Some said this one didn't beat the Bose QC35 and the fancy features were gimmicks. They were soooo wrong. I love the navigation and volume control gestures on the right ear cup. Brilliant design! Noise cancelling is stellar and sound quality is terrific. I am very satisfied. Pairing to my HP laptop and Samsung Galaxy Note 8 is a breeze. Havn't figured out the NFC pairing thing yet.

These ROCK, good everything...Better than QC35, Bass is solid, almost as good as Bose, but I love everything else...as well as Longer battery life, Vol Controls are awesome gesture driven by swiping on Right Earcup surface. Lots of refinements, voice prompts a bit obnoxious. and once you get to know the button placement... As there is different modes of Sound Cancelling that are overkill, but I can see their point. You know Sony tries so hard...and these are Solid and Better than their predecessors by a long shot. Comfortable, as the earcups are a bit bigger for Big Elephant Ears....

I am obsessed with these. They cancel so much noise, sound beautiful, and look very cool. They are pretty heavy and relatively large though. Not really an outfit addition, but that didn't matter to me. I use them to commute and block out people talking at work. They make commuting bearable and they work great. I love the feature that temporarily dims your music and boosts ambient noise. It makes it so easy to talk to people without pausing and taking off my headphones. I tried the newest Beats and Bose and other popular leading headphones, and they didn't match the noise cancelling and sound quality of the new Sonys.

I had been looking for a good headphones for long-term use. I am not a sound engineer but I used many headphones, from cheap ones to premium ones I have experience with headphones. First of all this headphone is definitely awesome, noise canceling works like a magic and sound quality is very good, I love the Headphones app as it gives you chance to have more control over it (I like changing the VPT so much!). Many people choose Bose because they say this headphones makes their ears sweat afterwhile, bro when I read that I said okay I am buying this, IT IS A FEATURE IN CANADA, Thanks to this headphone I do not even use ear muffs outside ( Even at home, it does not disturb me until I use it for 2 hours)

PROS:
Noise cancelling
Materials, Comfort
Keeps your ears warm (I live in Canada) :D
Sound quality
Battery life
CONS:
Warms up your ears ( Applies if you live in Texas) :)

Ordered these headphone sometime in December. Best headphones ive ever had. I purchased these because i had a pair of the beat Solos and was sorely dissapointed, heart broken actually, that the Cushions started coming off, and the Bluetooth connection stopped working all within 6 months, they also stopped accepting a charge. I could only use them with an AUX cord. For the "Beat Solos" to be as expensive as they were they should not have had that problem. So i chose to spend my money and put my trust in these Sony headphones instead. definitely glad i did. ill never go back to "beats". So far havent had any problems with the band cracking on these but if i do i will update this review. and i use them almost everyday.

I was so undecided as to which headphones to buy. So I bought both. The reviews were so good on both of them.

I listened both, side-to-side, for eight hours. This is what I found.

Sound quality:
Sony: Very bassey, almost too much on some songs. I believe this is because of the Hifi setting in the app for high definition songs. The nicest thing as far as musically, the music sounds more lyrical. Now keep in mind, I’m coming from regular Apple headphones. However, being a musician — there was a certain musicality to the Sonys.

Bose: The Bose was very balanced, unfortunately too much where everything sounded generic. It was well kept within a neutral line, and never dipped below or above it. It kind ruined the music of some pieces.

Comfort. Both legitimately were comfortable. They fit both of my ears fine.

The biggest thing beside the sound being better, I actually like the “gimmicks”, of the app and the head piece. It made the headphones a little bit more tech, and less just a headphones.

So if you’re on the fence, pick these up.

Unless you’re more attuned to higher trebles in singing, and neutral sounds, then get the Bose. However if you want the headphones to have lyrical sounds, then the Sony.

You’ll enjoy them.

I love the unit. It has great sound in my opinion and I never have had an issues so far (1 month). I enjoy the app and the features. They're very intuitive. I use it for making phone calls and no one has had a problem with hearing me. If I did it all over again I'd get this unit. I'm very pleased and impressed.

I’m very impressed by these headphones. I’m a novice audiophile coming from using open air Grados for years. Noise reduction in flight is remarkable - even without music, cabin racket turns into a faint, white noise. More quiet than even wearing ear plugs - it’s kind of surreal. I always used buds for music on planes, which got me by, to a point I could hear the music. But with these it is possible to appreciate subtleties of what’s playing. Even in a quiet office setting, it’s amazing how much background drone these can cut out, which really brings the music out. Battery life is great as well. Sony claims 20ish hours - I have surpassed that by a few hours on every charge so far. In a very quiet setting, I’ll still give the sound quality to any set of Grados. But if you’re looking for serious noise cancellation and great fidelity, I can’t imagine you can do better at this price point.

The best headphone I've ever bought and even better noise canceling than my Bose QC 25. I have compared this cans and Bose QC 35 at BestBuy and fell in love at first try. Sound wise Sony is better than Bose, not too mention it has adaptive noise canceling. I know $300+ is not cheap but you get premium quality and one of the best around. The battery can power up to 25 hours and no need to charge more than a week.
I have several cans range from AT, Bose, Phillips, AKG and Beats and this Sony is the best I have.

I can't fully utilize all the features because the application for Android never detects that the headphones are connected via Bluetooth. Tried both NFC and manual connections.

In terms of sound, I can't tell much difference between this and the Bose. Unless the app is updated soon these are likely going back.

I bought these mainly for use in an very large office space where it can get quite loud, and the low frequency droning noise of the aircon buzzing in my ears annoys me to no end.

Coming in knowing it won’t get rid of a lot of the voices, I was rather surprised it drowned it out quite well, to be degree of voices of people talking loudly a desk away from me sounds distant. It amazed me how putting the headphones on, the noise of the aircon literally disappeared, couldn’t help but whisper “wow...” under my breath.

With noise cancelling on, I have music gently pumping away to just further get rid of whatever higher frequency noises the headphones forgivabley let slip by, and it’s blissful.

Fast charging is ridiculously fast on this thing and it typically lasts me up to a week of use at work for a 9-5 job where I will probably use it for 2-3 hours total throughout the work day, and another hour or two at home, music playing from my iPhone.

Clarity of audio is decent, don’t expect pumping heavy, brassy audio from these, as they’re not meant for audiophiles, however, they still manage to pack a punch, and the EQ settings from the official app allows for some finer tuning to your liking (I sometimes use the extra bass preset, works well).

Comfort wise, after an hour of use, I do find it a bit uncomfortable on my ears, mainly because my ears stick out very slightly, but it’s not as bad as other headphones I’ve tried. No pressure find on top of my head.

Bluetooth is strong and works at quite a decent distance.

5/5, surprised at effectiveness. Recommended to my colleague who bought his the week I got mine.

These headphones have above average sound, amazing noise canceling, and are super comfortable... except for the fact that they warm up my ears very quickly. After about 30 minutes, my ears would be burning and bright red. It would take several hours for the sensation to go away. I think this is because the earpads don't provide for much breathing room, or maybe the material just didn't agree with my skin. If it weren't for this issue, these headphones would be 5 stars. Ultimately, I had to return them because it just wasnt possible to wear them for longer periods, my ears would get too warm.

Definitely a fantastic pair of headphones. The noise cancelling is ridiculous as I remember back in the 90's when noise cancelling had a buzz in the background. With these there's just a beep and suddenly everything goes quiet. It's pretty unnerving the first few times you do it, but having the option for ambient sound is amazing when walking through the city. The quick attention mode is great too to catch announcements on intercoms and such.

There are some annoying things about the headphone, but they are definitely not Sony's fault and more Android's fault. Android 8.0 / 8.1 have some bluetooth issues where using any codec other than SBC completely borks the mic making the headphones useless for taking calls or using assistant. I'm going to pretend I can tell the difference between SBC and LDAC so I would recommend you use that on any Android 8.0+ devices. That being said for me those were minor cases because the mic is not great as it picks up everything and the point of these are for listening to music anyways.

The noise headphones works pretty much as expected. Is easy to pair, the app communicated with the headphones flawlessly. The noise-cancelling aspect works well with certain kind of noises (e.g. wind noise, fan noise, AC noise etc) but not so well with human talking. When wearing headphone, it does look fatter than say Bose QC 35, which might make you look ridiculous in public places. Battery life is really excellent and when use somewhat sparingly, simply refuses to die. However, I do notice that the top of the headphone has some paint chipped off from day 1 even though I did not mishandle it (picture attached). It doesn't affect the performance of the headphone though but just looks annoying.

I got these after checking out an older pair at Costco and reading the reviews. I have several headphones now (I think I’m turning into a collector). These sound pretty good and love the ability of using the EQ in the app to customize what I’m listening to. So far so good!

Noise cancelling is excellent... wish they got a bit louder, but will suffice.

Update 4/1/18: Well, apparently the thing about "breaking in" headphones is true, the sound on these things have really opened up a bit.. and they are incredible sounding... I have tried many different genres of music as my taste is eclectic. Color me impressed.. the sound separation in musical instruments is amazing.

Very expensive, but you get what you pay for. These are incredible headphones. As a college student it is often that I pull these out of my backpack and enter into beautiful silent study. They cut out a very large amount of outside noise. They excel at blocking out ambient noises like fans, and other background noise, but they also reduce other sounds significantly like talking. These have been priceless for me. I can focus literally anywhere by putting these on. They work very well even when I'm not listening to music, and just using them to block outside noise. But when I turn on some soft classical music and zone in on my homework, I feel completely isolated and can't hear a thing around me. It hurt me to spend so much on these headphones ( I paid full price, $400), but I would buy them again and again. They have been an extraordinary investment.

I had a previous pare of Sony noise cancelling headphones and these by far are superior. On an airplane these can cancel almost 100% of the ambient noise. They are also comfortable enough to sleep in during the flight. Unlike my other Bluetooth headphones these never lose the signal, stays strong any distance in my house. I highly recommend these!

I've been a user of high end Sony in-ear headphones for the better part of a decade, and held off on noise canceling because I suffered from that weird feeling when it was on. Bose were also the choice for the longest time, and I never really liked the sound of them compared to non-bass boost Sony products. So that's where I'm coming from.

Recently I got some Apple AirPods for running, though, and just loved the freedom from wires. After catching my headphone cords on something I asked why I wasn't going bluetooth for my "nice" headphones.

I ended up going with these because they'd received great reviews from audio experts and it seemed like noise canceling had come a long way.

In actual experience...
- Sound quality is great. Way better than my in-ear Sonys. I didn't expect that.
- Noise canceling still bugged me at first, but I got used to it, and on balance I now really like it. I knocks down so much ambient garbage. I would kid myself on airplanes that the earbuds did a good enough job, but they don't. Not even close. These are great.
- Bluetooth is very strong. I sometimes forget my iPhone X on the desk and can walk across the house without a problem.
- Touch controls are actually great. I was a little worried about them, but they are easy to use once you get it.
- Battery life is great. Occasionally I'll think to charge them and have never run out.
- Case is really nice.
- Included cable works well if you end up needing it.

One complaint... The ear pads are a little too small, so my ear ends up touching the foam covering the driver. This makes them uncomfortable for long periods. I've seen online that you can actually use replacement Bose ear pads to bump them off your ears, and have taken them apart with a collar stay to see how to do it, which is very easy. So it's possible I'll make that upgrade, though I'm reluctant, because the replacement pads are kinda ugly. Oh well.

But overall, I'm really happy with these, despite the fact that they're so stinkin' expensive.

Premium headphones in look and build quality. When I put these on, the outside world is silent. Different listening modes means you will enjoy all of your music like new again. The headphones feel comfortable. The touch controls are intuitive and an added bonus for tech junkies. Wow, get these. Life is short, listen to music.

Most comfortable thing I have ever put on my head. Turn it on and it connects quickly, the noise cancelling immediately cutting in and transferring you to another world. Sound quality is stellar. These headphones are so good that it makes it hard to put anything else of lesser quality, basically every other product in existence, on you head or in your ears. After using these, you do get kind of spoiled. The touch features for pausing, calls, volume, and next and previous are easy to use, definitely a plus to not have to pull your phone out to make these kinds of adjustments. The rose gold color also looks amazing, far better than any other headphones around the office.

This is a pair of amazing headphones.
- I absolutely love the sound and noise cancellation. Helps to listen to what I like isolating myself from noisy surroundings.
- Long lasting battery charge, which is very important when you have wireless headphones.
- Very stylish and elegant.
- Super comfortable.
- Not the best for calls, though. But I don’t care. These headphones are for listening, not for talking!

My ear is a little pain, and this get harder to bear after 2-3hours. So pain. I wear glasses and I feel headache after like 2-3 hours. Noice cancelling function is great, but this cannot connect to my mbp. The gesture controlling is not good on my phone....

Great pair of headsets, but I have bumped an arm or hand (and one point someone tapped on my right headphone) which pretty much skipped my audio book ahead a few chapters. I really wish the app would allow you to disable some of the control points on the headphone. I truly only need to pause and play. Vol up/down and skip fwd/back is not a necessity I need to have.

Love the EQ options and available when the headset is connected to a phone, but when you connect it to the kindle fire.. there is no sony headphone app equivalent in the kindle app store. Which brings up that one kick-in-the-nuts that the Bose competing headset has over this one, in which it can connect to two devices at the same time.

On the plus, I'm loving the option of ambient sound. I believe this is exclusive to only Sony compared to Bose as their equivalent only has an option of high/low/off for noise control. All and All, I think this comparison would be split upon personal preferences and use environments.

I have yet to see if the hands free options for noise control when standing, walking, in motion, and running {running is not an option for this headset} works when you're connected to a device without GPS, but I'm sure you will lose this feature on a device without GPS (like my kindle fire). So without the dual device connection, the app is pretty much useless when connected to devices without the app support.

Without owning the equivalent headset, this is my review thus far. I think Sony has taken a big swing at a lot of options, but the smaller issues are starting to annoy me to a point in which one day I may not be ok with saying this is acceptable for a $300 pair of headphones while the bigger advantages go unused because my preferred listening device is not a GPS enabled phone and is not a device that has the sony headphone app to support it.

Without the highs, I'm left with normal and irritating lows in which I might look to either buy a lower priced version with the same options I do use, or look for something that fits a bit tighter to my lifestyle right now at or near the same quality. For now, it feels like I bought a Ferrari, but all the streets in my city has random pot holes with a max speed limit of 55 mph.

What I like:
Great noise canceling
Great sound
The app for Android, and the equalizer
The "swipe" interface for volume, pause, etc
Battery life
Cupping your right ear makes the headphones seem to disappear

What I don't like
Must be connected to an audio source or else noise canceling turns off after 5 minutes or so

I'd definitely buy these again.

Perfect design&Perfect noise cancelling technology&Very good sound with perfect base. It may not make you feel as comfortable as QC35 but the hand gestures and the base part will pay you back. Just a little bit complain about the app design. Other than that, perfect!

I've been using these for several hours now and so far i am very satisfied with my purchase. I did a lot of research and decided on these over the Bose QC35 and i believe i made the right choice. My co-worker has the Bose and i wasn't all that impressed with the sound, their volume seemed really low even when it was all the way up, but they are lighter and it could be argued, more comfortable than these.

These headphones offer great noise cancellation and amazing sound. I listen mainly to instrumental music like original scores and even my previous audiotechnica headphones which i thought were very good (for the price anyway, no comparison here) fell short in reproducing clear sound in certain notes. These so far have mastered every single note. The sound is loud and clear always.

My previous headphones weren't wireless or noise cancelling, so these are an upgrade for me and while they are not as lightweight as the Bose i have no complaints in regards to comfort; they certainly feel very comfortable to me. I think the app that comes with them could be improved and the software all together could be made easier to manage, but i do use it and it works fine for me, it just seems a bit more complicated than it probably should be.

The headphones also seem very sturdy and i haven't heard any cracking sound or any sound coming from them when i move as some people were reporting. They feel so well built that i seriously doubt i will have any problems with any cracking, but we'll see.

I bought these from Amazon.com and have am thrilled with the sound quality, active noise cancellation, and comfort. The battery life is excellent.

Things you should know: Your phone or digital device must support AptX HD or LDAC in order for you to experience the sound quality that these are capable of while in Bluetooth mode. SBC is a lossy connection standard and the sound quality is noticeably poorer in this mode. This will be true for any high-end Bluetooth headphone. So you're wasting your money if your music source can't support better codecs. LDAC is built into Android Oreo (8.1.0). Related to this issue, some features in the application are only available when the phones are connected using SBC, which means if you want the equalizer, sound stage, or sound location features, you need to sacrifice the overall quality. Fortunately these are mostly useless features, so I just leave the connection in LDAC.

You can't disable the gesture feature on the right can, which can be irritating. You will unintentionally lower or raise volume, skip songs, etc. if you play with your headphones at all. There should be a button on the device to disable or enable gestures. For an expensive set of headphones, I would expect this feature to be there. That being said, the gestures are very convenient while traveling.

The charging cable is micro-USB and isn't very fast. Instead of a charge full indicator (e.g., a green light), the red light simply turns off. I would expect a better system for this given the quality of this device. I would expect a type-C connector with much faster charging.

All that said, I recommend these headphones. With LDAC support, the sound quality is outstanding for a wireless pair of phones. I took these on multiple train rides and flights and these phones blocked out most of the ambient noise. I also worked in a coffee shop for hours on end and these phones blocked out groups of teenagers and kids playing around. I've heard the ANC isn't as good as the Bose QC 35 II, but I find the level of noise cancellation more than sufficient.

It's nice comfortable noise cancelling headphone and I love it. It's a little heavy as it has an incredible battery life. But after I spend 3 days to get used to it, I can enjoy my music for like 20 hours and rarely feel it now.
I have to say it still have a little flaw that most reviews I read didn't mention. That's it's gonna be a little like electrical noise sound after I've listen for about 20 hours. It did bother me for a few minutes, but it disappeared after I charged it. I will update this review if I find more problems.

Amazon likes to fiddle with the price on these. I gave $348 and then soon after they dropped them to $298. Looks like they're back up to $348 now. They're pretty nice headphones and the noise canceling works very well. The office can be really loud with several conversations going on and I can put these on and put on some gentle music and all of their troubles disappear.

The sound quality is really nice, and I love the touch interface. It works very well.

I'm still a little concerned about the possible breakage but so far they've held up for four months of regular use. They are a little slippery and could probably stand to be a little tighter fitting, but adjusting them back to where they belong is easy enough. I will also mention I have a relatively narrow shaped head, so people with a larger head probably won't have a problem.

I belive this headfone should be ine of the best in the market. The sound quality is impressive, the features really works well and do what they promise. The active noise canceling does an amazing job without giving you any kind of headaches or any sizzles. Of course is an expensive toy but for those who are looking for the newest in technology's this is the option. The case and the finish are premium quality. Now, I expect sony could do this awesome job in a wateresistance device. I don't know if this is possible due to the mics which must capture the noises to cancel those but if could, woulb be amazing to wear it in rainy days.

It is a great head phone. It is comparable to the other brand with well recognized for noise cancelling head phone. I like the case and the wire jack more than the other brand. The case a soft separator between ear cups to prevent scratch. The head phone use standard 3.5mm for wire input while the other brand use 2.5mm.
I subtract one star because of the touch control. I do like the cover the right ear cup to temporary stop noise cancelling function. I have problem with Volume up and forward track. The head phone mis-interpret a few times.

Comparing to the Bose QC Series I have, this is OK. The plus on this is the iOS app having the ability to adjust the noise cancellation and calibrate it. It can be used both as a wireless or wired headphone. Listening to normal music was good, such as adult contemporary. However, when listening to classical music, piano music, or instrumental music, there is a variation of static sound when it hit a particular pitch. It is quite annoying when you are trying to listen to calm music. But if the purchase is to listen to current modern rock or hip-hop, this does an ok job.

I tested out the bose 35i and the beats and the Sony headphones are so much better. Though these are a bit heavier than the bose, they are just as comfortable and superior to the beats in comfort. I wear glasses and they still give me a great fit even after hours.

The app is great too. It adjusts the noise canceling features based my movement.

These are some great headphones!

I don't travel all that often, so I mainly use these at work and in coffee shops. It completely blocks out the sound and I often forget people are around. The only time I can hear some sounds is when the I'm in between tracks. When listening to podcasts it feels like you're out in the audience listening. i often close my eyes to complete the experience.

These are very comfortable for me. I have small ears that fit perfectly inside the cups. I read in reviews that it can get uncomfortable for people with bigger ears. Will definitely use these on my airplane ride back home!

Sound quality is amazing for Bluetooth. The app. allows for further customization of the sound. Bose still has the edge for clarity, but Sony is better balanced and reproduces a more accurate sound. It also handles some genres (pop, rap, rock) better than Bose. Hands off to Sony for a great product.

I listen to a lot of classical music and found the sound quality of these headphones much superior to Bose, which is just not crisp enough. But after a transatlantic flight, even though the sound cancellation was great, my ears felt sore, so I gave them to my daughter, who has smaller ears. The headpiece also felt uncomfortable. It could use some padding. I'll probably buy them again because the sound was that good, but I'll have to limit how long I wear them.

I'm not going to go into any detail, but these headphones are awesome. It is a whole new world with them on. Recent trip back to Ohio and it was quiet and peaceful. On one leg of the flight apparently the plane was having some major scary difficulties and I didn't even know it because I'm in my own little world with these babies on. Plane lands and everyone is clapping and I'm like what happened...Bottom line, you are going to love these. Read all the technical reviews you want, but these are just excellent.

bought a Bose 35; very nice and my wife loved it. I decided to buy Sony based on some of the reviews. It was a great decision. Don't get me wrong; the Bose is very nice too. I would say that Bose has a bit better comfort for extended time say 3+ hours. However, Sony has better features and both sounds great.

The Really, Really Good

I've never owned such an expensive pair of headphones before, so understand that my opinion may be not fully credible. However here is what I have found. The audio quality is on another level compared to what I am used to. It's like not only is everything so clear and vivid. But (assuming the audio file isn't a bad one) I can also tell where the individual instruments would be playing if I were standing in the recording room. To experience this, listen to Give It One by Maynard Ferguson that track blew my socks off. The noise canceling is also pretty impressive, although I don't have much comparison as I've never owned a pair of active noise canceling headphones. It seems to me that it'll block out most noises below a certain volume threshold. So like I can still hear this ridiculously loud vacuum we have (you have no idea how loud this vacuum is though), or the blender when standing right next to it. Even then, those things weren't more noticeable than the music I was listening to, so it seems to do its job almost perfectly.

The Bad

There actually aren't any huge complaints, but the reason it doesn't get a perfect score is because it does have some flaws that I think really do need to be improved upon (only 2 to be exact though). The first one is that my ears get really hot after wearing them for a bit over an hour or two. So much so that I feel compelled to take them off for a minute or two just because the heat is pretty unbearable. The second is that it creaks every now and then when you stretch out the headband even a little. The second isn't even really a huge complaint I guess, because I don't think (and really hope) that Sony would make sure that the headband doesn't end up breaking.

Summary

Audio quality is next level compared to what I am used to and the noise canceling executes its job to the best of its ability. In future generations, I would obviously like to see even better audio quality and noise canceling (as hard as that may be) as well as an environment where it feels like my ears aren't being dipped in molten lava after just an hour or two (exaggeration, but they do get really hot for real). I highly recommend these, and honestly still can't decide if I am being too harsh in giving this a 4-star review. Most people either give this a 4 or 5-star review I assume and those that don't either had a really bad experience for some external factor or are out of their mind.

Great earbuds that I have been using now for 5-6 years. This is my 4th or 5th pair of these headphones. I constantly lose or break my headphones from daily use and bringing them to the gym. I have found that these are a great cheap pair of headphones that sound good for most daily listening. They do not block out any noise, but they play music very clearly and without any distortion. They do not fall out of my ears at all while running.

The different color styles are a nice added bonus.

Prior to this, I purchased the Sony MDR-E828LP Fontopia Earbuds for use with a small mp3 player I use while weightlifting. They were cheap and had good enough sound that I purchased them on numerous occasions over the years as each pair eventually became destroyed by sweat. I was disappointed to find that they were discontinued and purchased these ear buds with the expectation that they would be "pretty much the same". They're not, they have no discernable base sound. That may be fine if your using these to watch TV through a device or prefer "the transistor radio sound" but for my needs they are useless. Now I suppose I'll have to dredge through many pages and reviews to find something that suits my requirements (cheap, decent volume, reasonable sound).

EDIT: Based upon another review of these earbuds with a similar perspective to mine, I purchased the Edifier H180 earbuds. A little more expensive but much better sound IMO.

I bought these 2 years ago after my first pair from purchased from Walmart probably 5+ years ago now bit the dust. I hate the headphones that go in the ear and I dislike the look of headphones that go over the ear. These are the only headphones I'll tolerate but stores no longer sell them. Thank you amazon! These have a 90 degree angle at the headphone jack which means I don't end up with exposed wires or sound in just one ear quite so fast. The first pair lasted me all of high school although I wasn't using them daily. The next pair has lasted me 2 years of daily use in college and now are in my pocket all day everyday at work. Which is how they ended up going through the washer and dryer. Twice. 2 years later, these still work great, no exposed wires and the only reason i'm replacing them is because I was careless and after the second wash and dry cycle, the sound on the right side occasionally goes out. My bad. Today I'll be purchasing my 3rd and 4th pairs and I will continue to purchase as long as these continue to be made.

These headphones are very person specific, they fit me perfectly fine and the sound quality was pretty good. My girlfriend however was a different story. After attempting to use the headphones multiple times I was repeatedly told that they were falling out of her ears and the bass quality isn't very good. They are also shorter than the previous Sony design which makes them ride "strangely" in your ear canal and make them more difficult to take out of your ear quickly without losing your grasp on them.

Coming from someone who doesn't deal with super heavy bass music I thought the headphones performed quite well for the price. However if you're looking for headphones with supreme audio and very heavy bass you might want to look elsewhere. For the price however they are well constructed and would be a good fit to any ipod, mp3 player, or even cell phone because they are compact and can go anywhere. The overall cable design is well done, and it easily provides enough length to run up your shirt or hoodie if you desire your headphones to be discreet. Are they going to be for listening to music for hours on end with supreme quality? No, probably not, but will they get the job done? Sure. If you're looking for cheap head phones with a custom color then these will probably suit you.

These are definitely a hit or miss type of earbuds. I had a pair of these for about 4 years until I dropped them while on a run and the buds fell off entirely. They fit my ears so well that I just bought another pair. Although, a lot of my friends who have used these have often told me they don't fit their ears very well. My ears tend to not fit the general earbud size, so these fit mine very nicely. But if your ears often fit the stick-in earbuds (like the ones SkullCandy sells), these probably will not fit as well. If your ears are like mine and can't keep those earbuds in generally, these will fit nicely.

My love for these ear buds is a true love. I have been buying these exact ear buds for years now. The first time, I bought them because the ear buds that came with my iPod Classic died and I wanted something affordable but good quality. I bought them for about $10 at some local store and fell in love. They have a great length to them and are long lasting. Honestly, the reason why I've bought so many of these over the years isn't that they break - it's because I end up losing them on public transportation or among my collection of things. This style of headphones has lasted with me over the years and I know that the moment I lose (not break) the ones I currentlly have, I'll buy another pair.

Pros:
- Long cord that makes it easy for you to comfortably place your phone in your front or back pocket while listening to music. Also - great length for when you want to rest your phone on the treadmill stand while running.
- Durable - can handle more abuse than any product should be able to withstand.
- Decent sound quality. I'm no audiophile - I just want to be able to hear my music. It plays classical well enough to hear the flutes and it's decent for when you have a lot of bass.
- Price - for 10 bucks or less you can't go wrong.
- Portable - small headphones that are easy to keep with you everywhere.

Overall, I definitely recommend these headphones if you're looking for some decent headphones for a great price. Perfect for the person who takes public transit, runs, or just lives an active lifestyle.

After listening to a bunch of different earbuds I have, I can put them into 2 categories: Ones that sound like music, and ones that sound like music is coming out of a tin can. These, unfortunately, do not sound like music. They are "right at the lip" of the tin can, but, yes, still "in" the tin can. I bought the Sennheiser MX365's at the same time as these, and there is no comparison as to the sound quality. I have another pair of Sennheiser buds, the MX271, and both are exceptional in sound. I have a couple pairs of old walkman buds that also have a very similar sound to these Sony's. I have a cheap pair of JBL's (no model #) that sound better than the Sony's, but tonally not very well balanced and well below the quality of the Sennheisers. Do yourself a favor, and spend just a few dollars more for a whole lot better experience and buy some Sennheisers.

A super easy and cheap replacement for my last pair. I'm not an audiophile and I' didn't want to pay a ton for watching movies on my phone. I'm also not someone that buys into name brands like Beats just because they're trendy. I needed something simple that wasn't made by a no-name company that may or may not exist in a year and these fit the bill. A great cheap alternative to more expensive options from a company you can at least immediately recognize so you don't have to worry about what corners were cut.

That being said, the sound quality is fine and even bordering on "good". The sound is about 4 stars for the price you pay. They look just like the pictures and the blue that I got are nice and subtle but bold at the same time. I hear a weird "click" sound every once in a while when I move around which I believe is coming from the headphones... or I'm going crazy only while wearing the earpieces. I'm waiting for them to tell me which it is. Until then, a perfect 4 star product that I'd gladly pay again to save a fortune.

I use my phone almost exclusively via earphone, so anytime I'm around others I at least have phones with me. I use these other than a headphone as I only read the phone rather than call, etc.. In other words I don't need the "call, dial, etc" features typically.. only listening.
Due to low vision, my phone has a text-to-voice app which most wouldn't use, but it makes the phone accessible for me. I also follow podcasts and audio books a fair amount and don't like bothering others.

I find that these phones have the following advantages:
1. Inexpensive, so if I lose it or it breaks or whatever, it's a minor issue
2. Rugged.. I don't baby them and them. Once the part holding the pads snapped out of the hole and had to be pushed back on
3 .I LOVE the "handing" rather than the "in ear" type.. Much more comfortable over longer periods, adequately loud, yet don't block outside sound.. I don't like to "sound bubble" myself
4. Cord is long enough for me to comfortably put my phone in my pants and run the line up my shirt to my ears.
5. Sound is decent for an earphone of this price. At higher prices, I'd have to make a decision
I am not saying this is a perfect item, but darn good for the price. I keep a spare in case I lose or break it. I definitely would buy it again.

This will be a first impression review of 3 Sony earbuds bought at the same time:
*** MDRE9LP (the Ipod type that only sits inside the outer part of the ear)
**** MDR-EX37B (black body insertion type)
***** MDR-EX25LP (tiny unit that goes entirely into the ear)

All arrived in the typical over-engineered packaging that you can see that the designer is the only one that knows how to open without destroying the packaging. I've yet to figure out why.

Background:
My wife uses earbuds all day, home or work. Connecting to her BLU Selfie phone, her HP Laptop, her Toshiba Chromebook and her various Samsung tablets. She goes through them quickly, but we've had bad results from buying cheap buds, especially the Panasonic RPHJE120 line, which we bought 5 different colors and are all in a drawer because they don't align easily in the ear and have low output volume and very low bass... unacceptable even though they are Amazon's #1 Best Seller. She prefered to tape together some of her other broken earbuds and limp along with those instead. Her favorites to date have been the nice earbuds that came with her BLU phone and some very old ones that came with an Ipod she seldom uses anymore, but both of those are held together with scotch tape and come apart easily.

Soooo, I decided to buy one each of some Sony units to see which she liked. We both tested each using the same song at the same volume out of the phone.

She likes the EX37B ones the best (first quick use). These were priced at $13.99 and are the standard kind of L configuration. I like that they have a rugged appearance and a very good stress relief so the wires are not so likely to get damaged when she yanks them out or they get snagged on something as she rushes around while using them. To me (refined pitch perfect audiophile ears), they are a little distorted and loud, but have tremendous bass response.

Second she liked the tiny EX25LP. THEY WERE MY FAVORITE BY FAR! These were priced $14.99 and are little egg-like things that fall completely in the ear with only the thin wire coming out. My concern with these was that there is no stress relief for the wires at all, but upon trying them, we both remarked how easily they slide exactly into the right place in our ears, no alignment needed and they come out VERY easy... but do not FALL out on their own. They fit perfectly and have a very good sound, but not a huge bass note like the EX37B and our BLU phone buds.

Lastly she didn't like the MDRE9LP units that just are like little speakers that do not go into the ear canal, like so many you see and exactly like the Ipod buds she likes so much. These are hard to place properly in the ear and don't have the volume or bass quality of the other two. They are the cheaper of the trio at $8.99 and I don't see these being used unless it's a choice between those and the Panasonics.

I will UPDATE this review as problems or wonders happen. Stay tuned.

these are really great---even AMAZING---for the price! i can't use those awful newfangled earbuds with the rubber tips, and it's getting impossible to find this kind in stores, so i bought two pairs of earbuds---these and some like knockoff-y samsung 6 ones like the ones that originally came with my phone---and these are WAY better. they stay in my ears while running (my ultimate #1 on checklists) and, as i use them every day and night, have already been through quite a bit of wear in two months and are going strong (they're getting a little crackly but it is not bothersome). i love that they come in all sorts of colors---makes it easy to identify which are mine/most current and find them in a pinch. no more frustrating rubber tip earbuds or cheap sad ones when i can find em at walgreens! i'm basically going to order these forever :)

I've used these earbuds for years and swear by them. If you want ear buds that you can take on 0 degree runs, accidentally send through the washer and dryer, travel with, crumple in your pocket, use to catch a falling phone, and generally misuse, buy these. Sound quality is still the same as the day I opened the package, and I've put these puppies through the wringer.

I buy a new pair every 2 years or so, and these are earbuds that I carry with me every single day. I've since been able to get other friends to use these in place of more expensive headphones, since the jewel tone plastic makes it easy to spot, and there's no need to baby these buds.

When I needed new earbuds I bought three sets to compare: Sony MDRE9LP, JVC HAF160, and Panasonic RP-HV41. All three are around $8.

In my opinion the Sony's were the worst, mostly due to the terrible bass response. Both the JVC and Panasonic buds had decent bass. In the end I liked the JVC set the best due to that and the fact they fit the best - the Panasonic ones are awkward and fall out easily.

For the record, I dislike buds that enter the ear canal. While they would probably give even better bass, I just can't do it.

These are my fave earbuds. Most earbuds, even the Apple ones that came with my phone, feel horrible in my ears after about 20 minutes. These are great. I can even sleep in these without discomfort. I've purchased a back-up pair for later. The audio quality is not the best out there, but for me, it doesn't matter if they sound amazing if my ear canal is in pain the whole time. They'd be perfect if they had a mic to use for phone calls

I'm not an audiophile. I do like my music to sound good. I also HATE the new ear buds that are dominating the market that have a piece that goes into your ear canal. What IS that?! It feels like a rectal exam for my ear. This is one of the few brands that still makes the kind that just sit in the outer part of your ear. They sound great. I have two pairs, one for two years and the other for a year. They still work great. I do not treat them gently but I haven't noticed any damage or crackling, and I use them almost every day. I wish they would give you extras of those foam covers, but oh well. I bought some separately here on Amazon and I switch thm out every so often.

for the price they work well and sound well. I bought these and one pair from another brand as a backup as the last few sets have not lasted long at all. So far these have worked well for months. They still sound good and have not frayed or split yet even though I have snagged them a bunch of times. Might buy a backup set while these are still made. They are not audiophile quality, but they are not terrible or full of noise either. Since I go through them often I try to buy the $5-$15 pairs because after that it starts to hurt too much to keep replacing.

I've purchased a bunch of these headphones in different colors in the past and I always come back for more. They are not the greatest sounding headphones out there, nor the most durable, but for headphones that cost less than $10, they are great. Also, they are not the headphones that go in ear (bullet looking headphones) which are now everywhere and I just can't keep those in my ears while exercising, they always come out. So I come back for these.

I wear these to the gym every day to listen to podcasts/music and each time they last between six and eight months. Pretty good overall based on cost.

The quality of these earbuds is terrible. I had a pair of these a few years ago (that were actually good) and when my current pair of earbuds died; I thought I'd save some money and try these out again. They've obviously changed something because these are AWFUL.

The sound quality is horrible. It sounds like the audio is coming from inside a tunnel. That's underwater. And 50 miles away. Very tinny and high with lots of static. The earbuds themselves feel too big as well, they don't fit in my ear quite right. I should have read more of the recent reviews before I wasted money on these.

Earbuds these days are like shirts. Everyone has them, you can get them for $1 and up. But these particular earbuds are the best quality you can buy for under $10. If you could do a sound comparison on these and the $10+ ones you will find subtle differences, but compared to any that cost $1, major differences, and these were only around $7! I like the depth of these, not tinny or compacted, there are definite deeps and lows in these compared to more treble as many others have. For a true audiophile, for the price and size they perform really well and are long enough to work while listening to your tunes. I use them on the subway train and don't really HAVE to turn them up all the way to get a rich sound with an ipod. I have two pairs because I like them so much. If you can afford these, get them. They will be your best sounding micros for the price!

I was disappointed because these were not what I thought I was buying. I had the exact same experience as previous reviewer AYG from July 10th:

"I ordered MDRE9LP/BLK Earbuds. Instead of the normal Sony packaging they came in a weird little ziplock bag kind of thing with the text "Original high quality best accessories".On the back is the text "Accessories There is no best only better products. Enjoy the best quality Made in China". No mention of Sony on the packaging they came in anywhere. There is a label stuck on the back that says Sony black MADE IN CHINA. I opened them up and there are white earbuds inside, not black. They actually look more like MDRE9LP/GRAY. However, the printing on the side is so faint you can barely even see it and the parts don't seem to have a good fit. I actually had to put reading glasses on to read the logo. Sony is usually pretty good about making sure you can see their logo on their products and I don't think they usually ship them in a bag that says Best Accessories, Original High quality."

Like AYG, I got white headphones instead of black, they came in strange packaging, and the sound quality is poor. I'm not even super picky about having perfect sound--but these crackle when I listen through them. Disappointing for sure.

I would buy any brand of cheap earbuds, but they would fray before I'd finish using them.
Then I would exclusively buy Gummy brand because the sound quality was no different, but the rubber sheath covering the cord would last much longer.

Then the last Gummy gave out after a year or so and someone somewhere on the internet suggested these Sony earbuds.
The difference in sound quality is amazing! I didn't realize I'd been listening to poor quality sound for years until I bought this last month. They are a couple dollars more than the Gummy and they are worth it.

I had used Sony ear buds before but they're different ear buds,but these pairs of earbuds work fine and I use them when I'm doing exercise.The only thing that really makes me like them a lot are the sponges that I put on each one of the earbud,and they stay in place I don't have to move them all the time to put them in place because the sponge keeps them in place.

BEST HEAD PHONE I EVER USEDDDDDDD!!!!!!!!!!!!! Honestly I brought these because I need 8 more dollars for free shipping on Amazon. I didn't expect these to last too long, Its a year and half later and it still works like new. I mainly used Skull Candy head phones before for 2-3x the price and they would last me like 3 months to 1 year(RARELY). I use them a lot on the train, walking outside, and on my computer. Very good unexpected value.

I am really happy with these Sony Ear Buds. I am enjoying using them to listen to audible books while walking my dog, music while writing, podcasts and for meditations before bed and the sound is crisp and clear. What has been wonderful is the ear buds have been very comfortable. I have petite ears so normally ear buds can either not fit well and cause discomfort but even when I am exercising, they remain in place and are comfortable the entire time! I have paid a lot more for ear buds in the past and they haven't worked as well or been as nice as these.

I bought pair of these in three different colors. My absolute favorite ear buds. Previous pair I had lasted for three years. I only tossed them out because I thought they went bad, but it turns out my phone's headphone jack went bad. So, who knows how long that pair could have lasted.

If you're looking for a lot of bass in your ear buds or headphones, this isn't the pair for you.

LOVE LOVE LOVE these. I know a lot of people prefer silicone buds these days but those never stay in my ear. These are the perfect for my ears and they never fall out. Sound quality isn't complete trash too. If they came with a mic they're be perfect.

I like the fact that these don't have to be plugged in the earhole(, and scraping parts of it). The sound quality is sufficiently clear and comforable to wear and light. I have 2 sets of these at any one time. 1 set will become defective in 12 months; either one side starts to give off no sound. I just replacement it again and again.

But for the price, it can't be beat and a good replacement.

I was looking for earbuds at the price/quality of my trusty old sony mdr818. Unfortunately, sony stopped making them so I thought I would try these mdre9lp. Sadly, there is no comparing the two. Maybe I got defective ones, but the build quality of the ones I received are so bad compared to the 818s. The wires and their connections are thin and flimsy - maybe lightly better than what you'd get for free on an airplane. The sound quality is also poor, like tin cans compared to the 818s. Even without the foam tips, the 818s have more base and full sound than these. So disappointed.

For the price, these little guys are excellent. I've been using them since the summer with both my laptop and my cell phone and they're still clear as a bell. For those music nerds out there, the stereo quality and bass does leave something to be desired, but what do you want for under $10 ??? I use them for watching tv shows, movies, videos and you tube as well as music at pretty high volumes and they're pretty sensitive. I just love them and am buying a pair for my mom right now. :)

Got as replacement for previous model of these ear buds that I've had forever. (I accidentally damaged them) That replaced tiny Panasonic ear buds that i could not find again.

I wish they could make them even smaller so more comfortable to nap with.

This Sony model seems to be pretty much it if you need very small ear buds that are not the in ear kind. I'm seriously considering buying half a dozen in case they discontinue regular earbuds for in ear kind. Don't understand why they are out of fashion. I personally cant stand the in ear kind.

I bought this when another similar SONY earphones failed and those lasted me about 1 year. Good quality, basic headphones. Obviously you get what you pay for, so don't expect much, but I do think these exceed other headphones in the same price range. I will definitely buy again.
Nice

The earbuds were too big for my ears so they kept falling out and didn't sound good. I tried to return them but was informed by Amazon that they were not eligible for return. Gave them to some friends who seem to be happy with them.
Good earbuds, comfortable, great sound for a great price!
These are amazingly sturdy. I'm still using them but ymmv. I'm very happy with this purchase.
My son is very picky when it comes to earbuds. He says the sound quality is good and they don't bother his ears when he works out.
good !
It's not been a month since I bought these and my right earbud is not working

They are a little hard in the ears but no problems
With them other than that. Great product. I've been buying these ear buds for this vendor for quite some time and have never had a problem with so far

I got this item because Amazon's metadata said that it was a newer version of my MDRE10LP headphones that are finally wearing out after 3 years.

If this is the new one, they need to scrap the design and start over. The audio quality is crap. By comparison it is like listening to mono vs stereo. No base, mid is too high, and the treble sounds like it's coming through a can.
work and sound fine. only problem is the foam pads always fall off and the ear piece does not stay in the ears without them.

The sound quality sucks, put these in your pockets routinely and you'll have to spend minutes untangling them ( which is really annoying)
Don't waste your money on these they suck
Great sound and great product for such a low price, highly recommend!
Good quality
These are my favorite headphones. It fits and I've been buying them for years. Plus it last me for months. The longest time I've had a pair of these were about a year.
Broke
The new design is cool looking. My wife uses them when she goes jogging. Good sound for the price. I would buy them again.

I bought these instead of the Panasonic brand which stopped working in one ear after a while, and then in both ears. This was the second time I had bought Panasonic. I hope this brand does not give me trouble as well but I already appreciate the superior sound that it has!

I bought these earbuds about a week and a half ago, and they performed well in those few days. Afterwards, as I was holding an earbud in my hand, I dropped the earbuds on my glass table (not a very big drop to begin with, barely a foot) and the cover broke off the left one.

Guess that's how well a 7 dollar set of earbuds are made...
good quality. As expected

I had purchased some Panasonic RP-HV096 just recently only to be completely disappointed with the terrible quality of those earphones. These manage to feel better but sound worse, I could not believe my ears. I thought I had made a mistake going with Panasonic instead of Sony but apparently they are all equally trash. Still nothing to officially replace my old MDR-E818LP earphones.

I'm not sure what the deal is, maybe I got counterfeits. If that is the case, then the cheap reproduction Sony/iPod headphones directly from China sound better and are a quarter of the price. These are a waste of your money.

I've been using the excellent MDRe10 earbuds for years (which are now out of production) and wanted to replace them with the newer Sony MDRe9. BIG MISTAKE. The quality is terrible, instant and undeniable. I've decided to steer clear of Sony headphones in future because of this (yes, these ear buds are THAT BAD - we're talking 99 cent store quality). Why is there barely any bass?

The sound quality is just like any other ear phone. It is a bit clearer than average though. Yet, the bass quality of these earphones are low to nothing. I can barely hear any bass, yet I can't expect much for this price because it isn't one of those high performance quality headsets or something. Overall, it has a long enough cord. I'm not into the L shaped aux tip though. I guess it helps with angle and how much you turn your body. I believe it also prevents the cord from ripping and getting damaged from the end. Fits my ear pretty well without falling out. I have always liked Sony brand products. Yet, they are sometimes expensive. I'm cool with these though.

Earbuds are frustrating. I like the way these Sony earbuds fit (flat on the side and easy to wear when falling asleep). I get very frustrated with Sony because they don't work well for very long. Quickly one side or the other quits. I bought these because reviews of most earbuds are that they don't fit or they fall out so I decided to go with these - they fit me and their price is low. I'm making do, hoping this industry can come up with something that works!

One of the main problems with headphones (especially smaller or cheaper ones), is that the cord ends up getting bent (mostly in the area near the plug), resulting in poor sound, a breaking connection, or just no function at all.

It generally takes headphones a few months to a few years to get to this point. Not the case with these headphones! Right out of the box, the cord needed to be placed in a perfect position in order to have any sound output. Any slight movement caused it to cut out.

Not an issue with shipping, as they were well packed in their plastic bubble. Just a very poorly made product.

I have a pair of these that I've been using for 2 or 3 years. They sound quite good and are very compact. The stem/body (where the wires enter) is smaller than most ear buds. This has proven very useful for times when I put on hearing protection (when mowing grass for example) or when wearing a snug fitting hat. The low price makes the purchase a no-brainer.

Edited to add 1) the plug is a right-angle design, and 2) the left ear plug has a small bump on it so that you don't have to read the printed "L". This info was not provided in the product description.

I'm amazed by the number of positive reviews here, because I could not be more disappointed with these earbuds. Like several others, I owned and used the previous model of this product (E10LP) for years because they were both very cheap and had surprisingly good sound quality. Which is why I bought these. But I guess I should have paid more attention to the reviews beforehand, because the sound quality of these things is abysmal. Have you ever accidentally pulled your headphones partially out of the jack, and you get that really hollow sound quality, usually only coming out of one earbud? That's what these sound like. It is the most insubstantial sound I have ever gotten from a pair of headphones. As someone who usually hates the high amount of bass found in many cheap earbuds, I'm yearning for more bass here the way Oliver Twist yearns for a second helping of gruel. I can't even say "well, I guess at least I have a backup pair" because listening to music on these is physically discomforting. You might as well just hire a bum to shout songs through a tin can tied to a string.

Two stars for these only because they are functional, in the loosest sense of the word. Maybe you could get some use out of them listening to talk radio or something similar, but do yourself a favor, and buy a pair of E10LP's (which is what I just did before writing this review). There are plenty of people still selling them on Amazon.

HORRIBLE sound quality, do not fit in my ears well, and the cord seems to already have some damage after just opening it less than 3 minutes ago-if I move it the slightest bit, the [poor quality] sound gets staticky and stops working. Went to try to return it and says "not eligible for return." I am furious!

I had an older iteration of these that worked well even after I dunked them in my morning tea. The ear bud was comfortable and small. I figured I'd upgrade and ended up being just so-so. The ear piece is pretty bulky and the sound wasn't that great. I used to take walks with these and it was okay that sounds penetrated because then I could hear what was going on around me.

One fateful afternoon, not three weeks after I purchased them, I bent over to tie my shoe and when I stood up the wire wrapped around my knee, and the bud was yanked from my ear and rather dramatically whipped around and smashed onto the floor. :(

Not a spectacular set of earphones, and not an average set either. I like these for the adequate resonance in sound since I do listen to varied forms of music. I would advise to adjust your player's (phone, mp3 player, etc.) equalizer to your liking; they will be dynamic enough to adjust! Overall, if you take care of them they will make your music enjoyable till you find that other earphones (with a bigger bass response and fuller range) are appropriate to your listening experience. Sony brand knows their tech :)

I used to have these exact same headphones, except they were blue! These are great headphones for a sweaty workout. I am a runner and a fitness freak. Whenever I worked out, the buds never fell out of my ears and they stayed in place.

Somehow, my blue headphones got misplaced either I threw them away by accident, they were stolen or I must have dropped it by accident somewhere. So I re-ordered new ones, and I am glad they have green ones, too. Green is my favorite color so yep! For anyone who is looking to buy headphones for a workout session to listen to your music as your run, buy these. They have a good cord length and like I said, stay in your ears.

The ones I have now, "Gummy" Sony black ones. The ear buds always fall out of my ears. As I am running, I have to reach out to the ear bud, as it falling out of my ears, and put it back in there. The cord length to my current ones are very short and they bother me because I like to run the cord underneath my shirt so it's a problem for me. I would not recommend the "Gummy" Sony earphones. Just these!

However, the sound quality for both headphones are excellent! I can't wait to get my green ones in the mail. I brought the blue ones at a K-Mart and they lasted me for two years!!
Nothing fancy but they certainly do that job. I'm not an audiophile so I hardly notice the quality of a headphone unless it is truly terrible, these are not terrible and seem pretty sturdy.

I purchased these to replace the ones that were originally supplied with my Walkman. I didn't need anything fancy and these are very basic, but they are comfortable and the sound is good. They are comfy enough as is, but there are also some little spongy covers included, if you prefer not to have the hard plastic right up against your skin. The cord is longer than the original ones, which has turned out to be a big help, as I tend to catch it on things. (It's nice not to have them yanked out of my ears!) Finally, the plug is L-shaped, which helps keep the plug plugged in, even when jogging, etc. I would recommend these to anyone wanting basic buds at a great price.

Very disappointed with these headphones. I've purchased several Sony MDRE10LP earbuds, and while they ended up breaking after about a year they were comfortable and reliable until then, and while some people might not like the sound quality I couldn't tell the difference. The MDRE9LP sound is noticeably tinnier, although my ears get used to that after a while and the wires for the two earbuds separate about 18" from the earbud, significantly longer & more prone to tangling than the MDRE10LP and it doesn't have a slider to shorten it. But the reason I will not buy this model again is that the plug seems ridiculously sensitive. If the plug shifts a bit while the device it's connected to is in my pocket I get bursts of static & lower volume, which eventually turns into no volume if I don't twist or press it back. I've tried unplugging & replugging to see if it was just how I put it in, but the problem keeps recurring. I'll keep these as emergency backup headphones, but they won't be the ones I regularly use.

These are the only ear buds I buy because they are the only ones that stay in my ears. They also last a long time and let me tell you they are in my ears All day.....Every Day... Except that one time I accidentally cut the wire to one ear with a pair of scissors.

These are not as good as the ones that Sony makes which have soft material that fits into the ear. These sit just inside the ear and I don't find them as comfortable as the others, nor do they have the same sound.
